text: Text: Charging families for each bag of rubbish they produce seems like a good idea for the environment and economy. But it might not be. In many developed countries, people have their rubbish collected regularly. They put their rubbish in bags or bins, and a special truck takes it away to a landfill. Economists find this strange because it seems free. Families pay for this service through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a couple that throws away very little. However, getting rid of rubbish is not free. The more rubbish there is, the more collectors and trucks are needed, and the more local authorities have to pay for landfill fees. This is a basic economic problem: if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. The simple solution is to make families pay for the amount of rubbish they throw away. This would encourage them to throw out less and recycle more, assuming there are places to recycle. But two American economists, Don Fullerton and Thomas Kinnaman, found that this idea has complicated and sometimes disappointing results. They studied several American towns and cities that started charging for rubbish. The most common system is to sell stickers or tags for rubbish bags or cans. Only bags with these labels are collected. In a study, they looked at a scheme in Charlottesville, Virginia, where residents paid 80 cents for each tagged bag. This seemed like a good use of market forces. However, the authors found that the benefits did not cover the costs of the scheme. The number of bags did fall by 37%, but this was because people crammed more rubbish into each bag by jumping on it. The weight of rubbish collected fell by only 14%. In other Virginian cities without a pricing scheme, it fell by 3.5% anyway. Some people also dumped rubbish illegally to avoid paying. This is hard to measure, but the authors think illegal dumping might account for 30-40% of the reduction in collected rubbish. One positive result was a 15% increase in recycling, suggesting people chose to recycle instead of paying for rubbish collection. But the fee might not be the main reason for more recycling, as many people were already recycling voluntarily. In another study, Fullerton and Kinnaman found that pricing does reduce rubbish weight, but not by much. A 10% increase in sticker prices cuts rubbish by only 0.3%. This is lower than in other studies, but not surprising. To reduce rubbish a lot, people would need to buy less of everything. A small tax on rubbish is unlikely to make a big difference. Other factors, like income and education, might be just as important as price. In richer towns, people throw out more rubbish and have less time to recycle. Should we think charging for rubbish is a bad idea? Not at all. Free disposal is too cheap. But simple policies can have complex effects. Detailed economic models are often needed to understand them, and sometimes the results are not what we expect.

Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, character, and relationships. This is important because if your skills make you boring or unable to talk to others outside your field, or if you are too busy to learn new things or be creative, then no amount of money or status will make up for not being a well-rounded person.

Zeldin wants to find out how work can help us grow as people, instead of just shaping us to fit industrial needs. Work should not only be about making money but also about living a fulfilling life, discovering new talents, and meeting different people. However, this does not mean getting rid of unemployment is the only goal. As people become more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and meaningful. Work should be like a piece of art, with a happy person at its center.

Even traditional jobs like doctors, accountants, and architects are not as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are often more stressed than their patients, accountants worry about ethics, and architects rarely get to be creative. Middle managers are losing confidence in their roles. Companies and public institutions are getting smaller, and new ideas like decentralizing decisions and rewarding performance have not made employees more committed. In Britain, only 8% of employees feel their values match their organization's values.

Zeldin is studying different jobs to see how they affect people. He looks at how different cultures have expanded what humans can do and how courage can be developed. He is interested in happiness, love, friendship, and respect, and now he is focusing on finding more satisfying ways to work. Many experts work on making companies last longer and earn more money, but we also need to think about what kind of people we want to be and who we want to spend our time with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many of us feel like part-time slaves, stuck in jobs because we see no other choice?

Take hotel workers, for example. They make up 10% of the workforce in the hospitality industry. Many smart and lively people work in hotels but have low prestige, low pay, and long hours. Hotels have not changed much since the days of the Ritz, with its old idea of luxury. A hotel is not just a place to sleep; it is like a small United Nations where people from all over the world meet, but often do not talk to each other. Many hotel staff are foreigners who want to learn a new language and culture, but they have little interaction with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, connecting guests with the city and each other. They could use the skills of the students they hire, instead of giving them only simple tasks. If hotels paid attention to their staff's dreams, they could offer many more services. But accountants often say hotels should focus on one main activity to make the most money.

Zeldin believes work is about relationships. People want jobs that let them be independent and express themselves. They should be able to design their own jobs and choose their colleagues and customers, as long as it is practical and profitable. This means they need to communicate well with people from different fields. Communication is important, but real conversation is different. It is a deeper connection that creates respect and can change people. Every meaningful conversation can change the world a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**

The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand over a large area. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents the hope of modern times. It suggests planned growth and success if conditions are right. Broadcasting assumes there is a central source, like a bucket of seeds, ready to spread information widely.

The question is why a new technology that could send words and pictures electronically was set up in a way that fits this farming idea. Television, like the telegraph and telephone, is a two-way communication tool. But from the start, it was seen as a one-way, mass communication tool. Sending broadcasts from a central place to homes matched the social and economic structures of modern societies. Other ways of organizing television were tried but did not last.

Two interesting alternatives to traditional broadcasting deserve mention. In the early 1930s in Britain, radio enthusiasts experimented with two-way television, similar to a telephone. Magazines like Radio News explained how to build TV transmitters and receivers. However, in 1938, the British Radio Manufacturers Association set standards that pushed these hobbyists out. This ended the chance for television to develop as a grassroots, equal form of communication in Britain.

Broadcasting was linked to strong economic interests and the structure of modern societies. In the USA in the early 1930s, television was mainly used for public shows and was seen as a competitor to the film industry. In Britain and Germany, most people watched TV in public places. The idea of two-way, amateur television was not successful, but public viewing of TV was common in several countries in the 1930s. However, this did not stop the move towards home television.

Manufacturers saw the potential for selling TVs to homes once prices dropped. As working-class people improved their living standards from the 1920s, the dream of having entertainment at home became possible for many in Western countries. This trend is now happening worldwide. There is a link between social changes and how broadcasting is organized. As societies became more modern, power and money became more centralized, and traditional communities broke up. People moved more, both socially and geographically, leading to more isolated lives.

Centralized broadcasting helped governments reach all citizens with important information and created a sense of national community. This made broadcasting the main way to organize radio and TV. Broadcasting also played a role in democracy by providing equal access to information needed for political and social participation.

Television is changing, and the term 'broadcasting' might become outdated. If that happens, the idea of broadcasting will be seen as a way of organizing technology during a certain time in social history.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes it feels like no matter how many things you own, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes wanting more things can get out of control. Modern advertising is made to make us feel insecure. It often tells us that if we don't have certain things, we are not good enough. To see how much ads affect you, try not to read any billboards next time you walk down the street. These expensive ads try to convince us to buy things in ways we don't even notice. We see them everywhere—on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, T-shirts, the internet, and more—all telling us to buy, buy, buy.

**Caves**  
Research centers and universities around the world have spent many years studying caves. They look at how caves are formed, how water moves through them, and the life inside them. Caves are a small but mysterious part of nature, and they make us curious. Because of this, a lot of research has been done on them. In some parts of the world, caves have been important to how people live, so they have been studied even more. However, visiting many caves requires physical skill, so cave research is often done by both scientists and people who explore caves for fun.

**Weather Watch**  
Many people who watched the weather without any tools helped start the science of meteorology. Since the 17th century, it has become a very technical science. Today, satellites and electronic tools send us weather information quickly, and computers solve difficult math problems faster than humans can. Meteorology uses many long words that are hard to understand for most people. But simple weather knowledge is still important. Human experience is key to turning computer data into weather forecasts. People’s observations can still give important information to help professionals understand the atmosphere.

**MUSIC AND THEATRE**

Until recently, I thought opera was mainly about theatre. But after working at a national opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. This makes sense, but I come from the theatre world, where the words and the actors are the focus. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once the play starts, and the performers and audience usually speak the same language.

At musical performances, like concerts or operas, many people, including me, might not understand music technically. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. A great singer or a perfect orchestra is easy to admire. Even a good musician shows the results of years of hard work. Watching top-class music is like watching a sports match. We know athletes do something similar to us when we run, but they do it much better.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They often don't understand an actor's skill and aren't as impressed by something that seems like what they could do. They don't usually admire an actor for remembering long speeches, though they often ask, "How do you learn all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are more or less demanding than music audiences. Many people go to both. But in theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms, no matter how difficult the play is.

Should music learn from theatre about this relationship? I think yes. Music performances are full of emotion and can be very theatrical. But the way music is presented, with strict dress codes and respect for conductors and soloists, can make the difference between performers and audiences feel too big. Also, when audiences clap between movements or after a great performance, it can interrupt the flow of the music.

Is there a solution? Yes, a lot is being done to bring new audiences to concerts and operas and to make serious music more accessible. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from a cathedral to the town. It was a high-quality musical experience and life-changing for many in the audience, who also participated.

I wish music had more of the risk and excitement that theatre can have. Sometimes this comes from using unusual locations, which can surprise both performers and audiences. It might be uncomfortable, but theatre audiences are used to following artists into unexpected places. Most plays are performed in a traditional way, similar to concerts. But I believe music conventions can and should change.

I am just an enthusiast who loves theatre and music. I want both to succeed and for more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**  
I admire how sand can be turned into useful things like glass and concrete, but I don't like it much in its natural form. For me, sand is a problem that lies between the car park at the beach and the water. It blows into your face, gets into your sandwiches, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you like glue and is hard to remove, even with a strong water spray. But here's the funny thing: as soon as you step onto a beach towel, get into a car, or walk on a clean carpet, sand falls off you. For days, you keep finding sand on the floor every time you take off your shoes, and more sand comes out when you take off your socks. Sand stays with you longer than some illnesses. No, I don't like sand at all.

**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home for privacy and security since they first started building houses. The simple wooden bar behind the door has changed to an electronic lock that uses a plastic card with many combinations. But the need to keep out the 'bad guys' is still there. Locks and keys are comforting to people. Recently, some companies have tried using computerized locks, where smart cards control electronic locks. But people don't like them much. You might accept them at work, but at home, everyone wants the comfort of turning a real key in a lock. So, when one locksmith company made a new electronic system, they included a real metal key in it.

**Modern Art**  
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because, like many people, I don't understand modern art well. I know I like some of it, especially furry things, neon light sculptures, and big photos. Maybe if I knew more about it, I would have opinions on more things. But you're not supposed to think about it like a school essay. The idea is not to understand art but to let it speak to you. This is a great idea, but it never worked for me. However, this new gallery tries to help visitors understand the art. The first thing I noticed were the labels, real labels that explain the art and tell you what it means. Instead of just staring at the pictures without understanding, these bits of information helped me get it.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

When books are turned into movies, a lot of the story is cut or changed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also be interesting. While working on a movie script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of the dialogue and descriptions from the book and still keep the main idea. This doesn't mean the original book had unnecessary parts. It's about how each type of storytelling, like books or movies, needs different things from the audience. In books, certain details, like character traits or who is speaking, are repeated to help the reader understand. In plays, which are mostly dialogue, the way people talk can be very realistic or very stylized. Sometimes, the dialogue is so full of extra words that it's hard to know what's really being said.

**Watching Movies**

When you watch a movie, you can feel like you're part of the story. It's an experience that takes you away from real life for a while. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, you're back in the real world. In the past, some people thought movies were just for fun and not a real art form. They liked watching movies but didn't think they were as important as other arts.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were no clear signs or main entrance. There were three main entrances, but only one led to where you wanted to go. It was confusing for visitors, but the people who worked there knew their way around. These workers helped create movies that brought excitement and adventure to people, letting them escape from their everyday problems for a few hours.

**Film-makers**

Many people dream of making movies. Bookstores have many guides on how to write scripts and make films. Universities offer courses, and there are contests to win cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make his film El Mariachi. This film cost $7,000 and made him famous. Rodriguez achieved his dream early, making his first big film before he turned 25. In the past, filmmakers took longer to succeed. They learned by working in different jobs like editing or writing. Directors like John Huston and Fred Zinnemann made their first big films later in life. Today, without the support of big studios, new filmmakers have to be independent and creative.

In those days, the council houses covered the western side of the city. They were rows of small, dull houses made of orange half-brick or pale white stucco. In the summer, chemicals from the May and Baker factory, two miles away, filled the air with a strong smell of sulfur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he walked up to someone's front door. 

I have forgotten most of my early life, but I remember sitting near an upstairs window, looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. Later, I have other memories, like faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that I don't think was ours, and snow falling over the big mansion at Earlham. 

My mother often appears in these early memories. She was a small, precise, and often angry woman. I never understood why she was angry, so I couldn't do anything to make her happy. Even as a child, when I went with her to the small shops in Bunnett Square or on longer trips into the city, I noticed her unusual personality. She was the most solitary person I have ever known, alone even in a room full of people. She also had strict rules about how to behave, which was unusual in West Earlham. This sometimes led to intense cleaning or telling me to 'behave properly.' I didn't understand these rules, and even now, I'm not sure I do. 

For example, it meant not walking into neighbors' gardens or damaging their rose bushes, sitting quietly in the dining room with hands folded, listening to radio programs my mother liked, and many other rules. Over time, other people appeared in these early memories. Despite her loneliness, my mother had friends. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who rarely spoke, and Mrs. Laband, who was livelier and not fully approved by the others. Later, I realized that this group was not very cheerful. They often talked about their health, the cold weather, and ungrateful children, a group I often felt I was part of. 

Looking back, it felt like a heavy weight of the West Earlham houses, my mother and her friends, and the need to 'behave properly' was on my shoulders. I felt I had to grow up quickly to free myself from it. But this was not easy. Growing up in West Earlham followed a set pattern. Until you were five, you stayed at home, often getting in your parents' way. I remember boring days when I was about four, playing on a rug while my mother sat in an armchair. Then, after your fifth birthday, you went to Avenue Road infants school, half a mile away. Some lucky children had a mother with a bike and a child seat. I think my mother let other children in the street take me to school. 

If I remember anything about these early years, it's the summer holidays. During these times, I saw glimpses of the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next to Mrs. Buddery who told stories about his time in the Merchant Navy. Once, there was a charity event at a house far away, where a kind woman gave out lemonade and talked about something called the League of Pity, a junior charity. But my mother dismissed it, saying they just wanted money. My mother often talked about people wanting money, and she had a low opinion of politicians. She thought of the House of Commons as a place where rich people took money from the public. 

I might be exaggerating, and I might not be fair to my mother. But she didn't show much kindness. However, she did care about my education. Sometimes on Sundays, she would take me, dressed in my 'good clothes,' on the 85 bus to the Norwich Castle Museum. We would walk through rooms of paintings by the Norwich School of Artists. My mother didn't mind this activity and even started to have opinions about the paintings. I remember her once stopping in front of a painting of a Roman soldier and saying, 'Well, I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!' This was one of the few times I remember her trying to make a joke.

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the side with odd-numbered houses. It was getting dark, and the air was thick and wet, making my walk feel secretive. I knew this side of the street well since I was a child. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards, and there was Han Kieffer's grocery store. My first friends, who were all girls, lived in the Kring's and the Pottses' houses. Even if I didn't know everyone by name, each house was special to me, like the little rain channels in the sidewalk that I used to skate over. As the street went downhill, the houses seemed a bit less fancy, with lower porches and smaller front yards. Over time, some things changed: wooden porch railings were replaced with iron ones. In Shillington, some houses became stores, and some stores, like Pep Conrad's and Han Kieffer's, became homes again. I wondered how people lived in these spaces that used to be shops.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert, a furniture designer, lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. It has typical loft features like exposed brick and big doors. But Gilbert didn't want an open space because it was hard to separate work from home life. So, he used a large plastic sheet to create a hallway and hide his office. This also led the eye to the kitchen, which he wanted to be a neutral area for both cooking and meeting clients. To balance the modern look of his flat, he used light wood floors and added some sentimental furniture from his parents and markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin was a writer known for his adventurous life and mysterious stories. His first book, "In Patagonia," published in 1977, changed travel writing. It was exciting and imaginative, mixing real events with fiction to make the stories more interesting. Chatwin believed that through travel, one could discover fascinating histories.

**Swimming**

One summer, during a heavy rain, I swam in the pool behind my house. The rain made bubbles on the water, and the storm was so loud it drowned out the birds. It was then, in 1996, that I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and escape the routine of swimming back and forth in a pool. Many places today are clearly marked and explained, but activities like walking, cycling, and swimming let us explore and find mystery. A swimming journey would help me connect with the wild and unknown parts of the world.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose in evolution. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps create a bond between mother and child. Many people think that tears, especially in children, show helplessness. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than the way it looks. In early human groups, crying might have helped build trust and social connections. Tears can also happen for other reasons. We might cry to show sympathy for people facing injustice. Sometimes, we cry without meaning to, like when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, and this often happens more when we are with others than when we are alone. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**

We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it change our lives? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but no one is sure about its effects. A warmer climate will likely change the weather everywhere. Since the atmosphere is connected to everything on our planet, changes in climate will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. So, any changes to these resources are important.

The problem is understanding how the world will change and what causes these changes. In the last 100 years, human activities have increased the amount of certain gases in the atmosphere, which are linked to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the climate now and will continue to do so. We know that greenhouse gases and global temperatures have changed together over the past 40,000 years, showing they are related. Evidence suggests the Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C in the last century. Most scientists believe this warming is partly due to human pollution.

A lot of research uses computer models to predict what will happen with higher global temperatures. These models use physics and chemistry to study temperature, pressure, solar radiation, and other climate factors. However, they are not perfect and can be slow and costly. We do not fully understand all climate processes, but we know they are complex. Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before. Predictions suggest the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C by 2100, sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and rainfall patterns will change. Extreme weather like heatwaves, floods, and droughts may become more common.

These changes could affect where plants and animals live, the mix of species, and the benefits they provide to humans. This includes food production, water resources, and human settlements. Some effects might be irreversible and harmful, but not all. Some impacts could be positive. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have increased wheat yields since 1952 because there are fewer frosts.

However, many future effects of climate warming are not good. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry areas or places with existing shortages. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where rainfall patterns have changed. Another problem is changes to glaciers, which will affect ice, vegetation, wildlife, and human structures. The Arctic ice might melt completely, making it easier for marine transport and oil exploration but increasing iceberg dangers.

The most visible effect of global warming could be rising sea levels. This happens because warmer water takes up more space and melting ice adds more water. With about half of the world's population living near coasts, rising sea levels could cause severe problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo might face flooding. Many people could lose their homes, creating environmental refugees. Small island countries could disappear if the worst happens, affecting their people and culture and putting pressure on other countries to help displaced people.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong both physically and emotionally. This is the type of people needed for the first trip to Mars if millionaire Dennis Tito's plans to send a spacecraft on 5 January 2018 actually happen. The spacecraft will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. It will use Mars's gravity to return to Earth without using more fuel, because saving fuel is very important. The 2018 date is set because the next time Mars and Earth are in the right position for a launch is in 2031. It is a big challenge, and new technologies need to be developed quickly. If everything is ready in time, the spacecraft might succeed. But even if it doesn't launch, the work done to reach these goals will help future space missions.'

**Aesthetics**

Sometimes, the very existence of art makes it hard to understand what art really means. Artworks like buildings, books, paintings, or statues are often seen as just physical objects. People often forget that the real art is what these objects do to our experiences and feelings. This misunderstanding makes it difficult to truly understand art.

Some artworks are so admired and perfect that they create fixed ideas, which can block new ways of thinking about them. When an artwork becomes a classic, it often gets separated from the human experiences and conditions that created it. This separation makes it hard to see the true meaning of art, which is what aesthetic theory tries to explain. Art is often put in a special category, away from other human activities and achievements.

The main job for someone who wants to write about the philosophy of art is to connect art with everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art should be seen as part of human experience. To understand art, we need to look at everyday experiences that we don't usually think of as art. We need to take a different path to understand art.

For example, you can enjoy flowers without knowing how they grow. But to understand flowers, you need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. Similarly, to understand art, we need to start with everyday events and scenes that catch our attention and give us joy.

Many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comic strips without thinking of them as art. When art is only seen in museums and galleries, people look for enjoyable experiences in their daily lives. Even those who disagree with the idea of art being only in museums often still separate art from everyday life. The best times for appreciating art are when it is closely connected to everyday activities.

**Observing Lions**

People often imagine lions hunting as a perfect team. In the evening light, a group of quiet lions suddenly appears and surrounds their prey. Lions seem like perfect social animals, working together for a common goal, which is their next meal. However, after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. When we started our research in 1978, we wanted to find out why lions hunt together, raise their cubs, and scare away rivals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its young survive, then working together might not always be best. If an animal is too generous, others might benefit more. So, why do lions cooperate? We thought we could answer this in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. Like the noble gases krypton, argon, and neon, lions are often inactive. It has taken many research methods to learn about their behavior. Since wild lions can live up to 18 years, we are only now starting to understand them.

**Pop Music Review**

The release of Bedrock's third album was a big moment for the band. "New Life" started a new trend in rock music in the country for the rest of the decade. The old style of serious music with loud guitars was replaced by a lighter, more melodic style. The album mixed social themes with fun sounds like fairground organs and brass bands. It was full of humor and irony, and the singers didn't hide their accents. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting different styles and writing songs. They sang about typical English topics like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. But the album's real strength was in its deeper, more emotional songs like "So Low" and "To the Brink." "New Life" is a beautiful album with 16 high-quality tracks and no unnecessary songs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I was fascinated by stories of "The Sibyl," wise women with great influence in ancient times. I first heard about them from a story my mother told me. An old woman from Cumae offered nine books to Tarquin, King of Rome, for 300 gold pieces. He refused, so she burned three books and offered the remaining six for the same price. When he refused again, she burned three more books. He finally bought the last three for the full price. I learned an important lesson from this story about salesmanship and life. As a lonely child, I often asked to play with others but was refused. My mother advised me to do something interesting so others would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson. When I had the chance to write a travel book, I looked for something meaningful to me. I'm not a big traveler, so I sent my editor a list of places I didn't want to visit. I am interested in ruins because I like to travel through time in my mind.

**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**

When you submit your manuscript, it usually goes into a pile waiting to be sorted. This pile is called the "slush pile." The person sorting it is often a young editorial assistant or an experienced freelancer. They don't have much power, but they want to find something original. The junior wants to make a name for themselves, and the freelancer wants to keep their job. If they like your novel, they will pass it to a senior editor. Eventually, it will be discussed at a meeting. The editor must explain why your novel is good and if it can sell well. They also consider if you, as an author, have a future and if you can be promoted. Publishers often want to meet a new author before making an offer.

**Advertising Challenges in the Early 1990s**

If you worked in advertising during the early 1990s, it was likely a very tough time. The economy was in a recession, which was worse than expected. This affected many countries, especially industrialized ones, and was the worst in thirty years. In Britain, 1991 was particularly hard. The economy shrank, interest rates were high, people spent less money, over half a million people lost their jobs, and many homes were taken back by banks. Every business felt the impact, with some industries like car manufacturing and construction seeing a 30% drop in business. Many people and companies suffered.

Advertising professionals were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They were expected to help companies make money, so they were watched closely by their bosses. They also had to do more work with less money. Despite these challenges, the importance of marketing was growing. Companies started to focus more on making products that customers wanted, not just what was easy to produce. This change meant marketing was taken more seriously, and marketing professionals gained more respect, but also more responsibility.

Marketing was seen as a solution to many problems, and about half of marketing budgets were spent on advertising. In the 1980s, advertising was very successful, but the start of the 1990s was difficult for the industry. The recession made companies look closely at their advertising spending. They wanted to know if the money spent on advertising was worth it. Many companies were not sure what they were getting in return for their investment in advertising.

As a result, advertising was under scrutiny. Companies wanted better strategies, targeting, creativity, and media placement. They wanted the best people working hard to produce great advertising. This meant that advertising professionals had to find ways to do more with less money. The recession also made it hard to take risks, which are often needed for good advertising.

Other challenges included changes in population, the growing power of retailers, changing consumer needs, more sponsorships, stricter advertising laws, and the challenge of advertising in other countries. These issues, along with the economic situation, made it important for advertising to be more effective. Companies wanted to know which parts of their advertising worked.

Finding help to improve advertising was not easy. Companies and advertising agencies were busy dealing with these challenges and did not share their successful strategies. Conferences and seminars offered some help, but books on advertising were not very useful. They often made advertising seem more perfect than it was, which did not help those responsible for creating effective advertising.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Most people did not want to be chefs because it is a tough job. Chefs work long hours, the job is stressful, and the pay is not good. But these things did not stop me. I was not happy at university. The studies were difficult, and the social life felt closed and self-important. Being a chef seemed like the perfect way to escape from that. It offered a seriousness and honesty that I felt was missing in my college life. 

My wish to cook was not just because I was unhappy as a student. It was also about a love for beauty. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The meal was amazing. I still remember the starter. After eating, I wanted to thank the chef who made it. I felt happy and light for days. After this, I really wanted to learn the secrets of cooking. I changed my student life to prepare for a career in cooking. My history degree felt empty and distracted me from my real goal. I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making fancy meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The school's swimming teacher was a former drill sergeant. He was small, very muscular, and had tattoos on his arms. When I asked him to teach me how to dive, he told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward, pushing off with my feet. I practiced this move until the lesson was over. The next time, he had me stand up and dive off the edge. The instructor was very strict. Every time I came up from the water, he would say things like, "Don't look down, look up!" or "Keep your legs straight." The next week, I went up to the high diving board. It was very high, and I was scared. I tried to remember what I was taught, looked up, and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, I did not dive well, and my legs went everywhere. The instructor looked at me with disappointment, but I still felt very happy. I thought, "This is what it means to be 'free as a bird.'"

**The Traveller**

For people who like a comfortable bed, running water, and safety, the idea of a traveler is hard to understand but interesting. Travelers choose to take risks. They climb dangerous mountains, sail alone in small boats on big seas, and eat strange foods if they have to. They live with the unknown for months. It is easy to think of these people as strange or different, like hermits or writers. They live in a world that is not like our everyday life. We can ignore them and go back to our safe world with microwaves and phones, happy that our biggest risks are things like crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, which is why he spends a lot of time on it. He does not say he is a top sailor, but he is good at it. He sails because he likes to write about it. Sailing gives him exciting stories to write. Raban's boat has a device that tells sailors their exact location anywhere in the world. He likes this tool, but he also thinks that old ways of sailing are important. He believes that the compass changed how people connect with the sea. Before the compass, sailors had to watch the waves and feel the sea. Now, they just follow the compass, and the sea is just a space to cross. Because of autopilots, sailors do not have to steer all the time, which gives Raban time to watch the waves closely.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are closely connected. Books help us feel more at home in the world. We can relate to experiences in books written long ago or in faraway places because there are fewer types of people than there are people. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe situations we thought we were alone in feeling, or express our thoughts clearly. What we feel shy or confused about is clearly written in books, even if the book was written by someone far away or long ago. We feel thankful to these writers for reminding us of who we are. Through reading and travel, we escape the boring routine of life. Our eyes are most open during our first days in a new place, or when reading a great book. Books help us notice things we ignored before. We start to see the colors of the sky, the changes in a face, a friend's insincerity, or a hidden sadness we didn't know we had.

**Author's Note**

These travel reflections were published as articles in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I have restored some small cuts made by the editor, but added very little. I corrected a few mistakes, but only if they were important details. I could have made more changes, but that would never end. For example, in the second article about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but a year later it fell. If I changed the article to predict this, it would not be a true report from that time. Like any traveler, I was there at that moment, not knowing what would happen next, and trying to understand what had already happened. This is the real story of mass travel: the world opening up to people who only need a ticket. But I believe that travelers are not blind. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

If there were awards for tourism phrases that are overused, 'ecotourism' would win. The term started in the early 1980s, when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators realized that travelers wanted to believe their trips would not harm the environment. It quickly became a popular marketing term. Now, ecotourism includes anything from living with remote tribes for two weeks to a one-hour boat trip in Australia. Any tour with cultural interaction, natural beauty, wildlife, or a bit of adventure is called ecotourism. The original idea was to help people make informed choices, but without clear rules, many travelers are confused about what ecotourism really means.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook from my journey in Transylvania for 50 years, but found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time and write about it, but it wasn't perfect. In Transylvania, I had an easier time than I expected, staying in friendly country houses for weeks. When I stopped moving, I stopped writing because I thought there was nothing to record. I was slow to start writing again when I moved on, and sometimes only wrote short notes instead of a full story. I worried that some details might be out of order when I started writing this book, so I added some warnings. But then I realized this book is not a guidebook, so I let the story tell itself without too many worries.

**Fashion**

Fashion is often thought of as something modern, linked to the 1800s and 1900s when capitalism grew. However, many fashion historians say that fashion, in terms of style and design, has been around for a long time. They often start with the 1500s and 1600s when markets and trade began to grow. As societies became more complex, populations grew, and new ways to make different clothes and accessories were found, the meanings of what we wear also became more complex. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing or accessory means. For example, a man's suit, which seems very standard, can mean different things in different situations and to different people.

**Writer**

Newspaper stories about publishers fighting over new books give a wrong idea of what life is like for most writers. For those of us not on the best-seller lists, there are two ways to make a living. The smart ones write in the evenings and have other full-time jobs, so they have security even if their book isn't a hit. People like me, however, do various small jobs, like teaching, workshops, and writing articles like this one. I've heard about a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I've never gotten anything like that. Somehow, by juggling part-time jobs, using credit cards, and often with help from friends, the novel gets written.

**Sudden Fame**

The small places we were playing at around the country started to sell out, and extra security was needed to control the growing number of screaming girls. We had to use secret entrances to the places we played to avoid being surrounded by fans. On the few nights we weren't working, it was hard to leave the house without being chased by fans. In just a few days, we became celebrities. Our fans watched our every move, and our management and others took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, I felt a strange confidence that only shy people in similar situations might understand. In short, I was emotionally overwhelmed.

**Music - The Future Challenges**

Technology keeps changing how we live, work, and enjoy our free time. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, we had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, there were fewer live music performances and jobs for musicians. More people can now listen to music, which is important for many reasons. Music is part of big national events and personal activities. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the 21st century, but what kind of music it will be and if people will still want to learn instruments.

I believe people will still want to learn instruments. The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain, and musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can also help develop skills early on. Research in the USA shows that music can improve spatial reasoning, a part of intelligence. In Europe, group music lessons have helped with social skills and concentration in children. Playing an instrument might also help develop skills like good study habits and organization. Because of these benefits, there will be a demand for music lessons in the short term.

In the long term, music might change in two ways. First, people will listen to more types of music, mixing different styles. Second, technology will be used more to create and perform music, making it easier for people to compose music without needing technical skills. This might mean fewer live performances. More people of all ages might want to make music in their communities, reflecting their local traditions.

To prepare for this future, music teaching needs to change. More people should be able to learn different instruments throughout their lives. Music lessons and assessments will need to adapt to include more musical skills. Musicians will need to learn how to teach and inspire people of all ages, work with large groups, and have skills in communication, social interaction, and management. This is a big change from traditional music teaching. It will also require showing the public the value of music education.

Finally, we need to raise the importance of music in our lives. Music is very important, but often not appreciated enough. Everyone in the music profession should work together to change this.

**Paul Simon**

In the 1950s, rock and roll was mostly popular with young people. However, it also had a big effect on older people and the middle class. It helped create the next group of rock stars. These young people listened to rock and roll and felt it was important to their future. For Paul Simon and other young people in the US, the best way to hear this exciting new music was on Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. Freed's show was very important for many young people who wanted to become rock stars. Like John Lennon, who listened to Radio Luxembourg in Liverpool, Paul Simon loved the music from Freed's show. He was ready to move from just listening to music to making his own.

**Snow**

There was no clear path, but I thought I would be safe if I walked carefully. The wind was strong and pushed me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, and I fell through the thin layer. I climbed out, feeling scared and thinking about what I would do if the hole had been deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In one hour, I had only walked half a mile. It was clear that I needed to change my plan.

**Qualitative Research**

There are many books that try to help researchers with qualitative research. These books often talk a lot about how to collect data but not much about how to analyze it. Many people find data analysis confusing. So, we asked different social scientists who have done qualitative research to talk about how they analyze their data. The goal was to share ideas and understanding about data analysis, not to create a guidebook. This means making hidden processes more clear. Even though this sounds easy, it is not. We let our contributors share their work in different ways, like personal stories or more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**

A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting out a scene from a TV show he watched recently. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, and he didn't remember much. Many people are excited about learning through the internet and computers, but is learning from a screen really effective? One writer shared his experience with an interactive program he tried with his son. The father read the words carefully, but the son was more interested in playing with the pictures. The father thought that if his son had spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something. Television, as shown by my son and his noodles, is a medium that gives impressions and suggestions. Research shows that learning happens best in an environment where there is conversation with teachers or parents. It needs guidance. Using new technology to teach children is fine, but formal education is still very important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world's film-making had moved to Hollywood. The local people didn't like it at first because they thought these new people were ruining their area of Los Angeles. But eventually, they accepted it because Hollywood became very successful. Success in Hollywood means making a lot of money at the box office. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: a film that might make someone a star but will definitely make a lot of money. In less than a hundred years, Hollywood grew from a small village to a town as famous as New York, Rome, or Paris. Physically, it has changed a lot: a hundred years ago, you could walk through orange groves to the village store. But in some ways, it is still like a village, with a small-town feel and limited views. For people living and working there, the main topic is films: how much money they made, who is dating whom, who has been betrayed, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to leave: they work there but live somewhere else. Still, Hollywood is the place where almost everyone in show business wants to be.

**Photography**

Photography was invented in the 19th century by artists who wanted to create a lasting and accurate record of what they saw. They found a way to do this with light, lenses, shutters, and surfaces coated with light-sensitive chemicals. These images were more lasting, realistic, and detailed than what painters could create in weeks or months. This worried other artists, and after their initial excitement, art critics said photography was not real art. They believed that because photography relied on machines, it couldn't be considered a product of human creativity. Despite this, photographers knew they had discovered a new art form. They used photography to interpret the world and show their vision of nature, people, and things, just like other artists use brushes and pencils.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, when book illustrations were in black and white, it was common for every children's book to have illustrations. This also included many novels for older readers, although this became less common as time went on. Children's publishing was very active, but it was often done on a low budget, leading to a lot of average work. However, the best artists always did their best work. The black-and-white archives are a mix of ordinary and great work, making them a great place for research or browsing. The best works are likely to be shown to the public again, either through reprints of books or new publications about the artists. There are signs that interest in these works is returning, and publishers might soon see the potential for a series of classic children's book illustrations from this period, either as reprints or new editions using the original artwork.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**

Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins, which are online posts about where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just telling people, "Hey, I'm here," but you are also letting everyone know you are not at home. This made people realize that sharing too much online can be risky. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a global audience, offering dreams of wealth and fame. So, we dive into the internet, sharing personal stories and photos. But soon, we find out that the internet can be a dangerous place, and we can get lost in it.

This might sound sad, but don't worry. There is a way to navigate this future, thanks to a group of early internet users. In the early days of the web, they explored these challenges. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with the problems of being famous, all before social media existed. These early users, known as bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. We should learn from their experiences to avoid making the same mistakes.

In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the "WWW," which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was created at CERN in Switzerland to help researchers share their work. But Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people were interested in his bold use of this new medium. Hall shared everything, and nothing was off-limits. While some might call him an exhibitionist, his work had a certain beauty that could be seen as art.

One day, visitors to Hall's site found it replaced with a video called "Dark Night." He shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He realized that sharing too much online made people not trust him. He stopped blogging, but the problem of sharing too much online remains. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you more, you might be disappointed.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to the company's vice presidents, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. Experts call this the "online distribution effect," where people feel they can say things online they wouldn't say in person. But our online and real lives are connected, and ignoring this can lead to big mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. Although she was upset and stopped blogging for a while, she got married and started blogging again about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her writing supports her family. She learned that while the web lets us say anything, it doesn't mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and rich countries, people often can't sleep well and feel anxious. In the USA, research shows that 40 million people have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books have characters who can't sleep or are set in sleep research labs. People are interested in sleep, how it works, and why they have trouble sleeping. A main concern is that people need more sleep. A sleep expert says, "People sleep less when they are busy. They wake up early to avoid traffic."

A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to settle at about eight hours of sleep. This shows they needed more sleep than they were getting.

In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how airport noise affects sleep, and the dangers of driving when tired. They find volunteers through student newspapers. Volunteers are paid and asked to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner says some people worry because they put electrodes on their heads, but they can't see dreams or thoughts. The lab is more interested in physical effects.

In a dark room, there is a driving simulator. Volunteers come at 2 pm, when people naturally feel sleepy, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road on the screen seems endless, and the warm air makes them sleepy. Dr. Reyner has a video of someone trying not to fall asleep. At first, the driver is alert, but soon starts blinking and nodding off. The car goes off the road. Coffee can help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for a short time. She suggests using tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum, especially for shift workers.

We know that humans, like other animals, sleep in a daily cycle. During sleep, we go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. Dreams happen in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Scientists are sure that women sleep about 30 minutes longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they don't know why.

In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people went to bed early, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then slept again. This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. The poor enjoyed this quiet time the most. By the 17th century, with more artificial light, the rich started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer hours, changing sleep patterns for everyone except some country people.

Outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some places, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. In some tribal societies, noise and the need to watch for danger make continuous sleep impossible. It seems that people everywhere need more sleep.

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, each costing 800 dollars, while standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had on a full cowboy outfit, but I knew I wasn't a real cowboy. I looked at the Arizona mountains and realized I didn't belong there. I had flown in from Denver early in the morning and felt like I might look like a cowboy from the sky. But that feeling disappeared when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport. He was wearing a sweaty T-shirt, needed a shave, and was picking up a dirty bag. He looked at my new boots, raised an eyebrow, and walked away.

I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. I was addicted to driving fast cars, but I don't do it anymore. I can't even if I wanted to. I wondered what I should do now. I thought I had other plans for when I stopped racing, but they didn't work out. I tried to become a commentator for races, but there were already many former drivers doing that. I also tried to start a business selling classic cars, but it didn't work because nobody was buying them.

Being an "ex" anything is hard. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a World Champion. Even if I had been a champion, people would only listen to my story for a short time. Last year's champion is old news. I don't want sympathy because I had a good career and made money. But I miss driving those powerful cars and the excitement of racing. I miss the attention from reporters and fans. Now that I don't race, my phone hardly rings, and I have a lot of free time.

I looked at the sky and saw no buzzards, just some small birds in a cactus. They seemed to be telling me to leave their nest alone. I realized I had a lot to learn about life outside of racing.

**Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people like to walk down the city streets. If you walk with them, you will probably hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver because it has a mild climate, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, a clean and safe environment, and good schools and jobs. Some people complain about the many new buildings, but the new people and tourists have helped the city grow. Vancouver used to be called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Even though people don't use this name much anymore, Vancouver is still a gateway city.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists like me are usually not good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because we try hard to make our writing have a big impact, so we lose the natural feeling of a letter. Real artists, who don't think about the effect of their words (even if they rewrite a lot), don't have this problem. I think a real artist knows how their words will affect people. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about the big words he used, but they showed he was a great writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap opera star, a radio DJ, or a minor royal would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that they don't need famous people anymore. Why pay a celebrity when anyone can open it for free? Last week, people waiting to enter a new Superbuy store didn't care who opened it, as long as they were first in line. One customer heard that the first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel happy and those who came later feel jealous.

**Citizen Kane**

When the film *Citizen Kane* came out in 1941, there was a lot of excitement and controversy. Its release was delayed because the distributors were afraid of what William Randolph Hearst, who the film was supposedly about, might do to them. Even though the reviews were mostly very positive, the film did not make much money at first. It was television that made the film popular again. *Citizen Kane* is perhaps the most inspiring film for people who want to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said that the film was successful because he didn't know what he was or wasn't allowed to do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. When Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a film about a newspaper owner who was similar to Hearst, Welles knew he had found the perfect project for himself as both director and actor. He took the opportunity with great energy.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He told her twice that he might be late and not to worry if he stopped by the golf club on his way home. He needed to talk to someone, and the golf club was the best place for it. Carmel nodded her head both times, but it seemed like she wasn't really listening or understanding. "Will you be okay? What are you going to do today?" he asked. She smiled and said, "Funny you should ask that. I was just thinking I have nothing to do all day, so I might walk downtown and look at the shops. It feels almost wrong to just spend the day doing nothing." Dermot smiled back and said, "You deserve to enjoy yourself. And like I said, if I'm late, I won't need anything to eat. So don't worry about making dinner." "No, that's fine," she replied.

**Title Race**

Human nature can be very funny. A recent study showed that job titles can cause jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a top recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that job titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey found that 70% of office workers would rather have a better job title than a pay raise. If our desire for fancy titles is stronger than our desire for more money, we are in a difficult situation. Today, in the early twenty-first century, nobody wants to be seen as less important. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to say the same thing.

I was in Vienna to take photos. Taking photos was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light looked on different surfaces and how one photo could show the true feeling of a place or person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo, so I kept my camera ready. Once, I took a photo of smoke from a burning oil well that became very popular. It was just luck, but it made me famous for a short time. After that, I decided to work for myself, but things didn't go as planned. The mid-1990s were not as successful as I had hoped, even though my photo was on the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which was good enough for me.

I got the Vienna job by chance. I had taken photos in London for a book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which also included Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, left the job in Vienna, so they asked me to take his place. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the other photographers. I was happy to go because things at home were not going well. A week in snowy Vienna sounded great to me.

They put me up at a hotel in the center of the city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy summer trip, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in cold January, I knew it would be different. As soon as I arrived, I felt excited to take great pictures. On the first day, I just rode the trams around the city to get a feel for the place. The weather was cold and the city was beautiful. I wanted to make this Vienna my own, not like the other photographer's work. I waited for the right moments to take photos.

The next morning, I went out early. The snow had made the city look fresh and empty. I wanted to take a photo of the cathedral, but it was hard to capture it all in one shot. Its tall spire and large base made it difficult, but I knew it could still be magical. Photography has always seemed magical to me. Even when you understand how it works, it still feels mysterious. That's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't really surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**

Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It has changed from a serious place to one full of wonder. This change is not because of a big, expensive show, but because of a unique exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that involves movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art over the last 60 years. It shows that making art that moves or explores movement has been an important, but often unnoticed, part of art in the 20th century. The exhibition includes paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. Curator Guy Brett, who has studied this art for a long time, has put it together. There are not many explanations, so visitors can enjoy discovering things on their own.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art is liked by many people, even those who usually do not care about art. People might like his work because it is easy to understand or because it shows fun and relaxing subjects. Some people might be interested in Hockney himself because he is funny and interesting. Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. They say he is popular for the wrong reasons. But others argue that he might seem less important because it is unusual for popular artists to be taken seriously. Hockney knows his limits and does not claim to be a great artist. He believes only time will tell how important his work is.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**

Recently, I have seen many contemporary art exhibitions. Some are great, and some are not. What bothers me are shows that try to push a certain idea or trend. Sometimes this works, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to do something different. I worked with seven artists to create an exhibition in an empty warehouse. We called it 'Window-shopping.' The artworks were connected only because they were all art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats played on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera art flickered on a screen. These works did not fit into a specific theme, but they worked well together. I did not try to make a big statement about contemporary art. Art is personal, and artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who love paintings sometimes do not want to analyze them because they think it will ruin their enjoyment. Some say that art historians focus too much on theory and forget the pleasure of looking at art. This is like saying that knowing how a dish is made takes away from its taste. Enjoying art does not mean we cannot learn more about it. In fact, knowing more can make it more enjoyable. Our enjoyment of art is not just about our personal taste; it is also influenced by society. While it is important to enjoy art instinctively, thinking about it does not take away from that enjoyment. This idea comes from a time when art was seen as separate from thought.

**Metals**

Stone Age people might have started to like metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow stone. It was not like other stones; it was special and beautiful. This is how gold might have become important to early people. Gold is soft and easy to shape, so it quickly became popular. Copper might have been found by accident too. Once people saw how useful copper tools were, they worked hard to find copper and learn how to get it from rocks. This is how metalworking became an important skill for our ancestors.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is hard because it is gone. The people who lived in good times and bad times are no longer here. The reasons they moved or stayed, and how they formed families and villages, are forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we cannot test our ideas with real experiments on past cultures. We cannot watch the past like a movie. But maybe we can. Computer modelling lets us create old landscapes and fill them with virtual people. These digital people have some needs and abilities like real humans. We can set rules for them and change things like rain or population to see how these virtual communities react.

**Vervet Monkeys**

Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys and saw something interesting. One day, the leader male monkey noticed a new male monkey in a nearby group of trees. This new monkey wanted to join the group. If he joined, the leader might lose his position. To stop this, the leader monkey had a clever idea. Every time the new monkey tried to come closer, the leader gave an alarm call that meant a leopard was near. This scared the new monkey back into the trees. This trick worked well until the leader made a mistake. He gave the alarm call while he was calmly walking in the open, showing there was no real danger.

**What Cats Catch**

In the English village of Felmersham, people collected what their cats caught. Over a year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor saw this and thought that all the cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small animals each year. But this number is not realistic. Most cats live in towns and catch fewer animals. The important question is whether these numbers are too high. The answer seems to be no. Many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide places for birds to nest. So, the bird population stays high. The survey showed that cats are important hunters, but they are not destroying Britain's bird population.

**PICASSO, Pablo**

In 1940, Picasso painted things around him. In the fishing port of Royan, he painted fish still lifes. The painting shows a fishmonger's table with a crab and some fish. The fish look alive, even though they are not. Picasso used a flat pattern with overlapping shapes. The colors and brushwork make the painting look calm, like an underwater scene.
