Sometimes, it feels as cold as the Arctic inside. This is an example of how people often use too much air-conditioning. Air-conditioning is now a big part of our lives, showing how we can change the climate around us. But many buildings could stay cool in other ways. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and release it at night. These ideas might seem simple, but they can really help and would mean we need less air-conditioning.

**Sundials**

It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, people are interested in sundials again. Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. But as clocks and watches got better, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are interested in them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts working. Sundials are calm and romantic, reminding us of our place in the universe.

**Paint Your Own China**

I used to think china-painting was only for very skilled people. I once saw older women at an arts show painting teacups with perfect flowers. They were so good that it seemed like they had been doing it for many years or were born with a special talent. I wondered who would be brave enough to take a china-painting class. Would beginners be naturally good at it? But when I visited a class, it was not scary at all. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint flowers on teacups as quickly as I remembered.

Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price. It included a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to book the trip, the travel agent told them that the other people in their group were students learning Italian. But something went wrong. Either at the travel agency, the check-in desk, or in a computer, a mistake happened. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland.

At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they were surprised to hear people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe there was a cancellation or the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.

When they arrived, a woman with glasses told everyone to stay together. There was no mention of an overnight stop in the brochure, but Keith thought it was part of the plan. It was almost midnight when they reached the hotel, and they were too tired to ask questions. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist told them about the lake and the steamer to Interlaken.

Keith calmly told the receptionist there was a mistake because they were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist didn't know about any mistake. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip, hoping it would help. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, came over. Dawne explained they were in the wrong hotel. Mrs. Franks said there are many holidays with similar tickets and labels, and sometimes people follow the wrong group.

Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks said she would check and left them standing there. The receptionist was gone, and they heard typing. Dawne thought Mrs. Franks seemed kind, but Keith was lost in thought, trying to remember everything that happened.

An elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Nottage, talked to them. They said they had a great night's sleep because of the lakeside air. Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They didn't mention the irony of ending up on a holiday with elderly people when they wanted to escape from the demands of the elderly. Uncle had even said that was the point of the holiday.

**He Was a People Person**

American business leaders are looking up to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a great example of good leadership. Eluned Price reports.

In Britain, many people know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a general idea of his achievements. However, in America, he is only now becoming well-known. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which might be an exaggeration. But now, Americans are very interested in him. Books about Shackleton and his famous ship, the Endurance, are being written and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about his life.

Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They admire his actions and learn lessons about leadership and communication from his story. They even use the term "speaking Shackleton" to describe using his methods. Shackleton, with his clever use of resources like a reindeer sleeping bag and a blubber-stove, is now seen as a model for modern management.

Jim MacGregor, a manager at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has been inspired by Shackleton for years. His company deals with communication during business mergers, acquisitions, and crises. For example, if a company's factory explodes or if many employees need to be let go. MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great example of leadership because he was a strong leader and communicator. He made tough decisions, like turning back from the South Pole in 1908 when he was only 97 miles away, to save his men's lives.

In a crisis, people want to know someone is in charge. Today, managers often avoid responsibility, but Shackleton was different. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was trapped in ice for nine months and eventually crushed. Shackleton told his men they would survive if they trusted him and did their best. He always stayed in control and kept his men informed.

Shackleton believed an explorer needed optimism, physical endurance, and patience. MacGregor says that in difficult situations, sometimes doing nothing is the hardest thing, especially in America, where people want quick solutions. If you make a wrong decision, like buying bonds at the wrong time, you should wait instead of selling at a loss. Also, don't be afraid to change plans if they aren't working.

Shackleton led by example. On the journey back from the Endurance, he noticed the expedition photographer, Hurley, without gloves. He gave Hurley his own gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if Hurley didn't wear them. Someone else remembered Shackleton giving away a biscuit when they were starving, saying he would leave it in the snow if they didn't take it.

Caroline Alexander, author of "Endurance," says that people today are looking for real heroes. Shackleton shows us that true heroism is rare now. He stands out as a genuine example of the ideals we miss today.

In the forests of Madagascar, there is a primate called the aye-aye that lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insect larvae inside wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its sharp teeth to make holes and its long, thin third finger to reach and scoop out the insects.

Scientists have known about the aye-aye's feeding habits for over a hundred years, but they recently discovered how it finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied the hunting skills of some aye-ayes named Nosferatu, Poe, Samantha, and her baby Annabelle. He wanted to see if they found insects by looking for signs on the wood, like holes where insects might have entered. He gave them logs with drilled holes, some with mealworms inside and some empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the holes with food, without needing to see any signs on the surface.

Dr. Erickson tested if the aye-ayes used smell or sound to find the insects, but they didn't. They could find mealworms even when the smell was blocked and when the mealworms were dead and silent. So, how did they find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes could sense empty spaces inside the wood. They tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their big ears. Dr. Erickson thinks they use echo-location, like bats, to hear the sound of the taps and find hollow spaces. They might also hear insects moving when disturbed by the tapping.

The idea that the aye-aye acts like a woodpecker in Madagascar is interesting, but there are also birds there that look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is unique because it is like a woodpecker, an echo-locating bat, and even a squirrel. Its teeth grow continuously like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild breaking open nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat.

Title: Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives

Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we really know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries and family stories often don't give us the full picture. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down but never do. We might leave videos instead of photos, but they still don't tell the whole story.

Hannah Renier has a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. These are books of at least 20,000 words, sometimes with pictures, about ordinary people, not celebrities. She got the idea when she realized that much of her family's past was being forgotten. "At first, I didn't take it very seriously," she says. "But then I met people with interesting lives who wanted to share their stories. They do it for their children or future generations, but they also enjoy the process."

Hannah's clients feel safe to be honest because she keeps their stories private. One man, 62 years old, shared his life story, including painful parts like his divorce. He did it for his family, hoping they might learn something. However, he hasn't let his children read it yet because some details might hurt them. He thinks they should read it after he is gone.

Hannah has noticed that many people repeat patterns from their childhood. They often marry people their parents would like or do the opposite to rebel. Many still feel disappointed about things that happened with their parents, even 60 years later. They try to impress a parent who was never impressed, and some want to say, "I can't stand my mother."

Hannah listens to people's stories without judging. She lets them decide what to include in their book. People usually want to be honest, even about the bad parts. It's not about showing off an interesting life; it's about keeping a connection to the past. We are losing touch with our history, and these books help us remember.

Each book takes about 30 hours of recorded interviews. Hannah uses these to write the life story, organizing and interpreting the events. Modern technology helps her create the book, except for the cover with gold lettering. The book is meant for a private audience and is not a cheap product. It costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. Hannah gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the price stops many people. She thought it would be more affordable, but her clients are often wealthy people who might have had their portraits painted in the past.

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**

The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of Greek and Roman sculpture copies in the world, with over six hundred pieces. Remember, nothing here is real. All the sculptures are exact copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with great natural light. The good thing about plaster casts is that sculptures originally shown together but now in different museums across Europe can be seen together again. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.

**B. Cambridge Darkroom**

Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography with community darkrooms and a gallery showing different photography exhibitions. We often have courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a Beginner's Course, a short Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that lets members use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) improve their skills with our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books, magazines, and materials.

**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**

The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world and from all geological ages. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, made by Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). It includes nearly 10,000 rare and interesting items kept in their original early 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick, a Professor of Geology, added a lot to the collections, making the museum truly special. The collection is organized by geological age, so you can see the major changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery shows the beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern use.

**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**

There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos all over Great Britain. The photos are interesting as they show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but you can buy copies, which usually take about a month to make.

**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**

The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running centre of its kind in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction where you can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The centre makes resin copies, called facsimiles, to protect the originals while allowing people to enjoy brass rubbing. Brass plates were used as memorials instead of statues and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many were destroyed during revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and the Cambridge Centre has a wide range of examples.

**From Here to Fatherhood**

**A. The Theatre Director**

I have had 35 years of being around small children because of my unusual personal life. I have loved every moment of it. This morning, I fed the baby, and for me, that is what being a father is all about. I am very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This creates a strong bond, especially now that they are mostly grown up, and I am more of a friend than a father. I don't believe in hitting children. I have slapped my children in anger before, but I don't support it. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I am here if they need me, but I let them call me. If you start asking them why they haven't called, you make them feel guilty. My parents did that to me, and I would never do it to my children.

**B. The Advertising Executive**

I was young when my children were born, only about 25, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I value. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and clothes. This has been very helpful for my work at the agency. I have never felt out of touch. When they were young, I was busy building my business, so I missed some things like their first concerts and sports days. I feel sad about that, but now I can take them on holidays to the south of France. They get along well with our friends and come to parties and advertising award ceremonies with us without feeling shy. I think it helps that I have a job they find glamorous and interesting.

**C. The Politician**

My first child was born just as I was about to be elected to the Greater London Council, and the others came soon after. My wife and I promised to make time for them, but as I became more involved in politics, time became a problem. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if there are facilities for my kids to come with me. This way, they know what I do when I am not with them, and they don't feel like I am disappearing. I've noticed more MPs bringing their kids to the House. Maybe we are all realizing the importance of involving our children in our lives.

**D. The Writer**

My first marriage ended when Kate and Bonnie were young, so I had to think a lot about being a father. I tried hard to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even lived next door to each other for a while, so the kids could come and go as they wanted, but I think they found it confusing. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a very good father. I was around a lot, but like many parents in the Seventies, I treated the kids as adults too soon. Kate recently said we were too liberal. I think I could have been more organized. I regret that now. I still worry about my older daughters as much as my youngest. In that way, your kids never leave you.

**E. The TV Presenter**

I was ready for kids. I was 30, met my wife, and we had a nice house. We thought, "Why keep spending money on new sofas when we could have a child instead?" Having my daughter Betty made me understand who I am. You feel special when you have a child, and you are, but you also become just another parent. It's a great equalizer. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at her makes it go away. A baby's smile is the best way to make a grown man melt.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**

A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
This is a play by Marlowe about a powerful warrior. It is very long, but in Terry Hands' version, it becomes exciting and fast. Antony Sher plays the main role and does amazing stunts, like jumping from a balcony and sliding down a rope. He keeps the audience's full attention with his intense performance.  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by Michael Wall, who sadly died young, is now in London after being in Manchester. The first part is about two married couples talking in a garden, creating a tense feeling. The second part shows the impact of illness with deep emotion.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*

C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche, an Irish playwright, tells a story about the decline of the fishing industry in Wexford. The play has strong characters, deep emotions, and funny moments. It can feel a bit slow but ends with a powerful finish.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a classic thriller about 'the perfect murder'. Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play writers who want to kill each other. The story is familiar but has clever twists.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*

E. **The Alchemist**  
Director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about tricksters from the 17th century. The show was first in Stratford and now is in London, with great performances by Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*

F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James directs this comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society. It was successful in Edinburgh and is now in London. The play is stylish and well-acted.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*

G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn is a sweet version of Beauty and the Beast set in London. It has beautiful music by John Pattison and celebrates romantic love. It's a feel-good show.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*

H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's version of Shakespeare's comedy is not very good, but it has great comic performances by Ron Cook and Anton Lesser. Most of the other actors seem uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*

I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another play by Granville Barker, now touring. It tells the story of a lawyer who leaves a dishonest financial situation to his son. It's a great play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek** by Yvonne Coppard  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game by watching a suspicious bookshop. She is surprised to see her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime, using her love for him to turn her against her friends. The story becomes intense when Emma's life is in danger, and she is trapped in the basement of an old house. This book shows the details of family life, the strength of childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always the protectors they should be. It's an important and believable story.

**Backtrack** by Peter Hunt  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together to find out what happened in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. Their relatives were involved in the accident. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and first-hand accounts to help the reader understand the mystery. It's a smart and complex story that needs careful reading.

**Pigeon Summer** by Ann Turnbull  
Mary Dyer doesn't fit well into her family or her male-dominated culture. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves to find work, she takes care of them and wins prizes. This story is set in 1930 and has a strong message that there are different kinds of intelligence. Thoughtful readers will enjoy this story.

**Yaxley's Cat** by Robert Westall  
This is a chilling story about rural prejudice and persecution. Rose, a mature woman, rents Sepp Yaxley's cottage to escape her materialistic life. She finds a fierce cat and strange items in the house, which reveal why Yaxley disappeared. The local people become hostile, and Rose's family is in danger. The story is gripping, and Rose is shocked by her teenage son's actions.

**Someone's Mother is Missing** by Harry Mazer  
Sam is from the poorer side of the family and is impressed by his rich cousin, Lisa. When Lisa's world falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the value of family. The story is a bit slow in parts but has gentle humor and shows the growing closeness between the two teenagers. It is interesting for both boys and girls.

**Stanley's Aquarium** by Barry Faville  
Robbie takes a job gardening for Stanley, an elderly man. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is repelled by him. When she discovers what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans, the story becomes a thriller. The book is set in New Zealand and is unusual and compelling.

**Dodger** by Libby Gleeson  
This is a sad story about Mick, who has troubled personal relationships and a difficult school life. The story is told through flashbacks, a teacher's letters, Mick's notes, and a sympathetic narrative. Mick improves his self-worth through a role in a school play and with the help of a sensitive teacher. The story is highly recommended, even though it is painful to read, especially at the end.

**Science Defying Gravity**

Journalist Tom Mumford joined students testing their ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, the aircraft looked normal. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135 refueling tanker, built in 1964, similar to a Boeing 707 passenger plane. But inside, it was different. The plane had a long white tunnel with almost no windows, lit by lights along the padded walls. Most seats were removed, except a few at the back where the nervous students sat. 

For a year, these 13 students from Europe and America competed to be on this flight. The European Space Agency challenged them to suggest creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, which was like an extreme roller-coaster ride. 

For two hours, the plane flew like a giant bird, going up and then diving down. At the top of each curve, the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters. The plane continued to rise due to its momentum before gravity pulled it back down. During the few seconds between going up and falling, everything inside became weightless. The students felt like they were closer to the moon than to Earth.

The plane took off smoothly, but soon the pilot made it climb at a 45-degree angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, blood rushed from our heads, and we were thrown across the cabin floor. Then the engines stopped, and we were weightless almost immediately. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. The floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We floated without direction; up, down, left, or right no longer made sense.

After ten seconds of freefall, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned suddenly, and some students landed with a bump. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves gave ten minutes of 'space time' for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They used a device to turn it belly-down with radio controls. 

Nearby, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joins are affected by no gravity, thinking about future space stations. Another team from Utah State University tried to create solar sails from thin liquid films using ultraviolet light. They hoped these sails could use the sun's radiation like a yacht uses the wind.

After two hours of flying between the sky and Earth, breakfast felt uneasy, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. "It was an unforgettable experience," said one student. "I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Made My Connection to New Zealand**

**Jonathon Porritt Talks to Danny Danziger**

Jonathon Porritt is the author of "Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology."

I had a strange time in my life when I didn't experience any summers. I traveled to New Zealand every summer from my home, which is winter in New Zealand. So, I had nine winters in a row. I enjoyed it because I like winter. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which was nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was okay for planting trees.

I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs. So, the idea of planting trees sounded nice, and I was excited. The rest of my family became enthusiastic as we continued. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, we had planted the whole 70 acres.

In New Zealand in 1968, it rained a lot during the winter. It was a very happy time, even though it rained almost every day we were planting. I don't think I've ever been wetter or colder for such a long time. Every morning, I had to prepare for planting again. I would get out of the Land Rover, feeling warm and dry, but the rain would start, and my clothes were still wet from the day before. My boots were soaked, and my hands struggled with slippery laces. During this time, I had many thoughts and ideas about life.

In the first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which was helpful because I had never planted trees seriously before. You carry a planting bag around your neck, filled with as many trees as possible. When the bag is full, it's difficult, but it gets easier as it becomes lighter. The hardest part was making sure the lines were straight. You decide how far apart to plant the trees, then line up three poles to guide you. Once in line, you plant all the way down, turn around, and come back.

I enjoy hard physical work, and it made me fit. After a while, you can plant trees almost automatically. You get used to a rhythm and use the fewest spade strokes needed to dig a hole. This rhythm is common in many farming jobs. You train your body to do the same moves, and it becomes easy. You take the tree out of the bag, dig a hole, plant it, stamp it in, and move on.

Mentally, it was interesting. My thoughts about the natural world and our place in it started during this time. I've returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which is satisfying. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I worry when I read about bad weather in New Zealand, like strong winds or droughts. But the trees are now 20 years old and doing well.

In 1984, I took a break from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, "Seeing Green," there. I stayed in a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, table, and chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees, and in the evenings, I did research. The connection between me and that area is still very strong. It's the place where I feel most connected to the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

"What now?" I thought when one of my helpers handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I turned our dairy farm in Somerset into an "open farm" six years ago, and we are known for taking care of orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange, like a mix between a laugh and a bark. Curious, I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky-colored eyes on their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground. If they lose their mother, they usually die of hunger and are never found. These three were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. The mother was dead, and the babies were still trying to feed from her. They were healthy but cold and crying. After removing their fleas, I took them into the warm kitchen and placed them by the stove. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth to mimic their mother licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they were fed every four hours. Within a week, they were drinking from a bottle and moving around, though unsteadily. They seemed happy with each other and a heated pad as a substitute for their mother.

Three weeks later, I noticed Willow was not as active, though he was eating normally. It was a warning sign. I didn't act quickly enough, and the next morning, I found him dead. The vet said Willow died from a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, as liquid can go into the lungs. This caused an infection in Willow that was hard to treat, even with antibiotics. I was sad about losing Willow but continued caring for the others. Then, a local farmer brought me another male cub, also abandoned. He was cold and hungry, so we named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females and very hard to feed. I had to move the bottle's teat around in his mouth to get him to drink. After a while, he would finally latch on. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and other foods, but Willow II struggled. He would walk through his food or sit in it. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly ate. After a week of sausages, he was ready for other foods. At nearly five months old, they all ate cereals for breakfast, a meat and vegetable meal for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, baby rabbits, mice, voles, and plant shoots or roots. My badgers were lucky because the summer was very hot, making it hard to find earthworms.

By August, the cubs became more active at night and would only go for walks at dusk or late at night. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they played and chased each other. As "human badgers," we joined in their games. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek, who joined us less often, did not. His reactions to being bitten were sometimes as colorful as his bruises. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely looking for food, as badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive to outsiders. We were warned they might enter our badger pen and harm the cubs, so we made the gate more secure. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help. We started a project to build a home for the badgers on the farm. With advice and help, we designed a new home for them. Our son Daniel made the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels, an enclosure, and a badger gate. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side for people to see inside. As the sett was built, the badgers explored it before their walks. Eventually, they stopped going for walks and enjoyed their new home. The building cost more than expected, but a local bus company, Badgerline, sponsored part of it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Later, I checked on them and saw three badgers sleeping soundly in their chambers. Now, I don't walk with them as often, especially since they wake up at midnight. We see Primrose occasionally, as she joined a neighboring sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still greet us before heading off into the night. This is their territory now, a place they know well and a home they have accepted.

Text: 'In search of true north - and the man behind Halley's comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to map compass changes. Anjana Ahuja reports. Astronomer Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his important achievements was mapping 'compass variations' during his sea trips on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors couldn't correct their compasses, making it hard to find their exact position at sea. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to map declination in the North and South Atlantic. The first trip ended early due to crew problems, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, past South Georgia, up to Newfoundland, and back to England. From these travels, Halley published a 'New and Correct Chart showing the Variations of the Compass in the Western and Southern Oceans' in 1701. This chart was very useful to sailors for over a century until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate. Dr. Clark, who also loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the Paramore's route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first cross-Antarctica expedition, is supporting him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley during a two-year stay at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about the scientist. 'Halley led a remarkable life,' Dr. Clark says. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He wasn't just an astronomer; he also did research in geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped stars and found time for other interests.' During this time, Halley developed a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his book Principia Mathematica, the foundation of classical physics. Dr. Clark believes recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. It will involve taking the same measurements Halley did, but with more accurate tools. These measurements need updating because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the current model of Earth's magnetic field, known as the international geomagnetic reference field. 'It's common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. You need to know true north to measure the direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our expedition, we can use global positioning satellites to find that.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements around the world. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean, and he notes that ground-based measurements are useful for comparison. It's easy to forget how important Halley's Atlantic journey was. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian made a naval captain to study declination. Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to make his journey a success? Besides spending two years in Antarctica and working in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, he has already sailed 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with four different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I'm ready to give up my life for eight months to do this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his fascinating life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

**POWER DRESSING**

Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peahens. This display puzzled Charles Darwin because, in a world where survival is tough, it seemed strange that birds would have such extravagant tails. Darwin believed that animals evolved through natural selection, meaning the strongest and smartest survive. However, the peacock's tail seemed to be a disadvantage, so Darwin suggested another idea called 'sexual selection.' He thought females chose mates based on beauty.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, disagreed. He believed that if peahens chose the most beautiful males, there must be a good reason. Maybe these males had other qualities that helped them survive, even if humans couldn't see them.

Today, scientists like Marion Petrie from the Open University are studying peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if peahens really prefer males with the most impressive tails and if these males have other advantages. Observations show that peahens do like males with more eye-spots on their tails, which means longer tails. But it's still unclear if these males are better in other ways.

William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and have fewer parasites. This could be true for other birds, but it hasn't been tested in Whipsnade peacocks yet. This year, Dr. Petrie is comparing the offspring of attractive and unattractive males to see if the attractive ones have healthier or faster-growing children.

There's another idea from R.A. Fisher, a mathematician and biologist. He proposed 'Fisher's Runaway,' which suggests that if females prefer males with slightly better tails, their children will inherit these traits. Over time, this preference could lead to males with very long tails, supporting Darwin's idea of 'beauty for beauty's sake.'

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with new technology. Most of these boats are based on designs from 25 years ago. My boat, however, is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some might think I am a romantic dreamer, but I don't think so. My boat uses old boat design magic, but modern technology made it easier to build. 

Modern technology is important in boat design and building, but it often makes sailing too easy. Many people go to sea to experience the challenges of sailing. I don't think sailors should suffer, but I like my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable beds. If everything on a boat is automatic, like the sails, it takes away from the experience. Sometimes, dealing with the sails is part of being a sailor. 

Some boats have steering positions in the middle, which makes the cabin bigger, like a hotel room. But I believe a boat should feel like a boat, not a house. When I bought my old boat, Hirta, I sailed around Britain for a TV race. The previous owner said it had comfort but no luxury. Hirta had heavy sails, no pumped water, no electricity, no fridge, no central heating, no winches, and no electronics. Yet, she was the nicest boat I ever sailed. 

Old boats need a lot of care. After I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one. The Westerman has been great. Nigel Irens, the designer, first drew the boat on a napkin, then used a computer. He also made a model, like in the old days. We made changes until the design was perfect. 

The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of six races. She looks timeless, sails smoothly, and feels peaceful inside. This is because she was designed as a sailing boat first, not for furniture. She shows that you don't need to follow trends to be happy. Built with treated wood, she is waterproof like a fiberglass boat but looks and feels like a traditional one.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the large 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like body conditioning, stretch and tone, yoga, and body alignment. The instructors are very skilled. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments, such as aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The one-hour facial made me feel like a new person. The staff were very friendly and professional. The atmosphere is full of energy and enthusiasm. Henlow is planning to add a half-size Olympic swimming pool and a Light Diet Room this year. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you prefer to relax, you can read a magazine or walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling great and full of energy. I definitely want to visit again. This is a perfect break for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

The calm and relaxing atmosphere of this grand home was clear from the moment I walked up the large staircase to the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and lots of space, so you don't have to talk to anyone if you don't want to. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up, including weight and blood pressure. We were called patients, which felt strange since I am healthy. But I was impressed when a shoulder problem found during the check-up was quickly shared with the fitness instructor. We worked on it in group workshops and an extra individual session. Each person gets a specific diet to follow. I lost weight without fasting, but I was hungry enough to get a headache on the second day. My typical daily menu was grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and exotic fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for supper. If you're not fasting, you eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty and nicely presented. You have a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are reasonably priced. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys is not a health farm and doesn't claim to be. It's a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a big lounge. If you're watching your calories, you might skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delicious creamy desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool to help burn off the extra calories. (You can choose a 'health-conscious' diet if you want to lose weight.) There is a spa bath, steam room, Swiss shower, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got expert advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, relaxed and calm. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful woodland walks and gardens on the 376-acre National Trust estate. Waldo's, a famous restaurant, has dishes that are amazing. The dinner menu has many choices. The meal was wonderful, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed happy! The next morning, I spent a few hours in the gym to burn off some calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial with gentle heat and essential oils, followed by an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden offers fitness assessments, workouts, and beauty treatments if you want them before enjoying a meal at Waldo's. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It's the best because it's delicious, but the worst because it's 360 calories, which is not good if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep twice during the massage. I returned to my room and had the best night's sleep in years. The place is modern, well-run, with up-to-date facilities and luxurious bedrooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it's easy to schedule appointments. They offer many treatments, from manicures and pedicures to deep-cleansing facials and body treatments. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to mothers and daughters, best friends, and singles. I would love to visit here once a month. - Eve Cameron

**NATURAL TALENTS**

In the last seven million years, since humans split from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much. Genetically, we are still more than 98% the same as chimps. On a big evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is a recent change. Our ability to make art and do other things we think are uniquely human must come from a small part of our genes. This is a lot to expect from just a few genes. 

It's not surprising that studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are not. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have a simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences between us and animals, except for art.

If human art comes from a special genetic gift, it's strange that our ancestors didn't make art for most of the 7 million years since they split from chimps. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we can't know because these materials don't last. Clear evidence of human art, like cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments, only appears around 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons.

If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from similar animal works? Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not inherited.

First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means human art doesn't help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike most animal behaviors. Human art can communicate thoughts or feelings, but that's not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, for example, helps defend territory or attract mates, which helps pass on genes. By this measure, human art is different.

The second claim is that only human art is made for beauty. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during breeding season, so they probably don't sing just for beauty. Again, human art seems unique.

The third difference is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds, however, are born knowing their species' song. A French baby raised in Japan wouldn't suddenly sing the French national anthem. Human art changes quickly, unlike animal behaviors. 

For example, geese honked 2,000 years ago and still do today, but human art changes so fast that even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often identify when and who painted a work. However, they might mistake the works of two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Their paintings were shown in a 1957 exhibition in London, and most were sold, which many human artists can't claim.

These paintings by chimps blur the lines between human art and animal activities. Like human art, the ape paintings weren't made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. You might say human art is different because it's meant to communicate, but even some famous human art was made for the artist's personal satisfaction.

Title: A Big Adventure

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. 

There are not many big adventures left, and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories often had brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance on their journeys into the unknown. Today, you don't find such people in stories or real life. At least, that's what I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore's big adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. The name of the desert means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home. His team included four Britons (one was the medical officer), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were actually long-distance truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous and could have ruined the expedition.

This group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's toughest desert. Charles Blackmore wrote an amazing story about their journey. At the time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to prove something to himself. 'I always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to find out who Charles Blackmore really was, outside of the Army. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn't come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us.'

Anyone reading his story will wonder why he used the word 'kind'. The team faced many hardships: dysentery, extreme temperatures, severe thirst and dehydration, and losing part of their water supply. 'But', Blackmore explains, 'when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn't experience the Taklamakan's famous sandstorms. And we never faced the freezing desert cold that could have stopped us completely. That's not to say we weren't facing challenges all the time. The fine sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were very hard to climb, for us and the camels, which often fell over onto us.'

'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn't allow for one. No aircraft flew over us. Once we were in the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was very scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" At that moment, I was very scared.'

If it was like that at the beginning, how did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked for 1,000 kilometers, you're not going to give up. You've gone through so much; you've come so far. We were very thin, but very strong despite being exhausted. My body was in good shape, and my legs were like machines. I could walk over anything.'

In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert looking up at a full moon, thinking of his family. How aware was he of the difficulty it must have been for them? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace with himself. When I doubt myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to do it. As a personal achievement, I feel prouder of that expedition than anything else I've done. But in terms of a lifetime's achievement, I think of my family and the happiness we share -- compared to that, the desert doesn't measure up.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I long for the challenge -- for the open spaces -- the purpose of it all. We were lifted by the sense of purpose. I find it hard now to be part of the sameness of modern life.'

Susan Harr felt overwhelmed by technology, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. However, Susan realized that technology can be expensive and not always worth the trouble. She started to let go of household gadgets as they stopped working. This made her question if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets.

When her word processor broke, she left it in the backyard. She found freedom in not being tied to noisy machines and enjoyed taking her time with tasks like sewing. She discovered that some gadgets, like the washing machine, are very useful, but others, like the TV, can be replaced with simpler versions. Without a color TV, her family spent more time walking the dog, reading, and talking.

Susan also started sewing by hand after her sewing machine broke. She found it relaxing and satisfying to see her work improve. She realized that doing things by hand slowed down her life and freed her from the rush of modern life. She even enjoyed washing dishes by hand, which gave her time to daydream.

Now, Susan looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like the freezer, microwave, or electric lights. She thinks they could save a lot of money by living with fewer gadgets.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who creates beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt visits him at his workshop in East London. When she arrives, Hurst seems to be in a hurry. He quickly shakes her hand and says, "Well, fire away then!" It's not clear if he is naturally brusque or just shy. His workshop is busy, filled with half-made furniture and colorful wood. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He is always busy with orders, even though he doesn't advertise. People know that if they want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen unit, Hurst is the person to go to.

Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one like Hurst, who makes simple and beautiful furniture, is rare. Hurst is disappointed by some modern furniture and doesn't like mass-produced, low-quality pieces. He believes his success comes from his quest for perfection and his talent. Hurst is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability." He learned his craft by asking the right questions and teaching himself.

Most of Hurst's work comes from private clients. Some clients come back to him many times, which he finds satisfying. However, he admits that not all client relationships are easy. He finds it frustrating when clients don't know what they want until it's too late. He prefers clients who know exactly what they want.

Hurst is also willing to praise others who are better than him. He admires other craftsmen but criticizes those who take too long to make one piece or try to make fashion statements with their furniture. He believes furniture should be practical and not just for show.

Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As Joanna leaves, he humbly says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three ideas about why we sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This means sleep must be very important. But scientists still do not agree on exactly why we need to sleep so much. There are three main ideas. The first and most popular idea is that sleep is mainly for our body's health. It says we sleep to keep our body healthy. While we sleep, our body fixes any damage from the day and makes us ready for the next day. The second idea focuses on learning. It says sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not be able to learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery, so we have enough energy for the next day.'

**Eccentrics**

An eccentric is someone whose behavior is different from what is normal. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Most people have their own little habits or interests. For example, some people love entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. Inside us, there is a struggle between wanting to be different and wanting to fit in. It's like having two trains pushing against each other on the same track. One train is called individualism, and the other is conformity. For most people, conformity is stronger. We want to be accepted, loved, and feel like we belong. This is stronger than wanting to be different and stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find others like them. They form clubs, have meetings, and organize events to share their interests. They look for people who understand them, even if others think they are odd. Being part of a group, even a small one, feels comforting. We all feel a pull between being ourselves and fitting in. We might say we are different, like when someone at a bar says, "I say what I think," or when a new person says, "You must take me as I am."

At any time, we can choose to be more individual. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing and keep going, you will surprise many people." But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. If a pop singer wears strange clothes for attention or a hostess says shocking things to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. However, if they keep doing these things until it becomes who they are, then they might be eccentric. True eccentricity is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be odd; they just are. They do not care about what others think. They do what they do because of who they are. This makes them different from enthusiasts, practical jokers, criminals, exhibitionists, and recluses. These people are aware of the world and react to it. Some want to impress society, and some want to escape it, but they are aware of it. Eccentrics, however, continue on their own path without worrying about society.

**Natural Books**

We asked four nature experts to share the wildlife book that influenced them the most.

**A. Geoffrey Lean**

Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I've met many important people in this field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small but strong woman. She was very important in environmental issues in Europe after World War II. She combined her experiences into a powerful philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field better. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I think "The Home of Man" is her most important book. It talks about the fast growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It's a passionate call for what we now call 'sustainable development.' I've read many books since, but none match it.

**B. Linda Bennett**

When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a herring gull colony. This book explains animal communication very well with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony makes sense. You can see which birds are partners and where their territories are. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with Eric Ennion, a talented wildlife artist, to create this book. Ennion's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful. This is the work of a true nature expert.

**C. Lee Durrell**

"My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book made me love the natural world. I was researching animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. I was having a tough time, but reading this book made me happy. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty all together. Many people say humans are bad because of what we've done to nature. But I like to think of Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing the world as a family. We need to understand this idea.

**D. Bruce Pearson**

I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. I was attracted to the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and liked identifying birds. This book encouraged me to start sketching birds. It had more than just beautiful paintings. There were chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as important as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than math or physics, it opened a new path for me.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**

We asked five top British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in a newspaper. The Book Marketing Council found that more people buy books because of reviews than for other reasons like ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers both dislike getting no reviews, but publishers are usually calmer about bad reviews. They think that any mention, good or bad, can help sell books because people want to decide for themselves. Publishers enjoy reviews that match their own thoughts about a book because they are often the first to read it.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are still often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make a book and its author known. A good review by a trusted person can increase sales, especially if there are several reviews. Fame helps get books into readers' hands.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for literary publishing. Without them, we would struggle. We publish books by authors who are not famous, so we rely on reviews because we don't advertise much. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Reviews can help sell books, but they need to work with other things like word-of-mouth, support from bookshops, and smart marketing.

**Publisher D**  
In Britain, the link between publishing and reviews is unclear. In the U.S., a review in the New York Times can make or break a book. Here, bookshops don't always pay attention to reviews. Sometimes, it takes many years of good reviews for people to start reading a writer's work. Some poorly reviewed books sell very well, so it's unpredictable. Non-fiction reviews often focus more on what the reviewer knows about the topic than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want long, positive reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn't sell well because people felt they didn't need to buy the book after reading the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's more about the surprise of who reviews it or how interesting the review is that makes people want to buy the book.

Text: 'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in early Egyptian times. Today, this craft is still alive in Graham Smith's workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique and personal item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.' This is very different from the usual cockerel design, which is the most common weathervane. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. 'I realized that I could make weathervanes in many different shapes,' he says. Graham decided to focus on a weathervane business. He had trained as a precision engineer and worked in that job for 15 years. Then he and his wife, Liz, decided to change roles. She went to work as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to take care of the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his new job. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is exciting and creative,' he says. 'I really enjoy designing.' Graham has now made over 100 original designs. He works with very fine details and always asks the customer to approve the design before he starts cutting. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular too. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They like to have something a little different.' Graham does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a small, rural craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost lifelike,' he says. 'For centuries, weathervanes have helped communities understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like mine.' Graham is now very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients all over the world. Buyers from America and Denmark are especially interested. 'The price,' he explains, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.'

**Beginner Takes All**

Before it was even published, "The Horse Whisperer" was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British screenwriter Nicholas Evans, and it has made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about what inspired him and his success.

At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He is a screenwriter, producer, and wants to be a director. His year started badly when a film project called "Life and Limb," which he had worked on for months, suddenly failed. He was very worried because he hadn't made any money for two years, and this film was his only hope to pay the bank. 

Most people in his situation would have found a job. He could have gone back to working in television or started a TV project he had paused. But instead, he made a risky decision. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel for three months. 

The idea for the story came from a farrier (a person who shoes horses) he met on Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a calm horse that suddenly became wild. The owners were desperate until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. These people were called "horse whisperers." Evans was fascinated by this story. He started researching it to write a screenplay, but after his film project failed, he decided to write a book instead.

In the spring, he traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses and the people who work with them. He felt alone and worried about his future. He had tried for ten years to succeed as a filmmaker, but now he was in debt and worried about his family.

By August, he had written half of the book and was back home. The bank was pressuring him, and he needed to know if the book was worth finishing. He showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The friend said it was "fine" and thought Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts and support his family. He had already spent seven months on the book and needed at least two more months to finish it. 

In October, he sent the first 200 pages and a 12-page summary of the book to seven UK publishers. This was just before the Frankfurt Book Fair, a big event for publishers. Within days, his agent called to say they had turned down an offer of $75,000. The agent felt something big was happening.

Soon, the book was sold to Transworld Publications in the UK for $550,000 and to Delacorte in the US for $3.15 million, both record amounts for a first novel. Evans and his family were shocked. They hadn't even sent the book to New York, but somehow it got there. Hollywood studios also wanted it, and they offered $3 million for the film rights.

Evans told me all this while we drank coffee at his home. He said he turned down an offer to write the screenplay for "The Horse Whisperer." He didn't want to ruin the fairy tale by becoming an employee of the people who paid him so much. He would be involved in the film, but not too closely. 

The success of his novel also brought new interest in his film "Life and Limb," but he wasn't sure he wanted to make it anymore. He thought it would be wise to write another novel.

Text: 'Young Masters Bobby Fischer is trying to prove himself again, but age is not on his side. Chess is now a game for younger people. After 20 years away from chess, Bobby Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game with a brilliant move, but he is not the same as he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, not in practice, and not in good shape. Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now it is more professional. Winning is the main goal for modern players. In international chess, a player's nerves and stamina are as important as their intelligence. The game is very intense: players must make a certain number of moves in a set time, or they lose. Now, games last longer and are played without breaks, which benefits younger players. In the last 30 years, each new world champion has been younger than the one before. Of the top ten players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Much of the game happens off the board. Players must prepare well before matches, especially because computers have changed chess a lot. A small computer can store one million chess games and help players study their opponents. In a recent match, players used teams to find weaknesses in each other's games. The opening moves are now studied very carefully. Being well-prepared in the opening can decide the game. Today, there are more top players than ever before. Hundreds of grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success needs both physical and mental effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. Losing concentration can lead to disaster. The chess clock adds to the pressure. The end of the game can be a fast 'time scramble', where players have only seconds to make moves. They must move quickly and press the clock with great skill. These moments are not for thinkers; they are a battle of nerves and willpower. At the top level, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to rest. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to play again the next day. Most tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day. There is a tournament circuit all year round. World championship matches are even tougher. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov in Moscow had to stop because both players were too tired. Karpov lost about 10kg in weight. Can Fischer beat these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This made his leaving chess in 1972 hard to understand. But it made him a legend. If he returned for money, he will earn a lot. Whatever happens in his match with Spassky, both will become much richer. But if Fischer came back to prove he is still the best, losing could be very sad for him.'

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.

**A** Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three plays that critics love. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's a low-budget film, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before writing "Peaches," he had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know it's difficult. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I realized I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read, because of the rhythm and rhyme," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational environment. It was very exciting."

**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at Bristol, he was performing in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor and that I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but working with Steve Coogan has been the most successful. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.

**C** Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was very successful, and his career has taken off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says with a smile. "Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always going to be successful. Encouraged by his mother, he went from playing lead roles at school to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he stayed for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he is waiting for more praise, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for doing good work."

**D** Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released soon. "The record company has a different idea of good sales than I do," he says. "They talk about a big hit, but I have no idea. If two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to get into the music business ever since. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have happened at a better time. There were times when I was very depressed, and I've been in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."

**E** Poet and author Stephen Richards, 27, has won many prizes, awards, and academic honors. He is well-known in the poetry world, where he has been touring and giving readings for the past six years. Now his first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't express as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but became unhappy with education later. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with stuffing envelopes at a theater, I decided I should." After university, he published his first work, a children's book, in 1992. "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry getting so much praise, moving into novels is brave. "There's a structure with my poetry, and less chance to make big mistakes," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for bad words. My main goal is not to just produce work without caring about the quality."

**A.** Isabel, the main character in this funny novel, thinks she looks good in jeans but doesn't wear them often because she doesn't want to be seen with the wrong people. She is a 31-year-old art student who loves historical romance stories and is looking for Mr. Right. She worries that her knobbly knees might stop her from finding love.
