However, she always stays hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes with a lot of energy, like an old silent movie, with chapter titles such as 'Our Hero Feels Inspired.'

**B.** This story is about the start and almost end of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a smart but weak child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, a station created by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station soon broadcasts a mix of singers, preachers, soap-opera stars, and announcers. The small-town American setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing. The story takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of small shops, old cars, and, of course, the radio.

**C.** In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk with his wife's first husband. So, when successful professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a beautiful Russian poet, he talks to his wife's ex-husband about it. The poet writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she also wants his help to free her brother from prison. The author makes these problems interesting by using humor and carefully examining relationships. The story is enjoyable, smart, and funny.

**D.** Two pairs of best friends—two women and two men—meet in London during the 1960s and stay connected for 25 years. At the start of this long novel, one of them, an American businessman named James Hudson, is starting a newspaper, which his friend Richard Blake is editing. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that the woman they both loved (and one of them married) was killed years ago. The story includes murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is good. This book is long and detailed, allowing readers to really get to know the characters.

**E.** Written by a top American fiction writer, this funny and caring story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty for a mistake and decides to take care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, Ian is becoming an unusual bachelor surrounded by the mess of family life. The story explores many emotions and focuses on the sweet relationship Ian builds with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a lovely, warm book with a perfect mix of sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four experts talk about international volunteer work.

**A.** It's hard to say that volunteer work directly helps development a lot. Volunteer tourists often help build homes or schools, but they pay a lot of money to do this. If this money was given directly to local communities, it could pay for more work than one volunteer can do. This is especially true for gap year students, who usually don't have special skills or experience. Many studies question if gap year volunteering is really about helping others or if it's more about young people wanting to improve their own careers. However, these projects might help volunteers become more ethical and caring in their future lives and jobs.

**B.** Volunteering can lead to better international understanding, help solve conflicts, and increase participation in global issues. It can also create international friendships among regular people. In this way, both volunteers and host communities benefit, contributing to the global good. But if only rich people from wealthy countries volunteer, they might gain international experience and career benefits, while the communities they visit might not gain much. These volunteers might use the experience to advance personally, rather than truly helping the communities.

**C.** At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that benefits the volunteer more than the community. It can be about personal gain for wealthy Westerners. At its best, it benefits both volunteers and the communities, allowing for an exchange of skills and cultural experiences. Volunteering can also make people more aware of and committed to fighting poverty, injustice, and unsustainable development.

**D.** Volunteer tourism fits with the idea of helping others in small ways. This can seem positive, especially when people don't trust big governments or businesses. However, it can also ignore the need for bigger changes and reduce development to small acts of charity. While volunteering is a good act, when it's promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the real discussion about development. Volunteer tourism can sometimes avoid addressing the real social issues and inequalities in the world.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many of us listen to the radio when we wake up, and we often need something to help us get out of bed. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios.

One model has a 'dual alarm function.' I thought it would let you snooze and then wake up again, but it actually lets you set two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model is about the same price as another one we tested, but it includes a cassette player, which is a good deal. You can fall asleep to your own music and wake up without news. We all liked the radio's quality, but it's as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't work.

This model was the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, although the clock on his test model got stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with grey numbers on a green background. The snooze bar is wide, so you can tap it with your eyes closed. However, the buttons felt like piano keys, and I accidentally pressed them too much. The clock has a backup power feature, so you don't have to reset it if someone unplugs it. We all liked this feature, but setting it up was hard. Once we learned how, we felt 'cool' and sophisticated.

Tom Granger thought the model with a built-in lamp was 'tacky.' You have to pull the light out of its socket to use it, which made him question its quality. He had to read the instructions twice to make it work, and the clock kept jumping from 12:00 to 02:00. The light only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges liked the lamp idea but found the radio hard to tune. The buzzer was loud and annoying. Surprisingly, this model is the third most popular on the market.

Aimed at young people, one model has a bright casing and a matching strap. Tom Granger and I liked it because it stands out. It was the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. However, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes, which Paul Bridges found ridiculous. He said it was 'fiddly' and 'useless.'

The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was 'standard' and took up little space. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found easier to set up. With modern push-button tuning, you're never sure if you've pressed the buttons correctly. He admitted that radios have improved because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was basic, as did Paul Bridges, but we agreed the radio quality was fine. The buzzer worked well and got me out of bed in just two beeps!

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not originally from America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened. This makes their spines stick out to protect them. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines because they need to be lighter. These hedgehogs might try to run away from danger first and only roll into a ball if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, usually under bushes or in a hole in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**

Being successful in sports is difficult for everyone, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competitions take up a lot of time, so they have to make sacrifices. Despite these challenges, many women are overcoming obstacles and setting new records. Here, we talk to some talented British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

"I love the feeling of flying through the air and landing smoothly, but it can be scary. Sometimes the weather is bad, but you just have to keep going. We train for ten months a year, so it's hard to have a career outside skiing. You miss out on a lot of social life and friends, but I chose this. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and are treated the same - it's a young sport."

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike for a charity race and won because I was the fastest, even though I had never cycled before! I earn well as a professional, and cycling has many opportunities for sponsorships. However, I worry people might think I succeed because of my looks, not my skills. So, I focus on cycling and train at least four hours a day, plus stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands the time commitment."

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

"Rowing is hard for girls to start because few girls' schools offer it. Most start at 19 or 20, making it harder to succeed internationally. Coaches often stay for only a year, so there's little consistency, and the women's team is disorganized. But it's fun, I love being fit, and there's a good social life."

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

"At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not knowing how big it was! Britain felt too small and safe. I was stubborn and didn't like others controlling me. Now, I'm more tactful. Each walk is different. Walking across Australia was the hardest due to pain. I walked 50 miles and 21 hours a day with only three hours of sleep, in high temperatures, and with 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, as my sponsorship money was running out. Men often think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as risky."

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

"Some men have big egos when driving. When I do well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its downsides. At corners, men think, 'I have to beat her,' so I've had many bumps! You need to be competitive and aggressive. It's hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have raced since the 1920s and were seen as unusual. It's great that more women are racing now. I love saloon car racing because I aim for perfection, always trying for a perfect lap."

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Yes, I sometimes fall asleep at my desk! There's a lot of nervous energy before a race, and you push yourself hard. I've asked myself why I do it. The reasons are: a) I'm happier when I'm fit, b) I'm lazy at heart and need to push myself, c) racing is social. Men and women usually compete together, but media coverage focuses mostly on men. The prize money isn't as good for women, but we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission to work on this."

Title: The Day I Met Picasso

Richard Cork remembers the day he met the famous artist Picasso. At 18 years old, Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He was out of money and found a job painting boats in Cannes. One day, while eating at a restaurant, he saw Picasso, who was 78 years old, sitting with his wife and friends. Picasso was known to be a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him.

Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard approached Picasso and offered his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed his name and added a drawing on the page. Richard was thrilled and started a conversation with Picasso, using an American woman at the table to help translate.

After showing his friend the autograph, Richard was encouraged to go back and draw Picasso's portrait. Without asking for permission, Richard started drawing. Picasso noticed and made funny faces to make it difficult for Richard. Eventually, Picasso stopped and let Richard draw him properly. Richard was amazed by Picasso's youthful appearance and intense eyes.

When Richard finished, Picasso wanted to see the drawing. Although Richard was embarrassed, Picasso looked at it and then decided to draw Richard. In a few quick strokes, Picasso created a playful drawing of Richard. Richard asked Picasso to sign it, but Picasso said he had already given his signature.

Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and received his attention. It was a memorable experience for him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Spend More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Here are some tricks that stores use to make you spend more money.

**A. The Image of Freshness**

Supermarkets know that customers love fresh products. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance to make the store look fresh. They might also have a bakery inside, so the smell of fresh bread fills the air. The store might use green colors because people think of green as fresh. Most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh, but they use these tricks to create a fresh image.

**B. Displaying to Advantage**

Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas of the store are most popular. They put the most profitable or fast-selling products there. Products at eye level sell better, so companies want their items on these shelves. Special offers in big bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also place related items together, like salad dressings near salads, to encourage more buying.

**C. Spreading Staples Around the Store**

Supermarkets put basic items like bread, tea, and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers have to walk past other tempting products. Chain stores do the same with their popular items, placing them far from the entrance. They hope loyal customers will look for these items and see other products along the way.

**D. Less Sells More**

Some chain stores, like Next, have changed how they display products. Instead of having lots of cheap items, they show fewer items to make them seem special. This makes the store look like a boutique. Even though Next's clothes are mass-produced like others, their store design makes them seem exclusive.

**E. Tempting Totals**

Food shoppers care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets use this by selling a mix of cheap and expensive items. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers, known as 'loss leaders.' They also buy in large quantities to get discounts from manufacturers.

**F. The All-Important Price Tag**

In chain stores, shoppers buy fewer items and notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 can make a difference. This also helps reduce theft because staff have to record the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting to Effect**

Stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use lighting that looks like natural light, so clothes look the same as they would outside. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh food look better.

**H. Walk This Way**

Some chain stores use different carpets to guide shoppers. One type of carpet shows the path through the store, and another type marks sales areas. This is called the 'Yellow Brick Road.' Not all shoppers follow these paths, so stores like Marks and Spencer use wood or marble for paths and carpet for sales areas to encourage people to explore.

**I. In-Store Promotion**

When you enter a supermarket, you might see big photos of delicious food. This is very tempting, especially if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets use 'video trolleys' with screens that show ads as you shop. These ads are triggered by sensors and aim to increase impulse buying, boosting sales by about 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a famous mountaineer, is best known for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their trip in a book called "Sea, Ice and Rock."

In 1979, while working on "Quest for Adventure," Chris called Robin for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail, where Chris could teach him climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed, anchored, and then went to shore to practice climbing. Chris was impressed by Robin's calmness in difficult climbing conditions. When they reached a big drop, Chris showed Robin how to climb down safely. Robin, used to climbing down ropes on his boat, managed to lower himself safely.

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a bigger version of their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Although the skipper usually makes all decisions, Robin asked for everyone's opinion first. Chris found sailing boring and preferred being on land, while Robin enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because Robin didn't really need his help.

The crew was crowded on a small yacht, with six people on a boat meant for four. In Greenland, when it was Chris's turn to lead, he found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety while climbing. Climbing Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, was more challenging than Chris expected. Robin, not a natural climber, impressed Chris with his efforts. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours but had to turn back. Robin trusted Chris completely and was willing to try again despite worrying about the boat.

The only time Chris and Robin almost had a problem was on the way home. Chris was supposed to take a watch shift at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him, thinking he could handle it alone. Chris felt Robin didn't trust him, but Robin reassured him that wasn't true. By the end of the Greenland trip, Chris realized that Robin, despite his tough exterior, was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since prehistoric times. In ancient Britain, they spat out apple seeds. Around 10,000 years ago, people in Switzerland and Italy left apple remains near their homes. They even stored apple halves for winter. These were wild crab apples, small and not like the apples we know today.

**Norman Influence (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and they brought this knowledge to Britain. They also learned how to make cider. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but they didn't grow well in Britain. The Normans brought better varieties, and British monks developed new types of apples. Many Western apples come from these varieties.

**Medieval Apples (1200)**  
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain, known for its pear-like shape, was a favorite dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in Oxford markets. However, apple production declined due to droughts, the Black Death, and wars. More apples were imported until the 16th century when Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apple growing. Harris brought back many apple grafts, including the famous Pippins, and started a modern orchard in Kent.

**Apples Abroad (1750)**  
By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that settlers took them to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, Jan van Riebeeck to South Africa, and the Pilgrim Fathers to America. In North America, John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed,' planted apple nurseries from Pennsylvania to Indiana. He was known for his love of apple trees and his kindness.

**Modern Apples (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple growing from a dead tree. He called it 'Hawkey,' but it became known as 'Delicious' after a judge tasted it and exclaimed, "Delicious, delicious!" It became one of the most popular apples worldwide. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith discovered another famous apple. Known as 'Granny Smith,' she found a new apple tree growing from discarded fruit. This tree produced the first major crop of green apples, now famous worldwide.

**Uniformity in Apples (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown worldwide, from India to Africa. Most commercial apples come from just a few varieties, chosen for their red skin or ability to travel well, not for taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as it reduces the gene pool. While some gardeners in the UK keep old apple varieties alive, many have been lost in the US. Consumers are now asking for more variety. We need to protect natural diversity in apples and other foods for everyone's benefit.

Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures

Richard Nerurkar, a top British long-distance runner, visited a high-altitude training camp in Kenya. This camp is located in Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya, which is covered in glaciers. For three years, Richard trained in Kenya but never with Kenyan runners. On his fourth trip, he changed this. He competed in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. He was invited by the national team coach after finishing fifth in a world championship race. Training at high altitudes helps runners because it increases red blood cells, which carry oxygen better. This is one reason Kenyan runners are so successful.

Richard's first race in Africa was an international cross-country race in Nairobi. It was a humbling experience because 41 runners finished ahead of him, and most were Kenyan. He realized that Kenyan success is not just due to altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple approach to running. They run with ease, eat simple foods, and enjoy competing. Richard wanted to know how they train.

At the training camp, located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya, Richard found out. The camp is basic, with athletes living in simple dormitories. Their day includes three workouts: an easy morning run, interval training mid-morning, and a steady run in the afternoon. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers. Life at the camp is simple. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner include ugali, stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they bathe in streams from Mount Kenya.

Richard left the camp with a new appreciation for Kenyan runners. Their success is not just about genetics, upbringing, or altitude. It might be the simple lifestyle, hard training, and passion for success that make them the best in the world at distance running.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Almost everyone knows that advertising is having problems. It's not just because of the recession. Advertising started to drop in 1989, even before the recession got serious. The problems with advertising are deeper, and it's happening all over the world. The truth is, advertising hasn't kept up with how fast the economy is changing. Advertisers like to think about big markets and big media, but as more brands and media have appeared, target markets have become smaller. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they often don't. This is where advertising has gone wrong.

Think about how you shop. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or 50 items. Many of these won't be advertised brands; some will be the same brand bought multiple times. You might only buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 products in the store. Over a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. Big items like appliances? Maybe a dozen a year. Cars? If you have a new car, it's likely from your employer. If not, you buy one every three years. You don't buy many clothes either, and most aren't advertised brands. Even with candy, medicine, tools, and services, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

Compare that to the 32,500 branded goods and services that are advertised. Let's focus on the 9,500 brands that spend more on advertising. The average person buys 400 of those 9,500, and not all because of ads. That's about 4 percent. So, you could say 96 percent of advertising is wasted, but no one knows which 96 percent. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about one in 16 (6 percent), so the other 15 (94 percent) seem wasted.

You might think you're not affected by advertising, but almost everyone thinks that. The truth is, nobody buys most of the brands they see advertised. Waste is part of using media for advertising. It's silly to think everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. People notice only a few ads and ignore the rest, so waste can't be avoided. But advertising can still be cost-effective. Many ads have shown it works. Advertising needs to reach many people to find the right few, because advertisers can't know who will respond. Media advertising works because it's a cheap way to reach many people.

However, waste is still a problem. With smart targeting, advertisers can reduce waste by reaching more people who will respond, but they can never know exactly who will. Even the best direct mail never gets a 100 percent response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every client. This can't happen with media. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they wouldn't need media. They could contact people directly. This is true for all ads, from soft drinks to important announcements.

Any advertiser who gets one million new customers (2 percent of adults) is doing well. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million extra customers. So, any ad campaign that wins over 2 percent of the population is very successful. But that's still a small part of the population. The best way to reach them might be through mass media, but for advertising to improve, its message needs to be more focused than ever before.

Title: Britain's Greenest Home

Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. Southwell is known for its ancient cathedral, Southwell Minster, which has 'green' men carved into its decoration. But it also has Britain's greenest house, called the 'autonomous house', built by Robert and Brenda Vale.

The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their waste into garden compost, and heat their house with heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with their three children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and fits well with the town's old buildings. It even got approval from planners because it blends in with the conservation area.

The house is very quiet inside because it is super-insulated with special windows. When you enter, you must take off your shoes, and it feels very peaceful. On a sunny day, the conservatory warms the air before it goes into the house. Robert opens special vents and windows to let in fresh air because the house is very well sealed. Even the cats have their own special door.

The Vales, who teach architecture, have been interested in the environment for a long time. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s. They wanted to build a house that does not produce carbon dioxide and does not use mains water. They use composting toilets, collect rainwater, and use copper gutters to keep the water clean. They do not have a dishwasher because they do not want to use strong detergents.

The Vales wanted to show that it is possible to have an environmentally-friendly house without living in the dark ages. The house looks a bit medieval because of its design, but it is modern in its function. The Vales do not pay water bills, and last winter, they used very little electricity, costing about 70p a day. Soon, they will have solar panels to generate even more electricity, enough to charge an electric car.

The only heating in the house is a small wood-burning stove, which they rarely use. In winter, the house stays warm because there are no draughts and everything inside is the same temperature. Robert says that people used to be comfortable at lower temperatures because of their clothing.

The house is simple and low-tech, with most materials bought from local suppliers and built by local workers. This made it cheap to build, costing the same as low-cost housing. However, commercial builders are not interested in this idea.

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical and scientific person. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies taken in a garden, he believed they were real proof that fairies existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural beings. It wasn't until 1939 that the two women who took the photos admitted they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos are very beautiful. But the simple trick shows that a basic idea about photography, that the camera cannot lie, is not true. Cameras can lie, and they always could. Today, we know that computer software lets us change our digital photos, and it is not true that photography ever had a time when it was completely honest. From the start, when cameras began capturing reality, that reality was being changed.'

Blacksmiths

Iron has always been important to people, and those who work with it, called blacksmiths, have been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also celebrated as artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The flowing metal designs of French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings were also made by talented blacksmiths.

However, by the late 1960s in Britain, blacksmiths were almost gone because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern buildings rarely used decorative ironwork. But in the past 10 years, there has been a revival due to more interest in decorative architecture and new ideas in interior design. Still, much of the work looks old-fashioned, with many products being called 'classical' or 'Victorian-style'. Trendy design stores often sell rusty candlesticks with decorations.

Fortunately, there are new options, and several events aim to promote blacksmithing. One event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says we might be entering a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently now. Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld it easily. Dawson says, 'These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves.'

About 250 pieces are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most of the money will go to the makers, but some will help promote good ironwork. Dawson's own pieces include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says his style comes from letting steel bend and flow when it's hot, like drawing with metal in space.

Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's soft when hot but becomes hard when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles inspired by castles in horror films. One design looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. She loves that steel feels permanent.

Iron has given people visual pleasure and a sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

Title: The Day I Quit Smoking

I thought everyone would be happy when I quit smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She said, "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't really explain how I went from smoking a pack a day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It even surprised me. 

I attended a stop-smoking session that combined group therapy and hypnotherapy. This happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to quit smoking, and I didn't really want to. I was annoyed by the pressure from people who were against smoking. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family, so I didn't feel sick or cough. I even thought I got over colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On a regular Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" in Birmingham. I was there to write an article about other people trying to quit. I told them, "I won't try to stop myself because I'm here to write, not to quit. It wouldn't be fair to expect your method to work on me." I enjoyed smoking and it made me happy. The counselor seemed to understand something I didn't.

We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't really want to, and neither did the others. The messages about quitting smoking started to make sense to me. Just like smoking was a challenge because people were against it, quitting started to feel like a good idea. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling, just for me. Could I also achieve other things?

In many ways, quitting was easy. The physical craving for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two. I only felt it for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem at all. I believed I needed nicotine to meet deadlines, but I was wrong. Surprisingly, spending weekend mornings at home was the hardest part, and it still is. I think smoking was a way to avoid boredom; having a cigarette was something to do.

Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is different, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were all times when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but not many people in Britain know her name. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's biography, finds this surprising. If Hodgkin had won a Nobel Prize in literature, she would be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the progress of women's education and the spread of science around the world.

When Ferry started her research, she read scientific biographies. A friend of Hodgkin suggested a biography of Linus Pauling, a famous chemist and friend of Hodgkin. However, Ferry couldn't find any books about Pauling in her local bookshop. This made her realize that people in Britain might not find scientists' lives interesting, even if they are very important.

Some people think that scientists' lives are boring to read about. Peter Medawar, another Nobel Prize winner, once said that scientists' lives are not exciting. This view makes it hard for publishers to sell books about scientists. There is a belief that arts and sciences are very different, which affects how scientists are seen in biographies. Only the most famous scientists are usually written about.

However, scientists' lives can be just as interesting as those of artists, writers, or politicians. Some scientists avoid media attention because they don't want to seem like they are promoting themselves. This can make science seem less interesting to young people and the public.

Fortunately, things are changing. Scientists are now appearing more in public, not just in scientific interviews. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives prizes on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car advertisements. These activities help people see scientists as real people.

The publishing world is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be serious and not very interesting, often ignoring the scientist's personal life. This changed with Richard Feynman's book, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", which was funny and touching. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein are shown with their personal flaws.

Dorothy Hodgkin was very dedicated to her scientific work. She solved the structures of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and later insulin in 1969. She also had three children and a husband who was often away for his work as a historian. Her personal life may not seem important to her science, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life.

Hodgkin's life is interesting to many people, not just because of her science. Her passion for scientific discovery was a big part of her life. Writing about this passion is a challenge for biographers because many readers don't have the scientific background to understand complex ideas easily. It's sad that many educated people don't know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they are part of our rich heritage.

Margaret and Her Special Skill

Margaret Wilkins has a special ability called a 'sixth sense'. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

This skill, called dowsing, helps find water, minerals, and lost things underground. People have different ideas about how it works. Some think it is about magnetism, while others think it is spiritual. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Dowsers, like Margaret, might be very good at feeling these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' or even smell water.

In recent years, there has been a lot of work for the Wilkins because of droughts. At one point, they had a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of Margaret's customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, 'We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time.' Other customers have holiday homes far from water pipes, or they are building golf courses.

Margaret tries to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near any waste. The water they find is in cracks of hard rock, which keeps it clean. But in Cornwall, where they work, there is a lot of iron, so they have to be careful. They also need electricity to run the pump, so the well should be near power supplies.

To find water, Margaret starts with a map and a pendulum. She moves the pendulum over the map, and it swings when there is water. Then she walks over the land with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. She holds the stick with both hands, and when water is below, the stick moves up. It is important to drill exactly where the stick shows. If they are a little off, they might miss the water. Her husband also checks the area, and they must agree on where to drill. If they don't agree, they keep looking.

Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition. Many people are interested in how she does it. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This means she has a special way of understanding the land. Without this skill, her family could not run their well-drilling business successfully year after year.

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**

Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different. We arranged this for four people. Read about their experiences.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda, a 23-year-old mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant.

Amanda had never been in a place like the restaurant before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. It was very different from her hometown. She had to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand in just 15 minutes. The other waitresses made it look easy, but Amanda dropped the drinks, and they spilled everywhere. She was embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and said everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, there was already a line of people waiting to get in, and Amanda felt nervous. She was worried about remembering all the orders, but everything was automated, so it wasn't a problem. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and she couldn't get used to the loud music. She had to keep asking customers to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was very tired and wanted to soak her feet in hot water. She was surprised when a waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day. Amanda realized that waitressing is tiring and not as easy as she thought. She was glad to go back to her children, which seemed easier after waitressing.

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy was nervous but excited to be a "mum" for the day. She knew Amanda's daughters could be cheeky, but she thought she could handle it. She had to get the girls dressed and fed, drop Sophie at school, and Katie at nursery. She thought she would have some free time, but Amanda left her a note with chores like making beds, cleaning, and doing laundry.

At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. When Sophie came home from school, the girls started jumping on the sofa and screaming. Cindy thought they would get tired, but they didn't. She managed to get them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up and watch TV. Cindy found it exhausting to look after two small children and realized how much responsibility it is. Even though it was tiring, she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary, who is 42 and runs a dairy farm, swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher.

On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She was nervous about what to wear to school. At the school assembly, she hoped she blended in with the 400 pupils. She helped with a maths class and a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired but found out teachers only have about five minutes to eat. She attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a reading lesson and a French lesson, where the children practiced their French with her. Finally, there was a Physical Education class. Rosemary found it hard to stand in front of the class and speak. She decided she preferred farming, even though teachers get more holidays.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at White House Farm at 8:30 am and found out Rosemary had been up for three hours. The farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep. Rosemary also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream to sell. Hilary spent the morning in the ice cream shop, bottling milk and packing ice cream. She had to resist tasting the treats.

At lunchtime, she checked the sheep and helped a fallen ewe. If sheep are left on their backs for too long, they can die. After feeding the calves, she started milking the cows, which took two and a half hours. Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children at school. She realized that farming is hard work with little time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of holiday a year. Farming seems romantic, but it's tough, with irregular income and dependence on the weather.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, from a small town in southern Sweden, is one of them. At 30 years old, he is now a famous trumpet player. His music includes not only old concertos from the baroque and classical periods but also new works. When you meet him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of his trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a TV show talked about his work and life, showing parts filmed in Sweden and London.

Hakan was born near Malmo, and his career started because of a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong but wasn't musical, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, who was a talented musician in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra. Bo saw Hakan's natural talent right away. Hakan is grateful for having such a great teacher who loved the trumpet and was always learning more about it.

Hakan explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument with imperfections, and you can't find two mouthpieces that are exactly the same. He learned to work with these imperfections and make them part of his music. Even as a child, people could recognize his unique sound. Unlike John Wallace, a famous British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired Maurice Andre, a French trumpeter who also focused on solo performances. Hakan's parents supported his dream to become a professional trumpet player.

At 15, Hakan needed to decide where to study. America was too far and seemed dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud advised him against joining an orchestra, comparing it to gardening. Hakan knew he played better than others his age, but it was during a competition in Paris at 17 that he realized he had a special gift for connecting with people through music. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for experience. Hakan only prepared for the first round but made it to the final. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and noticed that people listened to him, even if he thought he didn't play perfectly.

Hakan is realistic about his talent and doesn't try to explain his ability to connect with audiences, saying that trying to explain it might ruin it. He believes the power of music is in its ability to move people.

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special story about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is known for its humor and the author's unique way of seeing things. It also has deep insights into human psychology. The novel is challenging but worth reading.

**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about the incident. Leo, who was a good student and never fought before, won't say why he did it. Joe recovers physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son and focuses all her energy on him. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, leading to an unusual friendship. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives and how mothers feel they can never do enough.

**C.** This book was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. It tells the story of one of the most remote Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long, quiet history. The book mixes this story with important moments in Scottish history, imagined by the young main character, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.

**D.** After a recent successful book, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle humor and sharp observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living is a mix of vanity, charm, and kindness. Rosie helps her in dealing with suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is taking over. The author is good at showing the sadness that is hidden in everyday life and how random events can be.

**E.** Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during the trip. They return home with their spirits lifted by the experience of life on the ocean. The author uses surprising images to show themes of memory and awareness, which are both confusing and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their different jobs: the good parts, the challenges, and what a typical workday looks like.

**A. The Brain Surgeon**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34

**Anne's Day:**  
Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym at 7 am, and starts work at 8 am. She begins operating at 8:30 am. She operates all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most operations take three hours, but some can last all day. Sometimes, she works for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. She doesn't feel stressed while operating, but she worries about the next day's work. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it succeeds, it feels great. From 10 am to 1 pm, she talks to patients about their operations. She enjoys this and finds it easy to talk to them. If patients get upset, she comforts them, but time can be tight. She leaves work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, she is on call and carries a pager. On holidays, she worries about her patients for the first three days and dreams about operating at night. She finds it hard to relax.

**B. The Senior Designer**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31

**Marita's Day:**  
Marita wakes up at 7:45 am, leaves home by 8:20 am, takes the train, and arrives at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, her team meets to discuss their work and any problems. Her team includes three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of her work is design; the rest is production. She gets a brief from the client and spends three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting her ideas to the client and getting approval, she works on budgets and hires photographers and illustrators. She communicates with printers to ensure everything is on time. Managing people is a big part of her job. She has to communicate well with many people and give clear instructions. She assembles everything and sends it to the printers. Managing several projects at once can be stressful. Deadlines are always near, and her day has no set structure. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, and she tries to go out. If not, she eats sandwiches and works through lunch. It's a great feeling when a client likes her designs, but disappointing if the work is rejected. She gets home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. She finds it hard to relax after work, especially when busy.

**C. The Chauffeur**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42

**Linda's Day:**  
Linda usually wakes up at 7 am, but two or three times a week, she meets early flights and wakes up between 4:30 am and 5 am. Around 10:30 or 11 am, she might go for a bike ride or swim. Since driving is a sitting job, she watches her diet and exercises carefully. She has a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask her for restaurant or shop recommendations, so she needs to know the area well. Many jobs are pre-booked, so she can check routes in advance. Not all passengers are polite; some are rude. But most are well-behaved, and she has a good relationship with regular clients. Sometimes she hears conversations in the car and has to focus on driving. The press has tried to get her to talk about clients, but she doesn't. She works seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and tries not to get too tired. She aims to be in bed by 11 pm.

**D. The Landscape Gardener**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27

**Tracy's Day:**  
Tracy wakes up at 7 am, leaves home at 7:30 am, and goes to her first job. She and her assistant mostly maintain gardens they designed. They do some commercial work, but mostly private gardens. They spend about an hour and a half at each house. Around 11 am, they get hungry and go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, she may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. Her business office is at home, so she checks messages and calls when she returns. If someone wants their garden landscaped, she arranges a meeting in the evening. They use old materials to make gardens look old. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren't great. It's satisfying to see a garden completed and blooming. It's hard to relax in the evenings because she hears the business phone. She sleeps well because the work is physical and tiring. She isn't very strong but is fit. The job is tough physically but allows creativity.

**E. The Civil Engineer**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27

**Zena's Day:**  
Zena arrives at the site by 8:30 am. She is an assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a wall to prevent cars from driving into a quarry. She checks that contractors follow the schedule and safety rules and have minimal environmental impact. She coordinates site professionals and solves problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so she first checks with the clerk of works about what happened since she left. Her day depends on this information. She reviews paperwork and answers design questions. Lunch is usually half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but she often eats on the go. When contractors are on break, it's easier to check the site. Checking their work can cause conflict, so she keeps an open relationship with them. She sees the duty resident engineer once a day but acts immediately if something important happens. She usually leaves the site at 6 pm and is always on call.

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7.30 am. I manage programs for our regular credit card users. My job includes starting and managing the Membership Rewards program in big European markets. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and answering emails. I handle all the advertising for the membership program across Europe, so I meet with our marketing team and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future projects. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. There are nine customer service units in Europe, and I travel to different markets once or twice a week to discuss issues. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6.30 pm and 7.00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10.00 am and go through the mail, which includes 10 to 20 demo tapes, letters from producers, and concert information. The phone starts ringing at 10.30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day to discuss campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be helpful because it's important work for the artists. I know if the sound fits our record label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets and spending. I leave work at 7.00 pm at the earliest and often go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After a concert, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life is mostly related to work, and I often get home at 1.00 am, where I listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**
I wake up at 8.00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9.30 am. I open the mail, check the diary for client visits, and wait to see who comes in. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and selling furniture, knowing it's going to a good home. We sell antiques from £1,000 to £6,000 and buy from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work with gilders, picture framers, and paper repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while having coffee to stay updated on the business. I visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5.30 pm and take about an hour to relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work in shifts, and on early shifts, I leave home at 6.00 am. At 7.00 am, I take over from the night shift at one of the four control positions in the tower. We have a rotating schedule, working for about an hour and a half at a station, then taking a break before returning to a different station. The team includes air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and a watch manager, and we control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read up on new air traffic requirements between 12 and 4.00 am. It's important to be alert in this job, so I don't hesitate to take sick leave if needed. The work is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and maybe even a general manager of the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8.00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system. I make sure someone is at the till and organize staff lunches and breaks. I spend the morning helping customers and ordering books for them. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be frustrating if they expect me to gather many books for them. Between 2.00 pm and 4.00 pm, publishers' representatives visit the shop, and I discuss new titles for the coming months. I decide how many copies of a title the shop might sell. When we feature a new title, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5.45 pm. Two days a week, I work a late shift, closing the computer system, locking up, and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7.00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving at 8.45 am. I contact our freelance reporters to learn about events in the region I cover. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential problems. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9.15 am to 9.30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first executive preview is due online by 10.00 am, and the second by 11.00 am, so I work quickly. I type stories, send them to my editor for approval, and make changes before they go online. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events or stay updated. I leave work around 6.00 pm. It's hard to relax, and I'm often awake at 1.00 am.

**Career Power: How to Be a Good Leader at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader is someone who inspires others and helps bring change. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote "Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace," says leadership is about making things happen with people who are as excited as you are. Enthusiasm is important, and a good leader should speak clearly and with confidence. Dixon says, "It's about saying 'I believe' instead of 'I think.'"

B. **Everyone Can Be a Leader**  
John van Maurik, who teaches leadership, says many people have more leadership potential than they know. Becoming a leader means recognizing and developing your hidden talents. We are all born with the ability to lead; we just need the right situation to grow. We often see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, but it can also be important in our own workplaces. Leadership is now seen as very important for good management.

C. **Think About Your Bosses**  
Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. They might have been good at meeting goals and deadlines. But how did they do it? The best leader motivated and supported you. The worst made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first was a good leader; the second was a bad manager.

D. **Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new paths. Michael Shea, who wrote "Leadership Rules," says a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a struggling organization, whether it's a company, a sports team, or a country.

E. **Improve Your Leadership Skills**  
Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some tips:  
- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find out what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired, use that energy to lead.  
- Think of yourself as a leader. Recognize your ability to lead.  
- Sometimes you need to be firm. Try different styles. If you usually ask for others' opinions, try taking the lead. See how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and try to beat them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better.

F. **Developing Leadership**  
- Leadership doesn't just happen. It grows from taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and give feedback.  
- Don't expect your way of leading to work right away. It might not be liked by everyone. Keep improving your communication skills. Your ideas and achievements are important.  
- Be visible and available to those who matter. But remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your help is needed and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before making Titanic, director James Cameron created this intense Cold War thriller. It's about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team remind us of heroes from old movies. The production design and special effects are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. Despite the great filmmaking, the story feels like a typical B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release is based on the James Jones novel about the battle for Guadalcanal. Directed by Andrew Marton, it is different from Terrence Malick's new film. Marton's version is a more traditional war movie and focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. While Malick's film is more complex, Marton's has its good moments. The flashback scene, where the soldier dreams of his wife, is done with a harshness that might work better than Malick's softer style.

**C. On Guard**  
This film is loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel. It's a fun and entertaining adventure with musketeers. Fabrice Luchini plays a great villain, and Vincent Perez is an energetic hero, though his role is short. Daniel Auteuil is a bit too serious for this type of movie, but he still has good moments as a swordsman. The film uses costume-drama clichés with so much wit and energy that it remains enjoyable.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film is a serious story. The detailed production and costumes make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the harsh bailiff Dreverhaven, who is very strict when evicting tenants. The story focuses on his difficult relationship with his son, but the filmmakers seem more interested in showing the period details than exploring the story's dark themes.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released video shows director Leone's skills very well. The sound editing is excellent, making every sound clear. The story is harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's great music makes it exciting again. Morally, there is little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act without much scruple in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This war epic boasts 'forty-eight international stars' and is three hours long. With four directors and 23,000 extras, it feels overdone. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, are slow for both the characters and the audience. Logistically, it's impressive, but it needs a big screen to be fully appreciated. On video, it loses some of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is a very interesting book. The story is about a lawyer who starts a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife, who is accused of killing her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending has a surprising twist. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B**  
*Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. It follows Sigismondo, who solves problems for rich people in the Italian Renaissance. He gets involved in politics, church secrets, and murder. We know he will find the guilty people. The story is a bit complicated and long, but it is still very good.

**BOOK C**  
*File Under: Deceased* is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. The main character, Leah Hunter, is a tax inspector. She starts investigating when a man dies in front of her. Leah is brave and smart, even when people don't like her. She is a great new detective character.

**BOOK D**  
*Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker is about a private investigator named Spenser. He helps his friend Hawk to get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The conversations are quick and clever, and there is more thinking than usual. It is high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**  
*False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a robbery and attack at a famous actress's daughter's house. The author's easy writing style and interesting look at human behavior make this a fun mystery.

**BOOK F**  
*Blood Red, Snow White* is written by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It is about a lawyer and his female client, but the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. The book has romance, money, and violence, making it an exciting suspense novel.

**BOOK G**  
*Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher, who is in danger. A funny group of characters come together to make a movie about Robin Hood. Philip is not happy with his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains, but this book is not as good as his others.

**BOOK H**  
*Fall Down Easy* by Lawrence Gough is his best book in a while. Canadian police are after a smart bank robber who targets female bank workers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the clever, troubled robber, making it better than the average detective novel.

Text: "I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age decide to take this big step. This summer, I quit my job, decided to rent out my apartment, and travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old, and I'm nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking around North and South America. When I came back, I wanted to do it again someday. But you know how life goes... I fell in love, started a career, bought an apartment, and got used to earning a salary. But I slowly realized I was giving up my happiness for my salary. When I quit my job, it felt like I was in control of my life again. Now, I have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't trade places with me, they envy my lack of responsibilities. I'm not in a relationship, and I don't have big career goals. I feel like I should enjoy this freedom, even for my friends' sake! Why am I so nervous? First, it's about making the necessary plans. How could I let someone else live in my home? And how would I organize the rental? Also, I had to decide where to go. I'm really bad at making decisions and am already weeks behind my plan. 'Might as well enjoy the summer in England,' I told myself. Then, 'Why not stay for the start of the football season?' Cutting emotional ties makes it even harder. I'm delaying because, deep down, I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among young backpackers just out of school and university? Maybe not. I've found that more Britons in their late twenties and thirties want to leave their lives behind and travel. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet guidebooks, says more people realize that adventure is possible: 'People who always say "I wish I had that chance" are realizing they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.' For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, it's a chance to have one last adventure before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm ready to give up job security for the trip,' says Danny. 'There's always a thought in your mind that, "OK, I'm not moving up in my career, I'll be in the same place when I come back," but I think it's a risk worth taking. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a way to show my defiance!' For Matt, who just left the Army, the year he spent traveling was a time of change. 'In the military, there's a set way of doing things. I went away because I needed to change this and get rid of this approach to have a normal life as a civilian.' While there are many reasons to travel at my age, there seem to be common factors. 'We have a more flexible workforce today,' says Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development. 'More people work on short-term contracts, so if your contract ends, you have nothing to lose.' Big companies are even allowing career breaks. 'If you've spent a lot of time and money training someone, it's nice to know they'll come back rather than work for a competitor.' For Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a company that shares stories of 'ordinary' travelers, more people in their thirties are thinking about their lives. 'If you're not happy with what you're doing - and many people aren't - it's not just about sticking with it. Now people know that opportunities exist and that a job isn't "for life" anymore. Travel offers a chance to rethink and consider your life.' Is wanting to travel just another example of my generation not wanting to grow up? Jennifer Cox doesn't think so. 'It's a sign of a better-educated, more stable society when we're less worried about paying bills and more about living a balanced life. We're actually taking the time to ask "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn't think he's running away. 'It's more about running towards something. It's trying to get things I want for myself.' But he does feel some fear. 'It's the thought of leaving behind a comfortable routine - just going to the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and sitting down with a cup of coffee.' I share Ben's worries about leaving behind an easy life with few challenges, and I'm not sure I'd be making this journey if I hadn't found my boss so difficult. As Jennifer Cox points out: 'This is common. There's often a reason, like a breakup or losing a job, that pushes people to go and do it.' It may have taken a push to get me moving, but I'm now looking forward to the next 12 months with excitement. Whatever happens, I'll be happy knowing I took control of my life. And in that, I'm sure I speak for all of us older backpackers."

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her journalism career and felt out of touch with new technology. She shares how she turned her home into a good place to work. When she turned 37, she realized she needed to restart her career in journalism, which seemed outdated. Her resume showed she was stuck in the 1980s, using old technology like typewriters. She felt unqualified for jobs that required computer skills, like desktop publishing. She was not good with technology, even simple things like calculators or video timers.

Georgina thought it would be hard to go back to work before her children grew up. But then she entered a competition in a local newspaper and won a computer package for her family. They received a laptop for her husband and a personal computer for everyone. They quickly learned about the Internet and started using terms like cyberspace and surfing. The children stopped watching TV, and Georgina set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, fax machine, CD-ROM, and modem to connect to the Internet. She could work from home and still take her children to school.

The children were comfortable with computers because they used them at school. Georgina was more cautious, worried she might lose her work by pressing the wrong button. But she learned the basic skills she needed, finding it logical and easy. She started freelancing for a magazine, writing two articles a month, and felt happy to have the best of both worlds.

The computer helped her become organized, especially with office tasks. She used spreadsheets to track income and expenses and saved time with pre-formatted invoices and letterheads. Being online allowed her to research stories and connect with other journalists worldwide. However, working from home also had downsides, like feeling isolated and dealing with household distractions. There were also arguments over who got to use the computer when the children were home.

Many people in her area bought multimedia PCs for education, leisure, and work. A new type of home business was growing, allowing people to avoid commuting to the city. A report on PC usage in UK homes described the typical computer user as 38 years old and well-educated, with most owning a personal computer and many having a CD-ROM and modem. Georgina felt she was ahead of the trend and hoped to one day email a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publish her own magazine from home. It seemed that the possibilities were endless.

The Tartan Museum

The new Museum of Scotland has modern buildings that look very different from the old city of Edinburgh. But are the things inside the museum as interesting? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.

You can't miss the museum. It stands out on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh with its big, yellow sandstone tower and unique buildings. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building. Some loved it, calling it a 'masterpiece', while others were not sure or didn't like it at all. This winter, as the museum is about to open, people might feel the same way about the exhibitions inside.

The museum tells many stories about Scotland's history. It has important objects like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and the Holyrood chapel silver. The museum does not just focus on national pride. The main question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to visit again.

Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants the museum to be enjoyable for everyone, not just experts. He believes in showing the truth about history, so there are no fake scenes or imagined stories. The museum uses explanation panels, captions, and some computers to tell the stories of the objects.

Inside the museum, the spaces are impressive. The galleries are different sizes and shapes, with pale walls that look like stone and deep display cases. Light comes in through narrow windows and from the roof. There is space to enjoy each item.

The museum also has a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of 9- to 12-year-olds from all over Scotland. They wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a special hands-on area for kids.

On the top floor, there is a Twentieth Century gallery. It will change every three years and shows objects that people in Scotland think are important, like an electric guitar, televisions, and favorite toys. This idea is fun, but it might not seem very serious. It could feel more meaningful when a computer display of personal stories starts next week.

Dr. Clarke believes that objects help us understand the past better than anything else. The modern architecture of the museum looks great from the inside, but whether it fits in with the old city is another question.

The end of print newspapers might take a long time. Change can be scary for some people, but the word "transition" makes it sound easier. Transition means moving smoothly from the present to the future. However, the move from print newspapers to online news is not smooth. Many people think it will happen because print sales are going down while visits to newspaper websites are going up. For example, newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen their print sales drop by 8% to 10% in a year, but their website visits are increasing.

However, the situation is not the same everywhere. The World Association of Newspapers says that global newspaper sales actually went up by 1.1% last year, thanks to more sales in Asia. In the West, sales went down, but news magazines saw a 5.4% increase. Books are also interesting. E-readers like Kindle are selling well, but the sales of physical books only went down by 0.4%. This shows that people are using both screens and paper.

The idea that young people are not reading newspapers is not true. Almost 5 million people aged 15 to 35 read the main national newspapers. In Europe, the situation is different in each country. In Britain, print sales dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the drop was only 7%, and in France, it was just 3.1%.

In the past, people thought that online ads would make online newspapers successful. But now, online ad revenue is going down. Many US newspapers have started charging for online content. The best way to get people to pay is to offer both print and digital access together. Print is still important for selling online subscriptions, and print ads make much more money than online ads.
