This is not easy for newspaper companies because running both print and online editions is expensive. But print still helps newspapers stay well-known, while online, it is harder to get noticed.

**Photographing People**

People are very interesting to photograph. A picture with a person in it is usually more interesting than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be hard. Besides thinking about the camera settings and artistic style, the photographer must pay attention to people's actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**

When taking group photos, avoid having people stand in straight lines. Ask them to stand at different angles and distances, or on different levels. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so that all faces are visible, or you can take the photo from a higher position.

**B. Posing for Pictures**

People often don't act naturally in front of a camera. They might become stiff and unnatural. Help them relax by suggesting they find a comfortable position, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**

Don't pretend you are not taking a picture when you clearly are, as this can make people uncomfortable. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, even if they protest a little at first. They might feel self-conscious, so you may need to guide them. A picture can be ruined if the person is looking away without focus.

**D. Eye Contact**

A photo is more powerful if the person looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the camera lens. They don't have to smile, but this creates a strong effect. They might not be able to do this for long, so remind them just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a natural reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**

Instead of direct eye contact, the person can focus on something in the picture. This might be easier for them, and the viewer can see what they are looking at. Candid shots, where the person doesn't know they are being photographed, can be very interesting. The expression is important in these photos.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about the person in the photo. A laughing child makes the viewer smile, while a sad face makes the viewer feel sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, or thumbs-up. These are a universal visual language.

**G. Situation Interest**

Photos that show a person with their background can be very interesting. The background can give more information about the person. Make sure the background doesn't distract from the person. You can blur the background or use a wide-angle lens to make the person stand out.

**H. Interaction**

When two or more people are interacting, there are great opportunities for photos. Couples, mothers and babies, or teams working together make good pictures. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Capture how one person reacts to another with expressions or gestures.

**I. People and Places**

Many photos of people are taken on holidays or trips to show where they visited. To take a good picture, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the whole scene. Ask people to stand close to the camera so they are in the foreground without blocking the background. A slightly higher camera position can help. A good photo balances the people and the place.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone you met briefly, ask them to pose with a nice background. Family photos can be boring if they are all posed. Candid photos of events are more lively. A spontaneous picture can bring back memories better than a posed one.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is an artist who creates trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. Joanna Watt interviews her in this article.

Sarah Janson is different from many artists because she doesn't sign her work unless someone asks her to. She believes the artwork is more important than the artist. Sarah is very humble and sometimes acts like her paintings create themselves. This makes her a bit shy during interviews. She even feels uncomfortable being photographed for the magazine.

Later, in her living room, which is full of art, Sarah becomes more relaxed and the interview turns fun and interesting. Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she wasn't happy with illustration, so she joined a decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to try trompe-l'oeil, and she loved it. She decided to start her own business, feeling she was on the right path.

Sarah's skills in observing and focusing on details, learned from illustrating, are very important for trompe-l'oeil. She says you can't really be taught trompe-l'oeil; it's about observing life. She believes she is still learning and says that if you think you know everything, it's time to stop. Sarah is honest about her weaknesses, like not being able to paint bread well, and she struggles with math. When she had to paint a big ceiling at Lulworth Castle, she found the measurements confusing and doubted herself.

Sarah often talks about her work as if someone else did it. Her trompe-l'oeil paintings are very special and better than many others who try this art. She has done many important projects for companies and private clients. Her work is often inspired by architecture. For example, she painted a dining room to look like a Venetian palace and a corridor that seems to lead to more rooms.

Trompe-l'oeil can lose its charm once people understand the trick, so Sarah makes sure her work keeps people interested and sparks their imagination. She believes the art should be personal to the client. Sarah enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. She listens to their wishes and tries to understand their imagination. Many clients become her friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.

Sarah appreciates her clients and is thankful for those who trust her with their walls. They are happy with her work, which keeps her busy, even though she doesn't like to boast about her talent. She says, "I don't like to shout about myself," and believes her work should be quiet and not loud. But her work is so good that it deserves more attention, even if she doesn't want to brag about it.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

**A** The way we are judged at work is changing. It's not just about how smart we are or our training, but also how we handle ourselves and others. This new way of judging is important for deciding who gets hired or promoted. It helps predict who will do well and who might not. These skills are important for future jobs too. They are not about doing well in exams. Instead, they focus on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness. These are called emotional intelligence.

**B** Today, job security is not guaranteed, so personal qualities are important at work. These qualities have been called different names like 'character' and 'soft skills'. Now, they are known as 'emotional intelligence'. This means being able to understand and manage your own and others' feelings. It includes self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. Emotional intelligence is not just about being nice. Sometimes it means telling someone the hard truth. It also means managing feelings so people can work well together.

**C** Many businesses now see emotional intelligence as important for management. The more complex the job, the more emotional intelligence matters. Some people succeed without it, but as work becomes more team-based, companies that have employees with good emotional intelligence do better. In today's workplace, teamwork and customer focus are important, and emotional intelligence is essential for success everywhere.

**D** Unlike IQ, which doesn't change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. Studies show that people get better at handling emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others as they get older. This growth is called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned, and we can add these skills to help us succeed. This is important when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for all problems, but ignoring it can make things harder.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to take pictures of important events. Social media has changed how people share these photos. Now, news often appears first on social networks, and some journalists use these images when events happen quickly. Unfortunately, some reporters have used these photos without asking for permission. There is a rule that says images on social media can be used without permission if there is a very good reason or if it is important for the public. However, people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take a photo or video of a news event. This means that user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. But, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure people are paid for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

**Acupuncture's Origins and Use**  
Acupuncture is a part of ancient Chinese medicine and is about 2,000 years old. It includes other practices like using herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is mainly known in the West for helping with pain. Some doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists use it to help people feel less pain.

**How Acupuncture Works**  
In traditional Chinese medicine, being healthy means your mind, body, and spirit are balanced. Energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), moves through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians connected to organs, and many smaller ones that carry Qi to every cell. If Qi is blocked or weak, you might feel sick or weak. An acupuncturist checks your wrist pulses, looks at your tongue, and asks about your health and habits to find where Qi is unbalanced. They use thin needles on the skin and sometimes add warmth or pressure to help Qi flow better.

**Acupuncture Points**  
There are over 300 main points on the meridians used in acupuncture. The points might not be near where you feel pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This feeling means the needle has reached the Qi. Needles can be moved by hand or with a machine.

**Scientific Views on Acupuncture**  
Even without believing in traditional Chinese ideas, some doctors agree acupuncture can help with pain. They think it might work by blocking pain signals to the brain or by releasing natural painkillers in the body.

**Types of Pain Treated**  
People with long-term pain often try acupuncture. It is used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also treat menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in very sick people.

**Modern Use of Acupuncture**  
Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, but using it instead of anesthesia in surgery started in the 1950s. This showed some doctors outside China that acupuncture could be more than just a mental effect. In China, it is used in many surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia, like feeling sick.

**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**  
It is hard to test acupuncture in clinical trials, but some show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with long-term pain. Acupuncturists say it usually takes six or seven visits to feel real relief, but some improvement should be felt after two or three visits.

**Different Views on Pain**  
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just symptoms. They spend time finding out what might be causing the pain, like if it is worse in cold or damp weather. This helps decide how to treat the pain with acupuncture.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**  
Some medical professionals are trained in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe their methods can lead to longer-lasting cures. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist who will refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very confident, like she could be the head of a girls' school, but she is actually quite shy. She says that Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is a bit like how she would be if she were a man. Both she and Dalgliesh like to work alone. She needs privacy to write and can do it anywhere as long as she is alone.

P.D. James is very humble and doesn't agree when people say she is Britain's most famous crime writer, even though millions of people read her 12 detective novels. She enjoys reading books by her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. She also likes books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also reads male authors like Graham Greene.

P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge, where she met her husband, Connor Bantry White. Life was difficult because her husband came back from World War II very sick. She had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped by taking care of the children.

She worked in administration for the National Health Service and later at the Home Office in the Police Department and Criminal Law section. While working in forensic science, she got used to seeing dead bodies, but it was the challenge of writing a crime novel that interested her, not death itself. She always wanted to be a writer and liked detective stories. Writing them was a way to learn how to be a serious novelist. She believes that solving a crime in a story brings order and shows the importance of life, even if the person who died was not well-liked. She says nobody really likes violence.

Text: 'The pen is mightier than the psychoanalyst The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting could help decide if you are right for the job. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is seen as a real science in many places. Researchers say it can help show certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and can reveal psychological and emotional issues. Handwriting analysis is being used more for career guidance and during job interviews. Many big companies now hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of people applying for important jobs. However, most doctors and psychiatrists are not sure about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, who has been a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says: 'Handwriting can show social class and intelligence. But more than that, it can help assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a tricky or honest character.' According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be useful in spotting possible criminal tendencies: 'Criminals often have messy handwriting, mostly poorly-shaped. Many criminals come from difficult backgrounds and have stopped developing emotionally. This often shows in very childish handwriting and in writing over letters several times. The person behind the handwriting: examples analyzed by graphologist Patricia Marne. 'I can tell if people are honest, manipulative, or reliable workers.' 'Young male offenders often have very high letters, showing they live in a world of fantasy and dream of success. Graphologists can tell if violence is about to happen, if the writer is under a lot of pressure, and if there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can be used to predict possible suicides.' Heart and lung problems can also appear, she says. 'You can't make a diagnosis from one sample, unless the writing is clearly shaky or disturbed. But if over time it changes or becomes broken, if there's a break in the signature that wasn't there before, that could be a sign of something serious.' A big emotional upset can also show in a temporarily changed signature, she says. Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. People whose letters form 'threads' instead of being separate are, apparently, tricky and clever. Those who write mainly in capital letters are trying to hide their true selves. Very light pressure shows sensitivity and low energy. Originality in handwriting - how much the writer has changed from standard script - shows confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is a sign of a loner. Very small signatures show inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a call for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word is a sign of intolerance and a patronizing attitude. Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, and this needs to be combined with empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. This will happen soon, she believes. 'It's actually more accurate than psychoanalysis, as you can tell the whole history of the person, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions they might answer incorrectly.' Interesting as this may sound, there is little solid evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical of them. They say handwriting is a result of education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught - and has no other meaning.'

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy, healthy team, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions. Office A. Advertising Agency Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, and windows open directly to the street. It is hard to see why this space works, but the people, who are part of a small, active team, seem to have few complaints. They adjust to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, much like they do at home. This might be the key: a team of seven people have created a happy, home-like work environment without any outside rules. Ergonomist: The furniture here is mixed; no two pieces are the same. Much of it causes bad working positions. Chairs are old, most can't be adjusted, and many are broken. Even though this is not good, the staff have a varied work schedule, which they control -- office work, meeting clients, making presentations, and so on. This variety helps reduce tiredness, boredom, and muscle problems. Occupational Psychologist: Staff are happy with the variety of work and the flexible office space. They said their office was 'just the right size' -- small enough to know what colleagues are doing, large enough to be alone and focus on personal work. I found the office attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity. Office B. News Service Building Health Consultant: While the office may not be very exciting, it seems comfortable and the staff do not dislike it. The air quality and general maintenance are good. This is helped by a No Smoking policy. Ergonomist: I was not surprised to learn that the company had already hired an ergonomist. Chairs are excellent, lighting and computer equipment are good. Space is good, although the layout could be better. But the environment is impersonal and not stimulating, with grey, bare walls. Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for at least five years and relationships are okay. The office could be better if desks were arranged to make sharing information easier. Success stories or information on future projects could be displayed on the walls. Office C. Bank Building Health Consultant: An office that gets mixed reactions from those working in it. It feels like being in a glass case, looking at and being looked at by many similar cases. Despite a mix of smokers and non-smokers in a small space, the air did not seem stale. Even standing only 1.5 meters from a smoker, it was not possible to smell the cigarette. Ergonomist: The office area is, unfortunately, very standard and not inspiring. The desks are just okay. Not all chairs used for computer work meet requirements, but this is the user's choice. Computer screens are often on small desk units with lowered keyboard shelves; this is not suitable for modern equipment. Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and are well served by technology. Many communication awards are on display. The wood-colored panels and brown carpet give a slightly serious effect. The office is busy with activity. Office D. Newspaper Building Health Consultant: It is hard to say anything good about this building. The air-conditioning control is very basic, causing big temperature changes. The space is cluttered and most people have too little desk space. The office is very dusty -- there are many places for dust to collect. The shed-type roof also collects dust, which, if disturbed, falls on those sitting below. Ergonomist: The furniture looks more suitable for a carpentry workshop than a high-tech industry. Most chairs are not good for keyboard users, especially those shorter than about 1.75 m. Many chairs are old, lack proper adjustment, and have armrests that stop the user from getting close to the desk. Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust, and dirt everywhere. A lot of room for improvement -- the place needs a good clean-up, individual success could be more recognized, air conditioning needs to be improved immediately -- there are many smokers. Few conversations were happening when we visited; everyone seemed stressed and driven by deadlines. The company needs to adopt a team-working policy.'

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular and people in America chew 12 million pieces every day. Let's see how this old habit became a big business. Each piece of gum has less than ten calories, but it is still considered food. This means it must follow the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration. 

Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and improve the texture. But it wasn't always like this. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, which grows in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. 

In America, colonists learned from the Amero-Indians in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States could buy lumps of spruce resin to chew, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, growing sapodilla trees commercially has not worked well. As the gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were needed.

Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a tough and dangerous job. They walk long distances in very humid conditions to collect sapodilla. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicle fly is especially bad because it lays eggs in the tappers' ears and nose. Despite these risks, chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap. They carry the liquid to a camp where it is boiled and made into bricks. Life at the camp is hard, with a simple diet of maize and local alcohol.

Even though their work is difficult, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. The U.S. used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle a year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use synthetic materials to save money and meet demand.

Gum producers are also finding new ways to market their products. They claim gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces tension. Soldiers in both world wars were given gum. The biggest claim is that gum reduces tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms and causes decay. Our saliva helps fight this by neutralizing the acid and providing minerals like calcium, phosphate, and fluoride. Gum makers say chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.

Research continues on new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are used to mix the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural help. Also, 137 square kilometers of America is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**

**A. INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The hotel combines the calm of an English country house with Indian style. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel is simple, with hot water brought in buckets, but this simplicity makes it special.

**B. NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by accident while climbing. We climbed a glacier and walked down to find this hotel. It is in a beautiful, wild area. After a tiring climb, it was amazing to find such luxury, with someone playing piano music.

**C. MAURITIUS - BEACHCOMBER PARADIS HOTEL**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in south-west Mauritius. The road to the hotel passes empty beaches. The hotel is not small, and many people enjoy the free watersports. However, you can find peace on the nine kilometers of private beach. In the evening, when everyone leaves, you can sit on the beach and feel far away from everything.

**D. ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning location. It is quiet and away from busy areas, 1,000 feet above sea level. The open rooms have views of the Pitons and the Caribbean Sea. The hotel has a colonial style with wooden furniture and four-poster beds with netting.

**E. TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a peaceful escape from Istanbul. The islands are an hour away by boat and have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages. The Splendid Hotel is a wooden building painted white with red domes. It is a bit old now but still charming.

**F. FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, is a beautiful 17th-century chateau. It has a moat with swans and 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds. There are special weekend offers with breakfast, dinner, and champagne.

**G. KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel in Nairobi is a comfortable place without too much luxury. It is a popular stop for travelers between safaris. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens and rooms. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to watch the sunset and enjoy a good dinner.

**H. ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido in Portofino was first visited by the Duke of Windsor. Many famous people have stayed here, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might meet wealthy business people. The hotel, once a monastery, is still very elegant. The restaurant serves simple, delicious food, and the hotel has beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Text: 'The Hotel Inspector Sue Brown checks hotels for her job. Christopher Middleton watched her work. Just one minute into her yearly check, things are already going wrong for the Globe Hotel. The receptionist is telling room prices over the phone to someone who might stay at the hotel. She doesn't know that the real guest she is ignoring is Sue Brown. 'She hasn't even noticed us,' Sue whispers. 'Very poor.' This is a common mistake Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. 'But this isn't a normal three-star hotel,' she says. 'It has three red stars, and I expect better.' Having red stars means the Globe is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide from the organization she works for. Even before the cold welcome, there was a problem. The way from the car park was through an empty door with a buzzer, then a long, empty hallway to the hotel entrance. 'Not what I expected,' says Sue. Could it get worse? Yes. 'We don't have your booking,' says the receptionist in a friendly voice. That night, 12 of the hotel's 15 rooms are empty. One room is on the top floor. Sue doesn't like it: it's stuffy, and there's a big hole in the wall behind a wardrobe panel. When she started her job, she was known for being tough. 'They called me The Woman in Black,' she remembers, 'which was funny because I never wore black. And I was never too tough.' The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the Globe's manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He looks scared. Before she says more, he apologizes for the bad smell in the main lounge. 'We think there's a blocked drain,' he says. 'We might have to take up the whole floor.' Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that room. 'Better to take them to the other lounge,' she says. Greaves nods and takes notes. He has been at the Globe for only five months, and he tries to believe Sue when she says her feedback will help the hotel in the long run. It's not all bad news. She praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, who shared notes about the building's 400-year history. Dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating, so Greaves asks, 'What do we need to do to get three rosettes?' Sue suggests, 'Don't serve a pudding that falls apart.' The hope in Greaves' eyes fades. Sue Brown's job is to say the complaints that other guests are too scared to say. 'Sometimes it's very sensitive. Once, a woman called to say I got her son fired. I just told the truth, that he served me apple pie with his fingers.' She often gets letters accusing her of being rude or asking for bribes. 'You get used to it, but it still hurts,' she says. Sue has to tell the hotel her findings and also send a full written report. The hotels pay to be in the guide. Being chosen for red-star treatment is worth it. Greaves is happy to hear that Sue won't suggest taking away the Globe's red stars. That's the good news. The bad news is that another inspector will come back in the next two months to check if everything is fixed. 'Good,' smiles Greaves, not very convincingly. 'We'll look forward to that.''

**Seven Up: Climbing the Seven Summits**

Mountaineer Doug Scott shares his experience of climbing the highest mountain on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He started this challenge later in life and describes his journey for each mountain.

**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**
Doug and his partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave near the top of Mt. Everest. Dougal started talking about sleeping bags, even though only Doug was there. Doug thought this was due to lack of oxygen. He was worried about frostbite but felt confident with Dougal. They reached the summit by finding a good climbing rhythm.

**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**
In April 1976, Doug and Dougal climbed Mt. McKinley, known for being dangerous. They carried all their gear on their backs, a first for a new route. The climb was tough, with cold and low air pressure making it feel higher than it was. They reached the summit and felt triumphant.

**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**
In September 1976, Doug and Paul Braithwaite planned to climb Mt. Kenya but ended up on Kilimanjaro. They got lost in the jungle and struggled to find water. They followed a trail of rubbish to a water source. After a difficult start, they chose a safer route and reached the summit.

**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, climbed Aconcagua. They met a guide who suggested a less crowded route. Due to time limits, they skipped the Polish Glacier and took the standard path. They reached the summit before dark. Meeting other climbers inspired Doug to consider climbing all Seven Summits.

**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**
In November 1992, Doug's team traveled to Antarctica. The sun was always up, and the air was refreshing. Despite strong winds and freezing temperatures, they reached the summit in 8 hours. The storm limited their view, but they were happy to succeed.

**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**
In summer 1994, Doug's team climbed Elbrus. After some acclimatization, they took a cableway to 3,900m and walked to a refuge. They faced strong winds and icy slopes. They thought they reached the summit but had to continue further. They returned to the refuge as night fell.

**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**
Doug's team aimed to find a new route and spend time with the local Dani people. Despite warnings of danger, they started climbing on May 12. The weather improved, and they reached the summit by 11 am. This was Doug's seventh summit, completing his mission.

**Style Merchants**

Style is important in our lives today, from clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley talks about the fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**

Ned Ingham creates beautiful, romantic wedding dresses. He suggests choosing simpler styles instead of traditional, stiff, or frilly dresses. Ingham started drawing and designing wedding dresses when he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. Besides wedding dresses, he also designs long evening dresses with modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a navy-blue suit, a staple in English women's wardrobes, but with a fresh look.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**

Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer and has no formal training in jewelry. She started designing jewelry when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Many famous people now seek her jewelry. Her style includes large semi-precious stones set in gold, inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she started using diamonds. At 36, she says, "I reached that moment in every woman's life when she wants a diamond."

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**

Lily Grimson entered the competitive fashion world four years ago with only a basic art and design course. Two of her handbags were chosen for a major design exhibition. Her bags, made in the UK, are always noticed. They are glamorous, made from fine calfskin or heavy silk. A mix of style and care makes a Grimson bag special.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**

For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He says most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His goal is to make sure clients don't look like they just left a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first visit, with a three-month waiting list. Peter also sells his own hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**

Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and is a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain. She also gives floral ideas to top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her simple yet modern flower arrangements have won many design awards. She has started her own London Flower School and has given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. She advises keeping flower arrangements simple and strong, with few leaves. For wedding bouquets, she says the flowers should be of the same type.

**Five-star Luxury with Modern Technology**

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four big old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is very happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can save guest preferences.

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little themselves, or the front desk can adjust it more. Business guests will like the technology in their rooms. MacCann thinks 65% of the hotel's business will come from business travelers. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing tool. The hotel has prepared for future technology changes by adding extra cables. TVs are rented, so they can be updated easily. DVD players can also be upgraded when needed.

Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food must be excellent, as in all luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He got to design a new, modern kitchen and has better parking. The hotel benefits by having a popular restaurant without financial risk. With great technology and skilled staff, the Merrion is likely to do well.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. She gets many of her ideas from the big garden around her house. This garden has many of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The garden has a nice mix of colors, shapes, and structures, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left plants that Susan likes, and she also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny didn't agree with some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants rather than the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She says, "I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then I add another one." Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." She also enjoys watching how flowers change over time. For example, tulips change shape when you put them in water. At first, they look boring, but then they open up and look amazing.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then because she thought they looked fake, like the ones made of silk or plastic. She was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks. Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit well in her garden. She lets the garden grow naturally, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.

Susan is busy with two upcoming exhibitions and has a lot of flowers to paint. She finds it hard to find time to work in the garden, so she hired another gardener. But she knows that to stay connected with her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Many trees in the Brackham area fell during the big storms in March. The town lost two important lime trees from the old market square. This change made the town center look different, which upset some of the older residents. Normally, Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police, would have been upset too. But during the storm, when the wind knocked down the walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. He was a strong and healthy man, but he got very sick with bronchitis for the first time in his life. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to get him to see a doctor. Pelham thought the police needed him, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forget things and become easily angry. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, he was getting his medicine from the pharmacy and going home to his wife, who sent him straight to bed. On Thursday morning, when Molly told him the walnut tree had fallen, Pelham couldn't understand it. On Thursday evening, he asked if the house was damaged, felt relieved when it wasn't, and went back to sleep. On Saturday, when the medicine started working and he felt better, he realized the walnut tree was gone and the living room looked different. The Pelhams' big house had a large garden, which made it feel private. Pelham didn't regret buying it, even though it was expensive. The garden used to have a beautiful walnut tree that made nice patterns of light and shade, hiding the old furniture they brought from their last house. Without the tree, the room was very bright, and the old furniture looked shabby. The view from the window was now of the tall house next door, which was not nice to look at. It had ugly purple bricks and pipes, and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams. 'Doesn't it look terrible?' Pelham said to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed happy. 'I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.'

Living in the Valley

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first understood the dangers in the hills around us. These dangers could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the nearby hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden strong winds; trees moved, but the branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were inconvenient, but they did not trouble us much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, that worried us the most. It reminded us of what could have happened if the water from the hills had not been controlled by dams many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. Grey clouds spread over the valleys. They twisted and turned, moving east and up, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was becoming fuller and wilder every day. The snow was slowly washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and getting close to a dangerous level. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like Niagara Falls, as water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the water rushed down to its lower parts. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was wild under the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it near our home, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held and the waters began to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river often flooded the nearby villages in a similar way. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only small overflows. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this, we feel our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Film Critic Mark Adams talks about his last ten years working as a film critic for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing about films for The Front Page was my first real job. Before that, I did some reviews for novels, films, and radio. That's how I met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page. He also wrote for radio and TV. He hired me, but Tom wasn't mainly a journalist, or he would have been more careful in choosing his team. 

At first, Tom wanted a team of critics to cover art forms that didn't need special knowledge: books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. We would have a weekly lunch to choose what to review, and there would be guests to make it fun. It felt like a dream: a new newspaper, and I was part of the team. It seemed unlikely that a new paper could succeed in a crowded market. It felt like a millionaire wanted to help me personally and was pretending to hire me. I didn't have much confidence. The first time I saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground and turning to my review, I didn't know where to look.

Tom's idea for a team of critics never worked out. It was a good idea, but we didn't meet as planned, so we did everything by phone. People preferred to link a reviewer with one subject, so I chose film. Without Tom's push, we wouldn't have the current setup, where I write a long weekly piece, usually on one film. This way of working suits me well. I wouldn't like the usual film critic's job, which means reviewing every film that comes out. That would make me bored quickly. I would soon be sitting in my seat on a Monday morning, thinking, 'What boring film must I watch now?' - a feeling common in screening rooms worldwide.

The space I have lets me expand my argument or, in a dull week, make something interesting. But what is my role in public? I think people choose films based on stars, publicity, or the director. People are loyal to certain types of films or the opposite. It's rare for someone who hates westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romance fan to avoid a romantic film because of reviews. So if a film review isn't really a guide for choosing films, what is it? I don't feel I have to be 'right' about a movie. I don't think there should be a set number of 'great' and 'bad' films each year. I just need to present an argument. I'm not a judge, and I don't want to be.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because she thinks it's fun. A teenager who loves endurance sports is looking for a training partner. The partner should be a sports enthusiast, preferably female, and interested in distance running, swimming, and cycling. The triathlon is becoming a very popular Olympic sport. Many people are amazed by athletes who swim, cycle, and run long distances without stopping. But why do these athletes push their bodies so hard? And why would a smart 17-year-old girl give up everything for this tough sport?

Melanie Sears, a young triathlete, hasn't learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that athletes often use. She says, "You swim for 1500 meters, then jump on your bike while still wet. You get cold, and after cycling 40 kilometers, you have to run 10 kilometers. It's exhausting, but it's great fun and worth it in the end."

Melanie did her first triathlon at 14 and won the junior section, but she was the only junior competing. She felt confident and entered the National Championships. Even though she was fast in swimming and running, she didn't win because she got lost during the cycling part and went 20 kilometers too far. She cried during the run but didn't give up and is determined to keep going.

Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director, admires her determination. He says she worked so hard on a running machine that it threw her off. Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She is working hard to improve her cycling.

Her parents are supporting her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships, which costs a lot. She also wants a new bike to compete in more races. Her intense training means she doesn't have much of a social life. She says, "I'm not a party person. After hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I keep in touch with my teammates."

Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which is shorter. She wants to try even tougher events. She says, "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with." It's interesting, isn't it?

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy talks about her love for collecting things and why many people enjoy this hobby. Collecting is a popular activity, with one in three adults doing it. It is a world full of passion and excitement. But if you want to start collecting, remember: only collect things you truly love.

People have been collecting since ancient times. Early humans collected pebbles because they liked their shapes and colors. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for the same reasons.

I have been collecting all my life, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote part of England. My parents took me to a local museum full of interesting objects, which fascinated me.

Many people share my interest in collecting. For some, it is the only part of their lives they can fully control. For me, it's just something I enjoy.

A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France, who had a 'room of wonders' with items like coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. But you don't need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great determination. I once convinced another tulip collector to give me a tulip I wanted, but it was later stolen by another collector.

I also collected 350 American rag dolls, searching all over the USA for different designs. Sadly, this collection was destroyed in a house fire. The next day, I saw the remains of my furniture and collection, and I wasn't sure which loss was worse.

I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or poet becomes valuable. As small objects become popular, their prices go up. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable, especially if you kept the original boxes. Unfortunately, I threw away both the boxes and the toys.

**My Job: Four People Talk About Their Work**

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. First, I learn about the exhibition topic and talk to experts to decide the main themes and goals. I choose what objects and pictures to show. I make sure visitors understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to ensure everything is safe. Before the exhibition opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start my day at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I prepare new maps and documents for students to learn the routes needed for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are at school, figuring out the best routes using the correct streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. When students are close to the test, I challenge them by asking for different routes, even if the road is closed, to make them think.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and work from home. My job includes answering phone calls, creating educational materials, and setting up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but mostly I am by the sea. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for people who manage the coast. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand marine life better. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. However, since I work for a charity, we always need more money, so I can't do everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is varied. I make sure our publishing program meets market needs and keep stocks of about 300 books we publish. We have high standards for information and content. We get many letters from readers about things like international boundaries, which need careful replies. I talk about future projects and current sales with co-publishers. I work with an enthusiastic team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is there is too much administration, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

Text: 'Our Holiday in Ireland We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, bought the house and made some changes, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. 'How about this?' he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school because Dekko Deacon sounds nice. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We're all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We think it's quite a coincidence. 'How very nice,' Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she's usually waiting in the big hall that always smells of flowers. 'Arthur, take the luggage up,' she told the old porter. 'Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium.' These are the names of the rooms for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of details like that, and her husband does the redecoration and repairs. 'Well, well, well,' Mr. Malseed said, coming into the hall from the kitchen. 'A hundred thousand welcomes,' he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt that our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn, everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. 'You look younger every year, all four of you,' she said, making everyone laugh. Arthur led us to the rooms, carrying as much of our luggage as he could and then coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others taking the path down to the seashore. In the morning, we'd do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then come back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we'd drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we developed this routine. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.'

Title: Keeping the Holiday-Makers Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex, works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. This is her second year doing this job. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University and graduated last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. 'It's a good way to meet successful people,' she says.

Sarah does not live at the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing breakfast for the guests. 'They get everything - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is 'the worst part of the job.' By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She tries to ski as much as she can. 'On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.'

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting, but she does not nap. 'It's a bad idea if you do,' she says. Dinner, which has three courses, is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans up after dinner and loads the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she chats with the guests, and other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks don't go as well.'

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. 'We usually start at Bananas, might go to G Jay's, and maybe end at Dick's T-Bar,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'A terrible day,' she says, 'when you don't want to cook breakfast with a bad headache.' Work starts earlier on Sunday because breakfast for departing guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. 'We clean everything - clear breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't done the week's shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. 'They arrive around 4:30 p.m.' Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. 'I'm sure it's the mountain air that affects them.'

Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes guests who need boots or skis to the ski shop and gets a ride back to the chalet from the ski shop staff. Soon, it's time for dinner again, and maybe a drink later, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early,' she says.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale-skinned girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie. However, she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by curly hair. She was so small and young-looking that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.

A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions on the phone or giving a short tour if he thought they were serious. Rita Cohen was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class. Years ago, these children visited the factory to see how gloves were made. Marie's favorite part was the laying-off table, where workers shaped and pressed each glove over steam-heated brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table. Marie called them the 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.

Rita asked Seymour, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" He replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She kept taking notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, "They come to the tannery. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" Rita said, "Not yet." Seymour offered, "You should visit a tannery if you're going to write about leather. I can arrange that for you. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but it's not very different from hundreds of years ago. It's hard work. Tanning is said to be the oldest industry, with remains found in Turkey from six thousand years ago. The first clothes were just skins tanned by smoking them. It's an interesting subject once you get into it. My father is the leather expert; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for two days. Glovemen love the trade. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" Rita replied, "I can't say I have." Seymour laughed when she said, "I saw my mother make a cake when I was a child." He found her eager to learn and full of spirit. She reminded him of Marie, who was always full of what she learned in school. Seymour decided, "I'll show you the whole process. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you'll watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is it a Dream Job? Chris Arnot asks four people if their dream jobs are as great as they seem.**

**A. Raquel Graham**

Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet me tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But there's one small problem - she doesn't like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down," she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she's not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring paperwork, like organizing the diary, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning schedules, and making more travel plans. She didn't apply for the job. She met a pop group's manager by chance, which led to a job offer. She took a secretarial course at night school at the same time. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a PA.

**B. David Brown**

David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. He liked being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there were some downsides. Caddies get a small fixed fee and a percentage of the golfer's winnings. They usually earn between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes on travel and hotels. He was 31 when he first worked for the golfer Greg Norman. "You're not just carrying bags. You're giving advice, using your knowledge against the weather, and trying to understand the golf course." His skills in accounting were noticed by European Tour Productions, and they made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies' scorecards. These results are wanted by TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers themselves.

**C. Martin Fern**

Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' pages of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to try food at the best restaurants. What does he think about restaurants that charge very high prices? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I'd rather spend £120 on a meal I'll remember forever than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a food column offer from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. For Martin, who was then a creative director at an advertising agency, it was a good extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in guaranteed income," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a profession." He still cooks at home and tries to keep fit by cycling a few miles to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**

"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed using them, but I mostly wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about the problem of chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's story." Where do his ideas come from? "Well, it's not easy, I have to work at them," he says. "That's what I usually do in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing out the morning's notes - all of which I do with one finger on an old portable typewriter instead of a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that's the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some secretarial help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, where trees were made into boards for building, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it were big piles of soft sawdust. These piles looked like golden mountains and covered the yard down to the blue lake. That afternoon, with nothing else to do, all the boys followed Michael up a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed on the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards," he said, trying to get them to jump too. Laughing, he watched them look down from the roof, scared, but then one by one, they jumped and got up smiling with relief. In the hot afternoon sun, they lay on the sawdust pile, telling jokes. Then one of the boys said, "Let's go up on the roof again and jump down." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and started jumping off again until only Michael was left. The others were below, smiling and calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to jump and join them, but he stayed on the edge of the roof, nervous and smiling awkwardly, wondering why it seemed like a longer drop this time. At first, they thought he was joking, but then they saw him clenching his fists. He tried to count to ten and jump, and when that didn't work, he tried to take a deep breath and close his eyes. After a while, the boys started laughing at him; they were tired of waiting, and it was almost dinnertime. "Come on, you're a coward. Do you think we'll stay here all night?" they shouted, and when he didn't move, they started to leave, still shouting. "Who started this? What's wrong with you all?" he called. But he stayed on the roof, looking sadly at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour while the sun, like a big orange ball, slowly set beyond the lake. His clothes were wet from sweating nervously. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, fell heavily on the sawdust, and lay there for a long time. There were no sounds in the yard; the workers had gone home. As he lay there, he wondered why he couldn't jump earlier, then got up slowly and walked home, feeling very ashamed and wanting to avoid everyone. He was so late for dinner that his stepmother said coldly, "You're old enough to get home on time for dinner. If you won't come home, you should stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke with controlled seriousness, but Michael, with his dark, sad face, hardly heard her; he was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy with your job but unsure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change jobs are now turning to careers advisers. You will need to write a short history about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. These tests help advisers suggest new careers and any retraining you might need.

I decided to try Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school exams. I was with about ten other people, answering questions quickly. It was important to remember that it wasn't about passing or failing. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes. After the tests, I talked with an adviser who gave me a report with his thoughts and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, although I was a bit upset to learn I didn't do well in the scientific and technical tests. It's probably good that I never became a nurse! But I was happy to hear that journalism was a good choice for me.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager at an insurance company. Her friends suggested she visit Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to think about my career and my skills,' says Donna. Some results surprised her. 'I didn't know I was good at design. But I had to think about the cost of retraining in design,' she says. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. 'I decided to use my current skills and move to a job better suited for me than insurance. Now, I work as a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped me see clearly what I wanted to do. I've recommended them to friends who are also happy with the service.'

Some people feel they couldn't have made changes without help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services and made big life decisions. 'After working at a bank for six years, I found my job boring and wanted a new challenge. I didn't know what to do, so I went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed I was interested in sciences,' she says. 'I had four sessions with an adviser. The third session was recorded, which was helpful because you forget things you say. After the fourth meeting, I decided to study geology and plan to start a degree course this year. The advice was worth the cost. I'm much happier and more positive now.'

However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, says: 'I didn't know where to go in my career. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. Although I got many new ideas, I rejected them because they required a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn't learn anything new about myself,' she says. 'You have to give the adviser a lot of personal information, and I felt that a friend could have given me similar advice.'

Title: 'A Fun Visit to the Dentist?'

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit for their check-ups. Jerome says, "Half of the people only go to the dentist when they are in pain, not for regular check-ups. This is because they are scared." To change this, he has made his office a place where people feel comfortable. He doesn't wear a white coat because he thinks it makes people think of pain. Jerome believes dental visits should be relaxing and even enjoyable.

This is surprising for many people who think of dental visits as painful or very formal. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed and entertained, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ideas is using virtual-reality headsets. His office was the first in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater wildlife while Jerome checks their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth. Many patients enjoy this part of their visit.

Another important thing is the smell in the office. It smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome says, "When people come in, I want them to know it's not like a regular dentist's office. Smell is important. The usual dental smell can make people nervous." I found the smell very nice.

Even though Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but good treatment is the most important. For example, he uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but it doesn't hurt if you are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about dental techniques. He learned that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for dentists. He thinks this patient-friendly approach will slowly change the traditional British dental profession.

Just then, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he wants to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it's easy to see why. The office feels more like a fancy beauty salon than a regular dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**

Chocolate, which started in South America, is now a big business around the world. At Easter, people in Britain spend over £230 million on chocolate. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought during this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate. 

Large-scale chocolate production began in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and contains 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans due to a spelling mistake from the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in their language, Nahuatl. The Aztecs flavored the drink with spices for ceremonies and to welcome visitors. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread across Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities, where people gathered to drink chocolate.

Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar as we know it started in 1847 when Fry and Sons, a company in Bristol, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. A Swiss company later added milk solids, creating milk chocolate.

At the start of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French style. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, first called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular with clever advertising that linked it to the healthy milk from the English countryside. 

Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. This has made chocolate makers find new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the 'extended line,' where a chocolate bar becomes an ice cream, a soft drink, or a dessert to interest people who want something different.

Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices at the end of the 1980s. Many farmers, who work on a small scale, had to stop their businesses. Maybe you can think of them when you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke is 83 years old and has become very skilled in his art. He still wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he focuses on making beautiful and unique objects from shells, a skill he has perfected over the last ten years.

When showing his work, Peter says, "Tell me if I am boring you." He is not boring at all; he is very enthusiastic and charming. He shows me some shell-covered ornaments above his fireplace and says, "I won't mind if people don't buy them because I love them. I never planned to sell my work. Some friends visited me five years ago and said, 'You should have an exhibition. People need to see these. We'll talk to an art gallery owner.'"

This led to an exhibition in London, where 70% of his pieces were sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The pieces are expensive, around £2,000 for the ornaments, but Peter doesn't mind if his fireplace is empty. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225 for a shell-flower in a crystal vase. Peter says he doesn't set the prices and is happy to talk about them. He believes no one else in the world makes work like his. The gallery owner told him, "One day you will stop, and everyone will want your pieces because there won't be any more."

Peter wishes he had started this work earlier in life. He feels he could have made even more amazing things. Although he still has ideas, he finds it harder to work physically now. However, his work is much better than the usual shell items found in seaside shops. He creates tiny, detailed boxes, pictures, and realistic flower baskets from shells.

Peter has his own way of working. He uses materials he finds, like cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says, "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just does itself," but his work shows careful attention to detail and color.

To find beautiful and tiny shells, Peter has traveled to places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of harming beaches. He says, "When I collect shells, I hear people stepping on them and breaking them faster than I can collect them. I would never take shells with living creatures in them. Once they are empty, why shouldn't I collect them?" His argument is convincing, especially when you see the beauty of his work.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to amazing places and appearing on magazine covers, you can find her studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.
