"I'm sorry, Kira will be a little late," the receptionist at the agency told me. "Oh, that's fine," I said, "no problem." I was trying to forget all the bad things I had read about models, like being difficult, vain, and not smart. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she thought going to the hairdresser was more fun than talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not want to answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and said sorry for being late. She was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes, just a simple black dress and trainers. She didn't seem selfish at all; she was just a very friendly, very tall, very pretty girl. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum, very proud of her successful daughter.

Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense because it was not planned. Her older sister decided she should enter the model competition. "She saw the competition and said I should try it," Kira remembers. "I said no, but she sent some photos in anyway." When she got the call that she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final gave Kira the confidence to go through with it, and she did great. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work right away.

Kira now finds it hard to manage her two separate lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. "They're really proud of me," she says. However, some unkind people at her school are rude about her success. "They say I think too much of myself." This must be hard for Kira because she is not self-important. But she says, "They think that because I've become a model, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I've become more confident—not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. "If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, 'Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us.'"

Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career ahead of her. Not many people can say that before they even finish their school exams. As I finish the interview with the girl who has it all, I ask what she would like to do if she didn't have the beauty that seems sure to make her successful. She pauses and replies, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Start Gold Rush

Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team who have traveled from Canada's cold north to Africa's hot climate to find valuable metals. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They believe their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 and from Liverpool, said, "As we dig, we find a lot of gold; we just need to dig a few more meters to where it is concentrated."

The Maddens have spent their lives looking for gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold worth millions in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the Welsh town of Dolgellau. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to choose the best area to explore. After clearing the land and finding small pieces of gold in the rocks, they spent ten years getting permission to dig, taking earth samples, and removing old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They have used their savings and need to find someone to invest £50,000 to dig a few more meters to reach the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it looks difficult, but we have some people we can ask."

As news spread about their digging, people in the valleys became interested in the gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and locals are hopeful. Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "It would bring more people here if they are right, but if they find gold, I hope not too many people come and dig up the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry has declined since the late 1880s when many people worked in hundreds of mines. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. Hall, who is 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's adventurous and exciting, like finding hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves to explore the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, where she teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemical processes in the sea. When she is not teaching, she goes on dives to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to dive three kilometers down into the ocean. Inside the vehicle, space is very tight, and she can touch the two pilots next to her. They cannot stand up or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly goes to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it might not be a pleasant ride.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who showed her what to do in emergencies, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has done six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes with chimneys blowing out black smoke. The Russian team was putting scientific equipment there to study the effects of a project that would make a hole 150 meters deep through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it so she can continue her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. The water comes out at one meter per second and is 350 degrees hot.

Rachel was only scared once, during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a big explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. They waited in silence, but nothing happened. The relief was incredible—they were still alive!

Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is a big adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the window and sees the chimneys, she feels a sense of wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing things no one else has seen before. After studying the black smokers for three years for her PhD, seeing them in real life was an amazing experience.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind couldn't handle any more foreign timetables, money, or languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. All I needed was one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Once you learn to sleep in a train corridor, regular beds feel different. The train's movement helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply. You might even burn socks that smell too bad or throw away books when you're done with them. This way of thinking fits the Inter-Rail spirit, where you can forget about common sense and just enjoy the freedom. All you need is one of those tickets. This system lets young people travel through many countries quickly, which is special. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't know how great this train ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But the idea of traveling all the time was too exciting. There was always another country to visit, just a bit further away. And it didn't cost us anything extra. We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, like most other Inter-Railers, so we only saw the most obvious sights. We wanted to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that in many places, I only saw the view from the train station. We were there to enjoy ourselves. We were like most other Inter-Railers, sharing train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. It's like the city didn't exist until the train arrived, and you saw it with your own eyes. Only by seeing Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different attitudes and lifestyles can you really understand the continent. Everyone knows what's there, but it doesn't mean much until you see it yourself. That's why other people's holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip won't show you anything new in the world, it's a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail gives people the best chance to see this, though it didn't happen for us right away.

There is nothing more disappointing than arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your baggage is missing. At best, you will have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. At worst, you might be in a different climate, far from home, and have to wear clothes that are not suitable. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it is common for regular travelers to lose their luggage at some point. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes, and no airline can promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes.

Here is how the system works. Airlines ask passengers to check in early to give enough time for baggage to go through the airport and be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times needed to transfer between two flights, and these times are also longer to allow for baggage transfers. Usually, the system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights, which can cause the baggage system to fail. There is also the chance of human error or an accident where the destination label is torn off. These problems can be worse at large transfer airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport handled more than 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with most moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even efficient airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The risk of losing baggage when changing planes is higher at some airports. Even in the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your luggage, choose direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connections by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport, and label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses. Don't forget to include the flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who knows a lot about the kingfisher. The kingfisher is a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. The area where it lives has old trees that hang over the water, creating a mix of soft green, brown, and yellow colors. The kingfisher flies quickly and directly, like a flash of light, and even though it disappears in a second, its image stays in your mind.

Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He can't explain exactly why he loves them so much, but they are part of many legends. In Greek mythology, the kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. Scientifically, kingfishers don't have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, their feathers reflect light in a way that makes them look blue or green, depending on the light.

Many wildlife photographers are excited about kingfishers because of their colors and because they can be watched easily from a hidden spot. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket he used to cover himself while waiting for a kingfisher. The bird came back quickly and sat very close to him. However, it took him four years to take a good picture. During this time, he spent as much time as possible near streams with many kingfishers, even skipping school, which affected his studies.

At 16, Charlie was noticed for his interest in kingfishers and was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant to the editor and then became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make the best kingfisher film, with no talking, just beautiful images. He loves the simple approach and enjoys photographing parts of the kingfisher's wings. Even after spending so much time with kingfishers, he is still fascinated by them. His photos show some of his feelings, but he knows there is more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can show.

**Conducting an Orchestra: Insights from Five New Conductors**

**A. Anne Manson**  
Anne Manson, 30, got a chance to work with famous conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna when she filled in for an absent assistant. She wasn't nervous about leading her first rehearsal because she felt confident in front of an orchestra. Anne, who is from America, works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming well-known in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has helped Abbado with several projects.

**B. Andrew Constantine**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is convincing people to give you opportunities. He won a big competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He believes the timing was perfect because if he had won earlier, he might not have succeeded. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being known only for the competition. He hopes that orchestras, like the English Chamber Orchestra, will continue to invite him back, or else his career might suffer.

**C. Wasfi Kani**  
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice sessions needed for opera productions. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London's business district until Pimlico Opera became fully professional. Learning from conductor Sian Edwards was important for her because Edwards was the same size as her, which made a big difference. Wasfi likes the complexity of opera, including dealing with singers' personalities and disagreements.

**D. Roger Vignoles**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting to be a surprise but very interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's "Agrippina" from the piano at a festival, which was easier than he expected. He knew the music well and tried to achieve the performance he wanted. People respect his musical skills, and he learns from all his experiences. He is open to trying new things to discover what he enjoys.

**E. Wayne Marshall**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, now 32, and recommended him to his agent. Marshall soon had to conduct a musical in London on short notice, which was challenging. He even dealt with musicians who were not paying attention during the show. He was firm with them and always gave clear instructions. Although he never formally studied conducting, he is confident and knows what he likes. People have been supportive, and he is determined to succeed.

**Variations on a Theme**

If you want to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many options. We asked five families to try out some of the best parks.

**Fun Island - The Burns family**

Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. But we were surprised. The park is great for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay longer because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. However, the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan family**

None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We spent six hours there and were happy to find places to rest. The park is beautifully designed, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, including adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with its exciting trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is great for younger kids. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small for it, which was a relief for us! The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member offered to go with one of them.

**The Great Park - The Langridge family**

We arrived at 1 p.m. and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This is a great park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those who are brave. If the kids were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all family**

The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary, according to Ben. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were sometimes great with young kids, but not always friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early!

Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women Share Their Stories

A. Christine Hogan runs a computer-aided design business that makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. She says, "My customers are friends." Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Before she got married, she worked with computers, so her husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. Christine was careful with spending and always informed the bank if she might spend too much. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings if she wants. The business is small, and local customers usually pick up their work.

B. Maggy Sasanow enjoys being independent. She designs greeting cards from home. Maggy studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no such jobs in the countryside where she moved after getting married. So, she started her own business, creating 50 different greeting cards that she sells to museums. She works in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. Her business grows through word of mouth, and she doesn't advertise. People send her work from London because she is cheaper than other artists. Although she misses sharing ideas with others, she finds more advantages than disadvantages in her work.

C. Delia Turner has a curtain-making business that has had ups and downs. She started it eight years ago when this type of business was growing. Her earnings went from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years, and she managed six full-time workers. But she had to let them go because of the economy, which was hard since jobs are scarce in her area. Now, she makes curtains at home with her husband's help and hires women who work from their homes. Delia has to be ready to lower her prices when needed and look for new opportunities.

D. Tessa Strickland runs the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because London was too expensive and she loves the country. Tessa likes working when she wants, but 80% of her income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so she has to take calls at odd hours. The challenge is to have the discipline to stop working. She publishes children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because all her professional experience was in London.

E. Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop, making £250,000 a year and employing six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, interested in health, making fruit cakes with good quality flour and eggs. Friends and family began asking for cakes, and soon she was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made. She has a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg no longer cooks; she manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial part because they didn't have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they are all involved in music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are talented musicians and composers, and their father, John, makes musical instruments. 

When Paul was ten years old, he needed a cello because he was getting very good at playing. But cellos were very expensive. So, John decided to try making one himself. He found a school nearby that taught instrument making and took evening classes for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he made his first cello for Paul. It turned out well, and he made another one later, which Paul used for many years.

John enjoyed making instruments so much that he retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman. He now makes about twelve violins a year. One of his violins was even bought by a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.

Paul and Huw started playing music when they were very young. Paul first played the piano, but soon he wanted to play the cello. His parents wanted him to play the violin, but he liked the cello player in his dad's music group and decided to learn the cello instead. Huw was also encouraged to play music, but he chose the piano and became a composer.

Paul became very successful with his father's cello. He won a big music competition and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra at just 20 years old. Now, he plays a very old and valuable cello, a Francesco Rugeri, which is on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. His father agrees that the new cello sounds very nice, but he believes his own cello will sound better as it gets older.

Paul will soon be on television playing the Rugeri cello in a famous piece, Elgar's Cello Concerto. However, he won't be able to watch it because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will be performed in London for the first time. Their parents, John and Hetty, will have to work hard to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules.

Title: Taking Care of the Countryside

THE NATIONAL TRUST

The National Trust is a group that works to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden for the Trust. 

Gareth says a National Trust Warden needs common sense. He also says you need to be good with people because you work with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people wanted the job of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. Gareth got the job because he knew the area well and had farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. 

Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. He says, "They can't fool me about anything!" His farming background also helps him with the physical work, like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. 

Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and wonders where they are now. He realizes that farming has changed the countryside, but it's not the farmers' fault. They were following government advice. 

When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists didn't agree. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth believes they are close to working together. 

Gareth's job includes conservation, allowing public access to Trust land, planting trees, and meeting with tenant farmers. He makes sure jobs are done well and cheaply. He enjoys seeing projects finished, though he spends a lot of time on paperwork. 

Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He likes talking to the public, but some people annoy him. They act like they own the place and demand things. Gareth says it's important to have common sense. If you have it and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't people look at you strangely?" She said, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra says, "My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships. I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible." This is her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries participating. "We'll have support from people at home, which is very special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Because we are playing here, there will be more pressure. People will expect us to start the tournament with a good game."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of skill." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day, there's no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance, and you have to be ready."

In the fifteen years since she started playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. "You don't do all that training not to win," says Kendra. "But once the final whistle blows, you become a different person. We're all friendlier after the game."

Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. "It's essential that we all think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I think it's important to have a strong mental attitude and lead by example. I see my role as supporting and encouraging the rest of the team."

"From the very beginning, my netball career has always been carefully planned," she says. "I decided some time ago that this competition would be the end of my playing career." She will probably coach young players in the future, but right now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening candlelight ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them grow their talent. Some parents might not notice their child's musical needs until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or science, but musically talented children need special support that regular schools might not offer, especially if music is not a main focus there. 

Children who are very good at music might benefit from going to a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools. These schools are for children aged seven to eighteen and help them improve their musical skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music activities, like lessons on their instruments, playing in orchestras, singing, conducting, and learning music theory. They also practice for several hours each day in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is spent on important school subjects like English, math, science, and languages, but they can also study other subjects if they want.

All five music schools in Britain are private, and they have small classes with many teachers. Most students live at the school, which means they spend a lot of time with other children who have the same interests. 

There are some downsides to these schools. First, they are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for students who live there. However, schools try to help parents with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want their children to live away from home at a young age. School directors are careful about accepting very young children because the environment is intense and disciplined. They want to make sure students become well-rounded individuals.

Being in a special music school can be stressful. Some children might lose interest in music as they grow older, and the pressure to succeed can be hard. But these schools watch each student's progress closely and offer help if needed. Many students say they learned a lot from the music teaching, but some worry that the academic subjects are not given enough attention. Many musically talented children are also smart and want to learn more in school. 

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves if they want to go to a specialist school. Children who are good at both music and academics might do well in a regular school with a strong music program or by taking music lessons at a music college on weekends. However, this might not be possible for families who live far from big cities like London.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house has a big garden with many flowers she loves, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread seeds everywhere. The garden has a nice mix of colors and shapes, thanks to the previous owners who loved gardening. They left plants that Susan likes, and she also kept their gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny didn't agree with some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint detailed pictures of single plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants where they are, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She says, "I don't set everything up at once. I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then I add another one." Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She says, "They all come out together, and you're so busy." She also enjoys watching flowers change as they age. For example, tulips change shape and open up when you put them in water.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She didn't like garden flowers back then because she thought they looked fake. She was amazed by how wildflowers could grow in difficult places like rocks or cliffs. Now, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they fit well in her garden. She lets the garden grow naturally, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause harm.

Susan is preparing for two exhibitions and has many flowers to paint, so she doesn't have much time to work in the garden. She hired another gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her work, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Title: Keeping Holiday Guests Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. Sarah, also known as Pilch, cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets. Chalets are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University and graduated last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it's a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more permanent job. 'It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful people every week,' she says.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. They get a full breakfast with porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After the guests finish breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms, which she says is the hardest part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as she can. 'On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.'

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before starting. She does not take a nap because it makes her too tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans up and loads the dishwasher. 'I don't like coming to a messy kitchen in the morning,' she says. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they prefer to be left alone. 'Good guests can make the week great, but some weeks are not as good,' she says.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. 'We usually start at Bananas, then maybe go to G Jay's, and end at Dick's T-Bar,' she says. But she never stays out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'It's a tough day,' she says, 'and you don't want to cook breakfast when you're tired.'

On Sunday, work starts earlier because breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet quickly. 'We clean everything, clear breakfast, strip the beds, and get everything ready.' If she hasn't done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests. 'They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. I think it's the mountain air,' she says.

Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need boots or skis by taking them to the ski shop. She gets a ride back to the chalet from the ski shop staff. Then it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early,' she says.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing what to wear was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, but here I was rushing around. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I usually clean cages or handle rats. I find magazines interesting, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there."

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in leather boots and dark blue trousers. They gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening show Ground Force. "I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn't know landscape gardening was so hard and needed careful planning. I'm more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't leave my nursing job."

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I would faint, but I was okay. The nurses' friendship is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is less important than nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't pleasant, but it was satisfying."

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different—people respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return flight, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this, but it inspired me to join a gym and be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses into Italy. It passes by some of the most beautiful sea views. It doesn't matter what the weather is like or what time of year it is; it is always charming. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively because there is an interesting mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the amazing journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have enjoyed many train journeys over the years, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which goes across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its big glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am grateful to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how nice it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable - we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days if he knew people were still coming. When the train appeared, hundreds of people climbed into and onto the carriages - some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have favorite train memories from when they are children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old, unused part of the line that volunteers had taken care of. That's where my love for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could, and when I went back last year, it was like time had stopped. Everything was still there, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, has advice for you. Many readers ask, 'I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to research publishers and improve your writing skills. Selling your writing requires knowing a lot about the 'writing world'. No matter what you write, you need to understand the markets you are targeting. The best way to do this is by reading a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading widely helps you see what publishers are accepting. Remember, this knowledge needs updating because new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. 

If you are unsure what to write, start by exploring. For example, if you want to write short love stories, find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and learn what kind of stories they buy and who their readers are. Editors focus on what their readers want. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But often, the work is not ready to be published. Most new writers send their work too soon, before they are ready. If you have only written one story or article, it is unlikely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. 

When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while waiting for a reply. Write ten or even twenty more. Each story will be better, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. Your skills and confidence will grow. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I also suggest not showing your work to others, especially at the beginning. Remember, every successful writer faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. Look for a creative writing course nearby or join a local writers' group. This will help you gain ideas and confidence from other writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was busier than usual. Elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. A well-dressed, grey-haired man was talking to different people. He asked a woman sitting alone if she was going to Philadelphia. Then he asked a girl near me the same question. She said she was going to New York, not Philadelphia. The man thanked her and moved on.

I was curious about him. He asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to Wilmington. He didn't say anything and continued to another couple. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. Maybe I didn't look reliable to him. He seemed stressed and asked a woman reading a book if she was going to Philadelphia. She said yes. He asked her for a favor.

I pretended to check my watch, even though I didn't have one. The woman seemed cautious. The man explained that his daughter was flying abroad from Philadelphia and had forgotten her passport. She called home from the station, unsure of what to do. He told her to stay there, and he would find someone to bring her passport.

The woman listened sympathetically. I wondered why he didn't go himself. He said he couldn't leave his wife alone because she was in a wheelchair. This seemed like a weak excuse to me. I noticed he was holding a padded envelope, not a regular one. It was stapled shut, which made me suspicious. I silently warned the woman to be careful.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his relationship with his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef.

I think everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was just what I wanted. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I was upset because I was left alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife took care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This was very good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life.

Gary was a very active child. When he was about seven, he tried to jump into our corner bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with small jobs, and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had a lot of money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. In a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was excellent in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he had a talent for it. So when he told me, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for my school course,' I sent him to a friend who has a restaurant.

Gary recently started playing the drums and now has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do well. I told him, 'Gary, if you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it might be too late.'

Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students, who are usually beginners, were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He had prepared everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping other people. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it because no one gives you anything for free. He saw the opportunity he was given and took it with both hands. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even ten percent of what you tell them, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.

Finding a good apartment in Dublin that you could afford was very difficult, like finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a place, that often helped. But if you were new to Dublin, like Jo, you had no personal contacts and no one to tell you about available rooms. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and search for a place. For her, Dublin was a big unknown. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she took the train to work there. She didn't question why she was going; everyone at her school assumed she would leave their small town. Who would want to stay in a boring, remote place? That's what she heard for years. Everyone wanted to leave, see the world, and have a real life. Some of her classmates went to nearby towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family would help them settle. But Jo was the only one from her year going to Dublin, and she was going alone.

Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed in the hostel permanently because it was run by nuns, and she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm because they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn't know they were all still thinking and talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that the people would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The "own television" part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, who seemed to have been rejected, was coming down the stairs. "Desperate place," she said to Jo. "They're both awful. Common as dirt." "Oh," said Jo and continued up the stairs.

"Hello," said a girl with "Nessa" on her T-shirt. "Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type." "What did she do?" asked Jo. "Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, 'Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear,' in a posh voice. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?" Pauline wore a very colorful shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo noticed she was a punk, which surprised her. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one. "I'm Jo, I work at the post office, and I called about the flat." Nessa said they were about to have tea and brought out three mugs. One said "Nessa," one said "Pauline," and the other said "Other." "We'll put your name on it if you stay," she said kindly.

Text: 'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We like to see them in seaside marinas, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in big trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are disappearing. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe areas. But this is not true, and not helping them could be a big wildlife problem. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out in the sea and are seen only in small groups. We do not know much about them. The large grey bottlenoses and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenoses are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few left have skin injuries, showing they are stressed. Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to know why their numbers are going down. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces fish stocks and threatens dolphins because they need to find food quickly. If fish are gone from one area, dolphins may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses big nets that float or move fast in the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornwall beaches, showing they died from getting caught in nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can build up in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can absorb them. These poisons can pass to their young through milk. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another big problem for dolphins is human noise. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This noise might disturb dolphins in ways we do not yet know.'

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels busy and stressful. You might think, "Oh no, another article about exercise!" But there are many good reasons to exercise, and not many reasons not to.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit with good posture, which is how you hold your body. Good posture prevents muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored. But did you know exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems? It also helps control stress and can improve some medical conditions. These are good reasons to start exercising.

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. Be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.

Good posture is important for how you look and feel. A stiff or slouching body can look unattractive and feel tired. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This helps you stand taller and breathe better. It also makes your body look slimmer.

Stretching your muscles makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period. Doing this four or five times a week will make your body more flexible and fit.

**In Their Natural Habitat**

What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their home comforts for months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, Amanda Barrett, a producer, and Owen Newman, a cameraman, are hard to find. They are currently in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained almost non-stop for six months, causing many problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive tool to help when their vehicles get stuck in the mud. Amanda can then pull him back to safety. Together, they have made some of TV's best wildlife films, like their popular film about leopards. Even while this film was being shown, they were already back in the wild, this time following the shy jackal.

This is common for TV partnerships. Film-makers have traveled the world to film exotic wildlife since TV began. I talked to Newman about their partnership when he was at a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue, but we get over it quickly,' he says about Amanda. Neither of them sees themselves as the leader. They get along well because they both see animals in the same way. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now we have a fixed camp, and we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their daily meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem,' says Newman. It can be tough, but being alone in remote areas lets them get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a lion family where a lioness would greet their car as part of her routine.

Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift.' Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months on location to get enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I have a good working relationship because we share the same ideas and vision,' says Newman. 'We want to make films that are rich in atmosphere, show the true spirit of the place and animals, and touch people's hearts. If you can make people feel something, it's better than just making them think.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a typical day before next month's World Championships: teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'

'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I'm on a strict schedule to get as fit as possible.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries taking part. 'We'll have support from people at home, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure. A home crowd will expect us to start with a good game.'

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They have a lot of skill.' The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra points out, the World Championships will be tough. 'You have to push yourself to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can still win if you lose the first game. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance, and you have to be ready.'

In the fifteen years since she started playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But once the game is over, we are all friendlier.' Netball is also using a more scientific approach to fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mental attitude and to lead by example. I support and encourage the team.'

'From the start, my netball career has been carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player.' She will probably coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who loves exploring the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She works at Southampton University, where she teaches and studies marine geochemistry, which is about the chemical processes in the sea. When she is not teaching, she goes on dives to study underwater volcanoes. She uses a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, to dive three kilometers down into the ocean.

Inside the vehicle, space is very tight. Rachel can touch the two pilots sitting next to her. They cannot stand up or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last 16 hours: three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that quickly rises to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has used it yet, and Rachel thinks it would not be a pleasant trip.

Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She was on a ship's deck with an instructor who explained the emergency procedures, like what to do if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would handle being in such a small space. Now, Rachel has done six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team to a place five days' sail from the Canary Islands. There, they studied a large area of underwater volcanoes. The Russian team was setting up equipment to study the effects of a project that would drill a 150-meter hole through a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she enjoys, but she does it so she can continue her research on "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes that release water that looks like black smoke. The water comes out at one meter per second and is 350 degrees hot.

Rachel was only scared once, during a dive with an American team. They were towing equipment when there was a loud explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle, and Rachel thought she was going to die. But nothing happened, and they were relieved to be safe.

Diving to the deepest parts of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she sees the underwater volcanoes, she feels amazed. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing things no one else has seen before. After studying black smokers for three years for her Ph.D., seeing them in real life was an incredible experience for her.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. Studies show that people decide what they think about us in the first few minutes of meeting. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice's volume and tone, as well as the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I finally graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I always think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. One of her friends, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to present her best image at an interview, what kind of teacher is she going to be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best." Many people forget how important it is to have a professional image. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but didn't even get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I applied again for promotion. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't make any difference."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression of a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of any message about our feelings and attitudes comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and a surprising 55% from our facial expressions. When our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages will only confuse the interviewer.

It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went so well she was offered the job right away. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I reacted to the offer with too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wasn't going to say no. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have got more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it will help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, the manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before you go for an interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about areas of company involvement. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will give a positive note and show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confused sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and even in highlighted points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He didn't plan to leave his job for another five or ten years, but he lost his job unexpectedly. He didn't get a lot of money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big opportunity came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat by mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and sells a product.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. Ron and his wife married young, and their children didn't need their support. They moved to the north of England, where they didn't know anyone. They left their friends, but their friendships survived, and many friends visit them now.

**The Hat Maker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so she left. People said she would get bored, but she never did. The secret is to have deadlines because it's a fashion business with collections and seasons. She feels happier and less stressed now. She misses socializing with colleagues but loves being responsible for her product. If she does a bad job, she takes the blame.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in financial markets at 22, making deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he resigned and traveled for a year. During that year, he thought about what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took massage courses. He got a part-time job at the Life Centre and has no regrets. Now he feels in control and has peace of mind.

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My biggest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't get much media attention, which was disappointing because I hoped for sponsorship to help with training costs. I train at home during winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great facilities and nightlife, but I have to be disciplined. If friends invite me out before training, I have to say no. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to compete in the next Olympics, which would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so you can't party late at night. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. It's worth it, though, because without dedication, I wouldn't have won the National Championships last year. After a win, I celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship got me a TV show about surfing. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in style, but we don't look for media attention. Sometimes reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who aren't in sailing. You can't focus on the sport all the time; it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I'm rarely recognized on the street, which I like. I get letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on the court. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out, but it can be difficult. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports and be professional. I'm okay with focusing on my game now and enjoying other things in life after I retire, which happens early in this sport.

**Shopping with Children**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the newest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, it's all three. I can't buy all this stuff, and if I do, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset even before we leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes during a shopping trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things. Arguments about sugar being bad for teeth don't work well against fun and emotional ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' that's still what they want."

Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They look at labels together, and now her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy.

Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm in a good mood, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

**Five-star luxury with modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four big old houses into this hotel. This way, they could add the newest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will be worth it over time. He is very happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible because of the guest-history feature, where staff can note down guest preferences.

Guests often complain about room temperature in hotels. The Merrion has a high-tech system to control this. Guests can change the temperature themselves within three degrees of the normal 18°C. Also, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C. 

Guests, especially business travelers, will like the technology in their rooms. MacCann thinks 65% of the hotel's business will come from business travelers. To meet their needs, each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing tool. Technology changes fast, so the hotel has prepared for future updates. Extra cables are ready for new technology. TVs are rented, not bought, so they can be replaced with newer models. DVD recorders can also be updated when needed.

Even with all this technology, MacCann says they have tried to make the rooms feel comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food must be excellent, as in all luxury hotels. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who had two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This is good for both him and the hotel. He got to design a new, modern kitchen and has better parking than before. The hotel benefits by having a popular restaurant without financial risks. With technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is likely to do well.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share how they stay energetic.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
"I get energy from excitement. I need to do things that challenge me. Learning new things gives me a lot of energy. I also get energy from rhythm, like when I learn flamenco dancing. Dance is great because it's expressive and gives you energy. If you're bored, you might feel tired and think life has no purpose. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives you energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a chore. If you like what you do, you won't feel down, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep, and when I get it, I feel great. If I only sleep six hours a night, I feel tired. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week before work and try to exercise at home. After exercising, I feel much better. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 in the afternoon, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily for energy; I think it's my natural enthusiasm and being positive. I don't like negative people. I believe we should enjoy life and live in the moment. Enjoyment is important. You need to set goals and achieve them. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many young people, and their energy affects me. I love being busy and social. I enjoy taking photos, but I'm not sure if I'm good at it. I can't wait to see them after they're developed. I've also started writing lyrics for fun, which helps me relax when I travel."

**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I do at work and with my family. Being positive helps. I love working with kids because they have a lot of energy and are strong.
