Energy is like a natural chemical that comes from talking to others. Try smiling at people and see how good it feels when they smile back. It's better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise plan. I get my exercise by playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
"I love making a garden from a wasteland. I did that once with a garden that was all concrete. I broke the concrete and added soil. It was better than any workout or tennis. I also get energy from knowing people want to read what I write. I find it hard to write if no one is interested. I like exploring places like a farmer's land or a wood. If someone finds me, I say, 'Oh, what a nice place, I didn't know it was private.' I like it because it feels like being a child."

**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
"I think you need to be interested in and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don't want to do makes you tired. I used to be on different committees and didn't like how they took my time. You only have so much energy, so use it for things that matter to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. People have found old skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until about 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was calm and stylish. But in the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie made skating more athletic, which made it more popular. Today, skating mixes art and sport, making it both beautiful and challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to stay balanced. Your body should lean a little forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It's quite easy, right? As you practice, you can make your movements longer.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills for skaters. Even the best skaters fall. To avoid getting hurt, try to stay relaxed when you fall. This helps reduce the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up. Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. It's best to start with figure skating and then learn basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basics, and soon you can try turns, jumps, and spins.

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, you should do regular exercises. It's dangerous to skate with a stiff body, so warm-up exercises are important. Focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also makes your heart and lungs stronger and generally strengthens your body. If you combine skating with swimming or jogging, you can have a great fitness program for overall health.

**Trills and Bills**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can make you cry with happiness. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about the good and bad parts of their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**

Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I don't have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gym and school. I try to take each training day as it comes. When I'm very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**

"Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, and it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we've given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was shy and hid behind me, but now she's met people worldwide and gained confidence."

**C. Sarah Stokes**

Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me to events. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I would do it because I'm determined. I'm happy they are proud when I win, but I do it for myself. My goal this year is to join the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

**D. Sarah's Mother**

"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she would get up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to travel all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happiest on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**

Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about being too proud. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's Mother**

"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to hold her back because she's special. If she has this talent, let her reach her potential."

Chris Greener was 14 years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every ten years, people in Europe get about one centimeter taller on average. More and more tall people are being born. This doesn't mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are now losing the effects of many years of poor diet, which is changing us a lot. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are becoming like Cro-Magnons again, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."

In the past, our ancestors ate a wide variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate 85 different wild plants. About 9,000 years ago, farming started, which changed everything. Farmers took over green areas, and now three plants—wheat, rice, and maize—give us more than half of our calories. This poor diet has hurt our health and bodies. Over time, we ate soups, porridges, and breads that left us underfed. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started growing corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, once thought to be a blessing, was actually bad for health.

Farming spread because it could support more people than hunting and gathering. But most people were poorly nourished. Only recently have richer countries started to improve diets. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are now more like our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, as they have been since 1860. Leg-room in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their products.

The question is: how tall will we get? We can't grow forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University says it could be 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. But scientists say that while individuals are getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might shrink even more. So, global warming could stop us from growing taller.

Text: 'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Like technical problems, studio audiences are a common part of TV life, but they are still a mystery to many of us. When we see them getting excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Among all live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least important. Some people in TV even look down on them, treating them 'like cattle,' as one cameraman said. I thought studio audiences were just people wanting a bit of fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. TV tries to get different people for different shows. Those of us who like watching TV at home don't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in an uncomfortable studio to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people hope to be seen on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. Why did she come? It was a chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was 'a friend gave me a ticket.' Few of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit there, crowded with strangers, while someone shows cards that say APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh when told. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager says, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching TV at home? For Claire, sitting in a studio is 'more exciting,' while Charlotte liked feeling part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you see him on TV at home, you miss a lot.' What I missed was seeing live actors - from where I sat, I could only see the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a studio screen. Going to a studio might be a bad way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.'

**Bruce**  
I don't like wild landscapes without people. I like places with a human touch. When I travel, I prefer lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling was a way to escape school. I loved exploring the hilltops, valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, the landscape felt familiar but different. I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my private diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.

**Sophia**  
There is a small railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by hobbyists. I always travel first class because it doesn't cost much more. The scenery isn't spectacular. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But I always look forward to one part of the journey when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we can see people doing everyday things like making tea or doing the dishes. I see myself as a woman in a tiny train, looking into other people's homes. I like the ordinary landscape. Just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look closer to find something special.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people. Some brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the sea's beauty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland through valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple self-catering places with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are not many people living or visiting there. It's a hidden, empty, and remote area, and I like the feeling of space. I found the area by chance when I was a student, and since then, I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It makes me sad that he's growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted pure peace and to reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's the place of my dreams. It's a magical, secluded, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals and enjoys being around them. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she found a great pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank for animals we found, so we could admire them and read about them in our natural history book.

I got home late and started cooking when I heard my sons shouting, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. The problem was with Domino, our cat, and Bianca, a white mouse I got as a Mother's Day gift. Domino had the mouse in his mouth and was running around the room, trying to find a way out. I tried to help but tripped and fell on the floor. As I thought about how to stop Domino, I saw the snake escaping from its tank.

The room was chaotic with the cat, mouse, kids, and now the snake. The dog was barking too. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and came back to the room. I managed to catch Domino by the tail and saved the mouse, which was wet but unharmed. Interestingly, this mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life.

Feeling confident after saving the mouse, I looked at the snake to see how to catch it. It was not easy. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, trying to calm it down. Slowly, the snake relaxed, and I carefully picked it up. I took it to the end of the garden and pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would go there. But when I let go of its head, the snake wrapped around my shoulders like a scarf, seeming to settle in for the winter.

We stood there, me, my four children, and the snake. My eldest, DJ, said, "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and fat and warm, and the shed isn't." We gently encouraged the snake to move on. Slowly, it climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Send me a letter! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old way of writing letters might disappear. But for me, getting a letter is special and different from other ways of communication. There is the excitement when it arrives, the happiness of seeing who sent it, and the joy of reading it. I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the small notes I wrote to my mother. My mother always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote once a week, and so did my mother. Sometimes my father wrote, and it was always fun to get his long, funny letters. Most letters from home were about everyday things happening with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most. There were also letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I often had boyfriends who had to work or study far away, and we could only stay in touch by writing letters. But instead of hurting the relationships, writing letters made them better. I found that I could often say things more easily in writing than by talking. I love the letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but it's even better to have a year's worth of news! And it's even better when it's an airmail envelope with beautiful stamps. My overseas letters come from Mangala in Sri Lanka, from someone I trained with over 20 years ago, and I have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. Then there's the lady who writes to me from France. If we hadn't started talking in a restaurant on the way home from holiday, if my husband hadn't taken her photo, and if I hadn't asked her for her address, I would never have been able to write to her. More importantly, if she hadn't replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can improve my French (she speaks no English); we have stayed at her home twice, and she has stayed with us. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer when my family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that a friendship through letters could last so long. The local newspaper even thought it was important enough to put on the front page. I am happy that my children are continuing the tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage readers not to let letter writing become a 'lost art'.'

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art in the Alps**

In the French Alps, there are tens of thousands of ancient pictures carved into rocks at Mont Bego. These pictures are very old, about 4,000 years, and show cows with horns, fields, and gods and goddesses. Scientists are worried because these drawings are being damaged quickly by careless tourists. They fear that if this continues, the drawings might not be there for future generations.

The site is popular, and many visitors are ruining the pictures with graffiti. Jean Clottes, who leads the International Committee on Rock Art, says people think the pictures will last forever, but they won't if the damage continues. He has seen tourists walking on the drawings, which wears them away. Some even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. When tourists can't take good photos, they rub the drawings to make them clearer, which damages them more.

Some people even scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts are not sure how to best protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the mountain should be closed to the public, except for guided tours. He believes this is the only way to save the site and continue important research.

However, Jean Clottes disagrees. He thinks closing the site completely would upset local people. The site is a historic monument, and he believes they should try to save it without closing it. David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says the area is too big to stop all damage, and they don't have enough money to hire guards. They might need to charge visitors a fee because there is no government funding.

Annie Echassoux, who also studies the site, is worried because tourists can now reach the mountain more easily by hiring vehicles. She thinks the damage will get worse. She believes they should rope off the area and provide guides. She insists that money must be found to protect the site because it is a historic area. If they don't act, the drawings might be lost for future generations.

**Shopping with Children**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not the newest sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, it's all three. I can't buy all this stuff, and if I do, I feel guilty for buying unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset even before we leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make their own choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes during a shopping trip. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things. Arguments about sugar being bad for teeth don't work well against fun and emotional ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' the effect is the same."

Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They look at labels together, and now her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy.

Parents also admit they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm in a good mood, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help reduce conflicts by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Even if parents spend less because their children aren't with them, the idea of shopping without a child's demands might attract more customers.

Text: 'Climbing Walls In the past, climbers went to the mountains. Now, you can have a challenging climb anywhere, indoors or outdoors. People watch closely as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by his fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at Birmingham's National Indoor Arena. This arena is also known for the TV show Gladiators, and both events have something in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new technology. Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they either climbed in cold weather, walked, or climbed on snow and ice in Scotland. As climbing became more popular, it was important for top climbers to stay fit. When cliffs were not usable, they used brick or stone buildings to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid boredom. Soon, sports centers started building walls for climbing, using bricks with special edges. One of the first was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in the mid-1960s at Leeds University. He put natural rock in concrete blocks for climbing walls. Many walls like this were built in sports halls in the 1970s, but they had problems. They could only be built straight up, while real cliffs have overhangs and angled rocks. Also, once built, they couldn't be changed, and climbers got bored with the same holds. In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a material that could be shaped like real cliff features. These could be attached to any wall and changed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started using panels on steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for overhanging walls, but steel frames could be set up anywhere. This system allowed climbers to have new holds all the time.'

Text: 'So you want to be an actor? If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky' very quickly. Acting is indeed a risky career. There are more people who want to be actors than there are jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some friends might say you are crazy, but others might think differently. Everyone will give you different advice. But becoming an actor is a personal choice, and only you can decide and work towards your dream. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and even if you finish your training, it does not mean you will get a job. Success depends on luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous, with the chance of earning a lot sometimes. People often ask what talent is. I think talent is natural skill plus imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. Talent also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain why you want to act. In the theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is important in all acting and is what motivates actors. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might just shrug. They might not know. They know some things about themselves and their skills, but they do not assume anything because they know their success depends on their current job. Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, doing other jobs like selling clothes or waitressing. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role, but you might not get it, even if you want it very much. So, actors do not talk much about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and possible rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Remember, rejection can happen from the first time you try to get a role. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, it is up to you. If you do not care enough, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are excited to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, Delia Smith often comes to mind. Her recipes come from all over the world and show her love for exciting food. She understands what the average cook can do in a regular kitchen. Her book, *Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course*, is a must-have for modern cooks. It offers simple and expert advice on both basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes. The book has been updated recently and is perfect for anyone who wants just one cookbook.

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc became a top chef and owner of a famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. His book, *Blanc Mange*, goes with his first TV series. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by showing how ingredients work together. He believes cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book has over 80 amazing recipes and explains why some dishes might not turn out well. It also introduces some basic food chemistry. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows how good he is at it.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is known for the best in classical French cooking. For 100 years, this famous cooking school has trained students to cook perfectly. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they released the *Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook*, which has 100 respected recipes. The recipes are classics but still feel fresh. The school has moved away from heavy sauces to healthier options. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and includes sections on Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes and secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Fast food? No way! Many think good food takes a long time to cook, but Nigel Slater, food editor of *The Observer*, disagrees. His book, *The 30-Minute Cook*, shows that fast food can be good food. Nigel believes you can make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered. He has already written two successful books about this. In his new book, you will find over 200 recipes from around the world that you can make in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way. If you think fast food can't be delicious, try his recipes—they are simply great.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He didn't plan to leave his job for another five or ten years, but he lost his job unexpectedly. He didn't get much money when he left, but it was enough to start his farm. His big chance came when he met the head chef of a local hotel with a top restaurant. By supplying them, his reputation grew, and now he also sells meat by mail order. He is happy not to be in an office anymore, but he still works 80 to 90 hours a week and sells a product.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now works as an artist. Painting started as a hobby, but he found it more exciting than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him, and he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. Ron and his family moved to the north of England, where they didn't know anyone. They left their friends, but their friendships have lasted, and many friends visit them now.

**The Hat Maker**

Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own business making hats in her London flat. She enjoyed her job as a lawyer and earned a lot of money, but the hours were long. She didn't want to become a senior partner and work even more hours, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she never did. She keeps busy with deadlines and fashion collections. She feels happier and less stressed now. She misses socializing with colleagues but loves being responsible for her product. If she does a bad job, it's her responsibility.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in financial markets at 22, making deals. He liked the excitement but didn't find the work rewarding. In 1989, he almost lost his job, so he resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what he wanted to do. He was interested in health, so he visited top gymnasiums and talked to the owners. He knew he needed qualifications to change careers, so he took massage courses. He got a part-time job at the Life Centre and has no regrets. He feels in control and has peace of mind now.

**Onto a Winner**

Two brothers are turning their childhood game into a successful business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers in their forties with big beards, are sitting in their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game from their childhood called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, who was a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. The family loved playing it on weekends and holidays. When they moved to New Mexico, they continued to play with the board their grandfather made from old wooden crates. Visitors were often curious because the game was not known in the southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave noticed the old board was damaged, so he made a new one. It was so nice that a relative and then a friend wanted one too. To see if more people were interested, the brothers took the new board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people laughed at the game, but once they tried it, they couldn't stop playing. When people asked about the game's history, Dave found out it probably started in India with a game called 'carroms'. It then became 'squails' in Britain and was brought to Canada by British immigrants. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version from Quebec.

Pichenotte is a game of skill for two to four players. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks' to flick across a board using one finger. Flicking a puck into a small hole scores 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight small posts make the game harder. A game usually lasts two minutes.

Seeing how popular the game was, the brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. The game became so popular that championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was created. As more people heard about it, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time business. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. They sell for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope their business will grow. Until then, they enjoy playing the game that might make them rich.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you first come to the Model Village, it's hard to believe that a few years ago, this place was just empty land covered with wild plants. People thought it was useless land. But one man, with the help of his wife, worked hard to turn it into the beautiful place you see today. They moved a lot of soil and clay to change the flat land into the nice landscape you see now. Machines helped, but there was also a lot of hard work involved. After shaping the land, they added about 1,000 tonnes of good soil to make the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens.

Many trees and bushes were planted in the Model Village. They had to choose plants that could survive the salty air from the sea and the strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some came from far places like Canada and New Zealand.

Colin Sims created the whole village, and he made over 100 models by himself over nine years. The village opened in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastics to last in all weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how materials would last in different weather, but soon he became an expert too.

You will see that the models are all made to the same scale, and even the smallest details are carefully done. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular because of its high quality and care. The techniques used here are now used in other model villages in England and are even taught in some schools.

All the model buildings show traditional British architecture but are not exact copies of real places. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, which looks like a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It is based on the style of manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will also see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest part of the village.

Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; a small mistake can mean hours of repair work for us. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead. 

To make your visit more fun, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press them to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us make the village more interesting. We also want to know if you think any models need improvement. We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Don't forget to tell your friends about it!

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC is an organization that deals with these issues. These pictures are rarely in the public interest. Do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress has complained about long-lens photos before. Since she was in a hotel, where she should expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. It is surprising that the PCC did not investigate this. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action on these and other unfair stories? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. These decisions would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such material. Even photographers would be affected, as it would not be worth their time to hide and take pictures of celebrities. If the PCC decided to act like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue anyway? Also, celebrities and royalty might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC watch over all British newspapers: national, regional, and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret, and they know it might come out if they complain. In this way, even the PCC might seem like the enemy. A British comedian also had problems with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon in the Caribbean. He didn't complain then, or later, when his family was photographed on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper, News of the World, would show the pictures again with a new story about his 'anger', saying it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many people give advice to college graduates looking for their first job. This article is about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for another temporary job while searching for a permanent one, or those leaving a bad job after a few weeks. We are focusing on those who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for next? It depends on your long-term goals. Do you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to a higher position, or change to a different field? Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. Plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. It should also help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be glad to see you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career. 

Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a great first job because the people were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her computer skills. But there was no chance to move up. So, she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, 'In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has grown.' Her boss wanted to help her develop from the start. Her job title is the same, but her duties have changed. She went from mostly typing and phone work to handling most of the correspondence and budgets. She also deals with different questions, from company chairmen to people wanting to start their own business. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

Confident people: What's their secret? Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but most of them learned how to be confident because they needed to. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

A. Jenny: When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was 25, I was asked to help at my daughter's school. I didn't think I could do it, but I did well. Someone there suggested I take a university course. I was very nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew, and I became more outgoing. Working at the school changed my life and helped everything else fall into place.

B. Michaela: Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to take over the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive and impatient. I thought confident people acted like that, but I learned that confidence means believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don't feel bad about leaving some tasks for the next day. When faced with something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you lose confidence, so I talk to myself to get rid of those fears.

C. Lisa: People think I'm confident, but the calmer I look, the more scared I am. I had to learn to look confident because it's important in TV. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous in important situations, and we feel better when we talk to someone friendly. My mom gave me the best advice when I was worried about wearing the right clothes. She said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves.' I remember that. You gain confidence by doing things that scare you. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I would never be that scared again.

D. Barbara: My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I've built it over the years. If you keep going and learn from mistakes, you become more confident. I work hard and am liked in the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You have to like yourself for who you are, not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped my confidence. They also encourage setting small goals. It helps to see you're achieving something real, instead of trying to do too much at once and getting nothing.

E. Kim: After college, I worked as a secretary and didn't always agree in meetings but was too scared to speak up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started in politics, I had never spoken in public and was very nervous. I told myself, 'Don't be silly. People do this every day, so you can too.' I also found it helpful to write down a few notes, like having a comfort blanket. Everyone feels a bit nervous about public speaking. The real secret to confidence is telling yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.'

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were exactly 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and split bamboo. We sat next to them in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest and most serious kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held up the kites, and a line of nervous competitors held their kite strings, waiting for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, judged on decoration, stability in the air, and how well they fly. 'Flying kites isn't very hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how it's done.' I received five invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, shiny room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving my car towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains covered with thick rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road suddenly ended at a river. A long, narrow boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a small sign caught my eye. It pointed up a path into the forest and said: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' Before starting, it would have been helpful to know that most of this distance was uphill, steep, and slippery. When I reached the path, I found a man waiting with a flask of tea. This was Baba, who took care of a tented kitchen and several bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about insects crawling under my thin foam mattress. The night was completely dark, full of different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many living things moved and squeaked. In the morning, there was an amazing view over five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning hit the treetops. Seconds later, I was soaked. Sliding downhill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the huge raindrops. I also worried about my car being washed away (it sometimes happens) and the chance of drowning if I opened my mouth. Luckily, the car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the path. No one is a stranger for long here. Back in Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, everyone asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' But they were very friendly. Kelantan might be best known for its kites, but I remember it more for its human kindness.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Everyone goes shopping, even if they love it or hate it. But people shop in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I love shopping! I can't stop spending money. When I have money, I go shopping, and it makes me happy. I find it hard to ignore sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often shop together. We are a shopping couple!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I don't like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't spend much time shopping for clothes. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all like different things. I don't often spend money on myself, so when I do, I feel guilty and don't tell my husband the real price. I always say it cost less because the real price sounds too high.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for things I really need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. When I shop, I know exactly what I want and won't buy anything else. I find shopping tiring and would rather do something else.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and shop quickly. I do have some clothes I bought by mistake, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes wrong choices.

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't like shopping at all. I really dislike shopping for clothes because I can't find what I want, and nobody helps me. The shops are too noisy and messy, and I find it very stressful. Luckily, I don't have to shop for clothes often because most of my clothes are gifts. For food shopping, I go to the local supermarket once a week and finish it quickly.

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I'm probably a happy shopper. Sometimes I go out with my friends to look around the shops, and we often end up buying things. I don't usually have a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I'll buy it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I'm a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don't buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don't go crazy. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I often feel worse because I spent too much money.

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it's too busy. I'm a careful shopper. I usually know what I want and don't buy things quickly. I like to check other shops to find a better deal, so I take a long time.

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I'm an unwilling shopper. Maybe because I work in the city center, the shops don't interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I do it quickly and don't try things on because it's too much trouble. Sometimes the clothes I buy don't fit, but I don't mind. I'd rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping.

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE

The Open University is like other universities because it can give you a degree. But, you don't have to stop working to study there. It can also help you find new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will also make many different friends. Your degree might help you find new job opportunities.

You don't go to the Open University for lectures. Instead, you study at home using television, radio, and computer programs. You can go to one class a month at an Open University center if you want. Like other universities, there are exams to take.

If you want to know more, just fill out the form below. It could be the beginning of a great new time in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, young visitors can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the desk by the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz sheets are available during normal gallery hours from 25 March to 9 April.

**New Picture**

The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is one of the first paintings of this kind in the Gallery. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for different flowers to bloom in their seasons to paint them. Miss Violet Churchman gave this picture to the Gallery in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started in the Sunley Room on 15 March. The Gallery recently bought works by three Spanish painters from this time: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians who worked in Spain, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

There are lectures every Wednesday to go with the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez's work. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will lecture on Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will discuss Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists often "tell a story" through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery is happy to announce that the restaurant now has better and more services. With new kitchens, the restaurant offers many hot and cold dishes at good prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and the whole range of important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are spent learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join the course. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora is twelve, and she's having trouble cutting onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I start a hobby, instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't very interested at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre charges a fee for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. You need to pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club; it is a place that offers outdoor sports and fun activities for everyone. If you are visiting with a group, please let the centre know before you come.

Windsurfing - One-day course
Beginner windsurfing courses are available on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very enjoyable. The feeling when you first sail across the water is unforgettable. Beginners can use boards with small sails. The course costs £32.50, and this includes all the equipment.

One-day adventure course
This is a great chance to try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is for adults who want to try outdoor activities in a fun and relaxed way. You do not need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. The course costs £22.50.

Play Park
The Play Park is for children aged two to ten years. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a large ball pool, a play castle, and much more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses
We also offer day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us often. There are three large rooms with twelve beds each, which can be booked in advance for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for ages 8-14)
Activities include sailing, climbing, windsurfing, and fun games. Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff are trained in First Aid and are qualified to teach the activities. We make sure that all children only do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Millions of people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is both interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections and find a hobby that can last a lifetime. 

Starting a stamp collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find them on holiday postcards from friends, birthday cards from family, and letters from pen pals. These can give you stamps from all over the world.

If you want to collect stamps seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps for your collection. You can receive these stamps in three ways: 

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope addressed to you.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful information pack with interesting facts.
3. We can send you individual stamps for you to arrange in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too, with a two-year membership costing just £5. If a group of you join at the same time, you can get a discount. This is great value for money. 

When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack at no extra cost. This pack has 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a helpful 4-page guide to collecting. This guide has more ideas on how to add to your collection and includes useful addresses of shops and businesses that sell stamps.

Every two months, you'll receive a copy of the club magazine. It is full of competitions and quizzes, and it gives you the chance to exchange stamps with members around the world.

Why not start an adventure that will give you years of pleasure? You will spend many happy hours looking at the amazing variety of stamps in your collection or searching for unusual ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and discover the fun and excitement of stamp collecting. 

To join the Club, simply complete the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will be sent within 28 days after we receive your application.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? The pound, the dollar, or the franc are like units of measurement, such as a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or a couple of cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that costs very little to make. 

Thousands of years ago, people didn't have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, people like Mr Green, who was a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' to make trading easier. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges, including Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing, want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were very popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like, but here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, most people who wrote for us did this. Love, family, and problems with friends were the main topics. However, you need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right Don't describe a town or explain how something works if you are not sure about it. Only write about things you know are correct. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is the worst. Develop the story carefully and try to think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story seem real by using good words to describe them. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. Even if you are close to the deadline, we cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your £5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST

Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist mentioned in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University, and he made sure she got the best education possible. This was unusual because most women at that time did not have many chances to study. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia went back to Alexandria and started teaching mathematics. She became famous for her knowledge of new ideas. We do not have any copies of her books, but we know she wrote several important works in mathematics. Hypatia was also interested in technology and invented some scientific tools to help with her work. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people connected with it were in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long. It goes through the beautiful Nene Park, starting from Peterborough in the east to Wansford, where the main office is. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, which is the current western end of the line. Ticket prices are £10.00 for adults, £5.00 for children, and £25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Prices may change on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park is a great place for a family day out. It has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. There are also many hectares of public parkland with boating lakes, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a small railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a special collection of historic trains from different parts of Europe. This includes famous trains like the elegant De Glen Compound locomotive from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, which is the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can also see '92 Squadron' and 'Mayflower', which were made in Britain. These engines can be seen all year, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are only open when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can set projects for students to do while visiting or in the classroom. There is an educational pack available for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages on days when the train is not running. Bookings should be made one month in advance. There are special low prices for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
The Railway is a popular place for family events or company visits. It can be a fun afternoon or evening out. Special programs can be arranged to include a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, and more. For more information, please contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass

Grass is probably the most successful plant in the world. There are over 9,000 different types of grass, and they are found everywhere on Earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can live in the cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. Unlike other plants, new leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one area. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food.

Kal Kaur Rai has always loved fashion and recently won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she enjoyed drawing clothes and creating designs. However, she never told her parents, who own a supermarket, that she wanted to make fashion her career. She thought they wanted her to choose a more traditional job, so she studied management at university. After finishing her studies, she moved to London and worked at an advertising agency. She had to go to industry events but couldn't afford the expensive clothes she liked, so she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends loved her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs, and they sold very well. This success gave her the confidence to leave her job, take a £20,000 loan, and start her own women's clothing brand. Kal's parents were not upset about her career change and promised to support her, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than £500,000. Her designs are featured in fashion magazines, she creates clothes for pop stars, and she has gained public recognition by winning this award. Kal feels very lucky and says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

**SUNNINGDALE HOTEL**

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given great service to people from all over the world. Over the past 80 years, more than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here.

The hotel is on a main road that leads to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to get to the center, and buses to many parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Be careful not to take buses with the blue sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is an underground station less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 comfortable single rooms with central heating. Each room has a basin with hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel also has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. Guests can use eight pianos. There is parking available in the hotel drive. Free daily newspapers are provided, and you can buy stamps at the office.

Guests staying for a long time must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short-term and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get room priority. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9:30 am, lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm, and dinner from 5:30 pm to 7 pm. On weekdays, if you are studying or working late, you can request dinner until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires (for heating food or rooms) are allowed. Please respect others' comfort. Keep noise from tapes or CDs low, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main railway station.

Text: 'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is one of the most successful actors in movie history. But his life wasn't always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends, even though he loved being in school plays. After finishing high school, Tom moved to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also went to drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, he became so successful that he was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood, making millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and is very popular with his many fans from all over the world.'

Title: "Little Cat, Little Cat, Where Have You Been?"

Bo the cat had a big adventure when she decided to explore a furniture van. The van driver found her after driving more than 500 kilometers. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry. The driver gave Bo some milk and started looking for her owner. He called his last customers, but none of them had lost a cat. Since it was late, he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital.

Meanwhile, Bo's owner was also trying to find her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that had visited a neighbor. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely returned to him.

Text: 'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north coast through a lot of desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is mostly known for being late. The idea of a train line between Darwin and Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but there was often flooding, making it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train - there are few stops and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on board is very good. The railway was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's busy south through Darwin and the train, instead of by ship around the continent, would save time and money. It is not every day a railway across a continent is finished, and the Ghan says it is the world's first north-south one. As I waited to get on the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the trip. Most of the other travelers were older Australians, and they were very eager to board. Our first stop, where the Ghan waited four hours, was at Katherine. Some passengers got off here and took a boat trip up the gorge. I didn't leave the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group just walked around the rock and stayed to watch the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land, with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the foothills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train might not have given everything the ads promise, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.'

Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We planned to climb the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. This climb is 600 meters high and is probably the longest in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is so hard it feels like ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we packed a lot of safety equipment. We had lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path soon went up, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but when I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that next time I would train better before a climb. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we were not so lucky because a mist came down. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as climbing up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns doing that job. That first time, I only really enjoyed the experience when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we moved into our new school building! It's a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this new school is special because it is designed to be very good for the environment. It took many months to build, so we watched it being built. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it also meant we lost some nice open space. The building machines were very noisy, and the builders often had to stop because of heavy rain. We started to think the building would never be finished.

Now, we have five classrooms, which are very big - much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town when they need to have meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use them when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will notice there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building is designed to keep all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound inside too. So, when we sing in our classrooms, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is that there is a tree on the school roof! The builders put it there because it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday, and it spins very fast. It is so big that you can see it from far away! We took some pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are already using the school, there are still some parts to be added. For example, we are putting on a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall to do it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many people already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**
You just need to send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**
As a special offer, you can choose any books at a reduced price from our new members' book list, up to a total value of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money on the publishers' prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift chosen by our staff from our book list. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the usual price.

**When you've joined:**
As a member, you will save between 30% and 50% off the publisher's price on every book you buy, and they will be delivered straight to your door. You will receive a free club magazine once a month, which will keep you updated with the latest best-sellers. Every year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. You can find all our titles for the year on our special members' website.

**Being a member:**
All we ask is that you choose four books during your first year. After that, you can decide how many books you want to buy. In each monthly club magazine, our experienced staff choose a "Club Choice" book, which is a fiction or reference book they think is worth buying, offered at a special price. If you do not want this book, just say so on the form. We will send the book if we do not hear from you.

So, return your application form today, but hurry - we don't make offers like this every day. To become a member, just fill in the enclosed form and return it in the postage-paid envelope. Soon, your books will arrive. Please don't send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have up to two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. You can then either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never thought that on a Saturday afternoon in November, I would be hanging 30 meters above the ground and enjoying it. Now, as I looked down at the river far below, I understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place we stayed wasn't great, but it had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outdoors, but we weren't sure exactly what we would do. Half of us spent the morning caving, while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but felt happy and excited about what we had done.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it, I had my cheque book, address book, and my purse with about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do: I'm 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I explained what had happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I should keep the fare.
