I got home safely, and soon after, the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, with everything still inside. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the scariest animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks very dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if you turn a shark over on its back, it can stop moving completely. This is helpful for scientists who study sharks because it lets them learn more about these interesting animals.'

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Scheduled flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, and back from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, you will take Air Australia flights between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. You will travel by coach from Sydney to Melbourne, passing through Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia are included. You will stay for nineteen nights in good hotels with full continental breakfast. The trip includes a day visit to Ayers Rock, a full day boat trip to the Great Barrier Reef, a visit to an Australian sheep farm, and city tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All state and local taxes are covered. Hotel baggage handling is included. An experienced Globewise Tour Manager will be with you throughout the trip. PERTH Enjoy long, golden beaches, excellent restaurants, beautiful parks, and the lovely Swan River. A city tour is included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs, located in the heart of Aboriginal country. A full sightseeing tour is included. Visit the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Travel to Yulara National Park. Visit the mysterious Olgas and Ayers Rock, which has caves and Aboriginal rock paintings. Then fly to the lively seaside town of Cairns to relax in the sun. GREAT BARRIER REEF We have included a full day's boat trip on the famous reef, where you can see amazing, brightly colored fish and other sea creatures. SYDNEY Experience the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city. A sightseeing tour and a visit to the famous Opera House are included. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE A city sightseeing tour is included, or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise that by the end of the trip, you'll want to come back!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet I'm Nathalie. Last year, I became one of the youngest foreign students to join the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone came to me, asking questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they started talking in English, so we could understand each other. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me, my Russian has improved a lot, and I understand my teachers. For the first two weeks after I arrived, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. I even called home late at night once because I felt a little lonely. Compared to my ballet school in England, the classes in Russia are very hard, and I eat a lot to keep my energy up. This makes me confident that I can meet the school's high standards. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the movie ends. Now that I've settled in, I feel really at home here. I like walking around the city and visiting different shops, even in December when it was very cold. I decided to buy a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was mild for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy. Right now, we are preparing for a new show, and there is also a competition for young dancers that I will enter. I feel so lucky to be here.'

THE ICEHOTEL

For many years, people liked to visit the Arctic in the summer to see the land of the midnight sun. But in winter, only a few people lived there, and they had the snow and ice all to themselves. By the end of the 1980s, people thought the dark and cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to open an art show in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in the small town of Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This building, called Arctic Hall, brought many visitors to the area. One night, some foreign guests thought it would be fun to sleep in the Arctic Hall. The next morning, they were very happy with their experience, and this gave the idea for an ice hotel. Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous all over the world.

When winter starts, a team of snow builders, architects, and artists from different countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is ready, it opens to visitors and guests who want to stay overnight, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and each week a new part opens until January 7th, when the hotel is finished. The ICEHOTEL is built outside, using natural winter materials, so the finishing date can change because of the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it is colder outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the price of staying at the hotel. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, a scarf, and lots of wool socks. They should choose shoes that are bigger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm sweaters, wool socks, and more on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these things when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can arrange bus transport from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop that had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. About 6,000 people rushed to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). Normally, the shop will be open from 9 am to 9 pm every day, but Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours on the first day. However, it had to close just 30 minutes after opening. A police officer who went to the shop said: 'The police knew a big crowd was coming, but people were not patient. The shop filled up quickly, and the managers wisely decided to close the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could get in, and they didn't want to wait quietly. Another problem was the long line of cars trying to reach the car park. I couldn't believe that many people left their cars in the middle of the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road completely.' One customer, Jenny Smith, who got into the shop, said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained the situation. They had no choice because it wasn't safe. I'll come back when they reopen, but I won't wait in line again.'

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts groups.

**Society Magazines**  
We make several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories by some of Britain's best writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work published. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and lots of information about events, competitions, festivals, and writing in general. You can see some articles from recent issues by following the links on this website.

**National Short Story Competition**  
We organize the National Short Story Competition, the biggest competition of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and you can write about any topic. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. Members of the Society do not pay an entry fee, but non-members pay £5. The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to make their own collection of short stories.

**Education**  
For almost thirty years, the Society has brought writers into classrooms to give children and teachers new ideas and help them feel more confident in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners get book prizes and can attend a five-day course taught by professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**  
The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, with freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is located in the heart of London and is open from 11:00 am to 10:00 pm Monday to Friday and 11:00 am to 8:00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events.

**Becoming a Member**  
We have members all over the world, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.

Tanya Streeter is a famous free-diver with four world records. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath. In 2003, Tanya became the first person to dive 120 meters deep and return without help, holding her breath for over three and a half minutes. This made her the only woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive to ensure her safety. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous, but Tanya believes safety and training are most important.

Tanya's training is mostly on land, with two-thirds of her time spent in the gym. She uses an exercise bike to keep her heart fit but avoids running to protect her knees. Instead, she prefers fast walking. When she practices diving, she usually travels and does fourteen dives over four weeks, resting between each dive to avoid getting tired.

When not training, Tanya appears in public to promote sports products and supports environmental causes by doing research or making films. Growing up on Grand Cayman in the Caribbean, she loved swimming and exploring sea life. She feels her life now is like living her childhood dreams. Tanya is well-known in some countries, so people listen to her about environmental issues. In her thirties, she plans to keep breaking her own records and doesn't want to retire from free-diving anytime soon, as she only started at age twenty-five.

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films can do almost anything. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the movie screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming fun again for everyone, no matter their age. By the end of the 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for children. But soon, a few directors had new ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy together. However, not every cartoon film was a hit. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson, a new TV star, shares her experience about her first TV role. She says, "I never thought I would spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I dreamed of playing her. 

Before starting university, I took a year off to travel. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the role. My mother was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. 

The outdoor filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on my essays. I didn't tell my university friends about the filming, but they found out and thought it was amazing. It was a fantastic experience, and I feel very lucky. 

After university, I want to become an actress. I don't come from an acting family, although my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received any offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything because I also had a busy social life. When filming ended, I didn't know what to do with my time. Since then, I've acted in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my only goal was to make enough money to take care of my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a company that is growing quickly all over the world. Since we started, I have learned a lot. Many of the things I have learned are in this book because I believe our company has important ideas about running a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. This is not a typical business book, and it is not just about my life. The main idea is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with care, and it can do good things. In business, just like in life, I need to have fun, feel like part of a family, and be excited by surprises. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with everyone. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do, too.'

Title: A Journey Along the Beautiful Douro River

Jules Verne offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The ship, MV Lady Ivy May, can host 160 guests in double cabins. Each cabin has a private shower and toilet, and all cabins face outside. The ship has air-conditioning and includes a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library.

Itinerary:

Day 1: You will leave London Heathrow in the early evening and fly to Oporto. A guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will stay overnight.

Day 2: In the morning, you will explore Oporto. After sightseeing, you will return to the ship and travel to Entre-os-Rios. This journey takes four hours.

Day 3: The ship will continue up the river. In the early evening, it will stop at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. You can enjoy local food and drinks at dinner.

Day 4: After breakfast, you will take a bus to the old town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum used to be a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. You will then return to the ship and sail to Tua.

Day 5: The Douro River becomes narrow here. If the river is deep enough, you might continue by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by coach, with many sights to see on the way.

Day 6: In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro Valley. After lunch on the ship, you will take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting.

Day 7: You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch. Then, you will travel back down the river to Oporto and spend the night on the ship.

Day 8: You will arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before flying back to London Heathrow.

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It is made of water and sugars. Bees can travel up to 75,000 kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than 300 types of honey. Lighter-colored honey usually has a milder taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very valuable to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research shows that it can help prevent tiredness and improve sports performance. But honey is not just food - it can be used for sore throats and is in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a part of Britain. People have lived there for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By 1066, during the Norman invasion, it had become one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a popular place for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it received a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself.

Today, Norwich is smaller than cities like London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. However, in the 16th century, it was the second-largest city in England. It grew richer over the next 300 years and was known for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but in 1964, the University of East Anglia was built in Norwich. The city has a growing student population and is a modern commercial center. It is the biggest center for insurance services outside London. Norwich offers many entertainment options, such as theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' with green and yellow colors, though the reason for the name is unclear.

Norwich has a modern shopping center called 'The Castle Mall.' To build it, workers dug up the main car park, creating a large hole in the city for over two years. They moved nearly a million tons of earth to make the roof of the Mall a city center park with water pools and trees. The people of Norwich are happy that the old open market is still there, next to the new development. Both the market and the shopping center are successful, showing that Norwich has combined the old and the new well.

**The Albuquerque Balloon Festival**

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the southwestern United States, becomes full of bright colors. This is because of the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event that happens every year. The first festival was in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. Back then, there were only about twelve hot-air balloons, and they took off from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown a lot. This year, at least a thousand balloons from more than a third of the countries in the world are expected at the festival's current location outside the city.

**What to See**

The balloon pilots talk to each other using radios and light up their balloons' burners at the same time. This is called a 'balloon glow' and is a great chance to take amazing photos. To see these 'glows,' you need to arrive just after it gets dark or before 5:30 am when the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to take off. The balloons come in many sizes and colors, and some are shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will really enjoy it.

In the afternoon, you can even take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering flights. Another option is to take a cable car ride from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains. This is the longest cable car ride anywhere and gives you a great view of the festival from above. There are many other things to do for visitors of all ages, like balloon races and fireworks on the first night and the last three nights of the festival.

**The Albuquerque Box**

This is a special wind pattern in the area that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control the direction of their balloons by going up or down.

**Practical Advice**

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long lines at the festival site. Wear several layers of thin clothing because it can be cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, you will need sunglasses and sunscreen. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, bring your camera. If you are not using a digital camera, you will need high-speed film for taking pictures in the evening and at night.

The Eden Project

Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular places for tourists to visit. At first, the large 'biospheres' on this old industrial site look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is amazing to see how many products we use every day come from plants, like wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate. Over 135,000 different types of plants grow here. Even if the weather is cold outside, computer-controlled electric heaters keep the plants at the right temperature. In the Rainforest Zone, the air is always damp because of a big waterfall. Another zone copies the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to build a desert zone soon.

Text: 'No Title Some people have complained about this year's book, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. It has 500 pages of original writing for only £6.99, which is great! Most of the book is fiction, with parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the less famous writers mostly wrote about food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - don't read it right after eating because it has some scenes that might upset your stomach! There is also excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. You can find parts of novels being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, like a very funny article by Alan Rusbridger about some newspapers, and an interesting piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is a special collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will have.'

The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when you are learning about the world." Margaret lives in London and likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some eager five-year-olds. She began teaching the violin in 1972, and her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. 

Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson lasts an hour, happening once every two weeks. In addition, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes because it is important for them to be interested in the lessons.

From the beginning, students learn to play by listening. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for several years. For a long time, there is a big difference between how well they play and how well they read music. Margaret says her method is not meant to create great violinists. She suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. The new CD is called 'Here Again' and it comes after their last CD, 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar instead of Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Also, Tom Simpson has joined the band as the drummer. 

From the first song on the CD, which is a dance song, it is clear that the band is not focusing on slow songs anymore. The second song is also a dance song and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two dance songs will surprise many fans. However, they are very good and could become hit singles. 

Singer Rob Letchford sings very well on this CD, hitting every note perfectly. Fans should be happy that he recorded the songs before he had problems with his throat. Because of his throat issues, the band had to cancel their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets should not worry because all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob is better.)

On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from the slow songs we know to the new dance songs that make you want to move. I think the best songs are at the beginning of the CD, and the last few songs are not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big success and bring more fame to the band.

San Francisco

San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Interestingly, even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbor, it was found by people traveling on land, not by sea. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. But it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people made money by owning banks and law firms, and they built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It gives a detailed and interesting description of everyday life in England between 1660 and 1669. Pepys writes about important news stories of the time, like disease, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, even about his faults - he often slept during church or looked at the pretty girls. He describes his home life - a quarrel with his wife and how they became friends again, and his worry about her illness. Besides books, he liked music, the theatre, card games, and parties with good food and lots of fun. Pepys was a busy man who had many important jobs - he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his work for the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, people did not care if shoes were comfortable or fashionable. Early shoes were probably made from animal skins, which people tied around their ankles when it was cold. We still use leather today, but other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton are also popular, depending on what is in style. Only one hundred and fifty years ago, people started wearing a different shoe on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either the left or right foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now, even though some shoemakers still use traditional skills, most shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to stop my running career for a while. I wanted to help more women try running, to show them how fun it can be and to help them feel confident to start running. So, I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because many race organizers complained that not many women join races, but they also didn't provide separate changing rooms for women. I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were of all ages and fitness levels. Most of them wanted to lose weight, but I don't think they had thought much about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined hard and painful training. They didn't think about running while chatting and smiling in beautiful places, like by a river. At first, they could only run for one minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They have also learned from other runners about eating well and staying fit. I wanted to help women's running, and I have enjoyed watching their progress a lot - almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there hoping to become rich. New towns were built and grew quickly. One of these towns was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew so fast that it became the largest city in Alaska for a short time. 

In the summer, boats could bring important supplies to these towns. But in the winter, the rivers and ocean froze, so boats couldn't travel. In 1910, a winter trail was made for teams of dogs pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This trail was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a team of dogs to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers could sleep and eat, and feed their dogs.

The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes started to replace boats and dog teams. However, in 1925, a disease called diphtheria hit the city of Nome. The disease could be cured, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, on the other side of Alaska. Airplanes were new, and people were not sure if they could fly in such cold weather. Also, the only skilled pilot, Carl Eielson, was away. So, they decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. 

The journey was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams just six days to finish the trip. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He trusted his dog Togo to find the way in the snow, and Togo was a good guide. The last part of the journey was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had driven dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. At one point, Balto refused to go further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can be as low as -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit every year to see one of Europe's most unique hotels. In this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there if you want. The bar is also made of ice, so it's not a good idea to put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. If you need them, you can also get warm outdoor clothes. The hotel is never older than six months because it melts in the summer. Each winter, it is built again. Building the hotel uses 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Maria Mutola

In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." A local newspaper wrote about the story, and Jose Craveirinha, who had helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to meet her and saw her playing football outside the club. He noticed she was very fast. "He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant because the only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs hurt a lot."

Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could be successful in athletics and that it could help their family out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an invitation to train in the United States. She had said no before because she knew she would miss her family. Her life was very different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew very little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot."

Today, Maria still runs, and for most of the year, she lives happily in South Africa with her mother.

The Skywalk

The Grand Canyon in the United States was made by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and mostly to enjoy the view. The view is amazing, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the beautiful rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands of people have visited it. You have to wear special covers on your shoes to keep the glass from getting scratched. Walking on the Skywalk makes you feel like a bird flying high in the air.

THE ROCKIES

The Rocky Mountains, or the Rockies, stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest and are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern parts. Even though the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are just as amazing. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start your journey in Vancouver, which is one of the most beautiful big cities in Canada. Vancouver is special because it is close to both the ocean and the mountains. People living there can ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from the city center. In the past, thirty passenger trains left Vancouver every day on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still a great adventure. You can sleep on the train, which is fun, but you will travel through some of the most beautiful scenery at night.

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China created a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In the early zoos, animals were made to perform tricks for visitors. This does not happen anymore because now zoos are places where people can see animals acting naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or a wildlife park. However, not everyone likes zoos. People who support zoos say they help us learn about nature and see wild animals up close, which we couldn't do without zoos. On the other hand, some people do not like zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and eat the wrong food.'

**JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14**

I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes. My band wore black school uniforms, while others wore bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to performing in competitions. The quality of playing was amazing, especially because everyone was so young. Players from each band even made up new tunes right there on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played on stage!

We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play in it gets accepted. Only about half of the students do. But anyone who really wants to play goes to jazz practice before school. We often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country. I've been to a couple and learned a lot.

Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for people like me who are serious about music. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old at the same time. You can create your own music, but you also feel like you're part of its history, playing on stage like great jazz performers before you.

My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we wouldn't get anywhere with our music!

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. It doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. However, because many winters have been dry recently, the rain is welcomed by the local people. Marrakesh's parks and gardens are not there because of the rain. They exist because of underground channels, dug in the 11th century, that bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. If you travel further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used to grow food. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old and the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has older brothers who work in banking and computers, but Gareth always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. Kath says, 'People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three.' 

When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to try to find full-time jobs in a circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go back home in the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. Kath says, 'I can't say it was easy. There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths.'

Gareth says, 'People ask about my education, but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I use the same books as everyone back at school, and I have a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates.' 

And what about the future? Kath says, 'It was a difficult decision, but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it.' And Gareth? 'I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day,' he says, 'maybe Bippo's circus.'

Eight-eighteen News

Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8 to 18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to big newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites to be published. You can read or listen to the news stories and articles by our members on the Eight-eighteen website if they are accepted by newspapers and TV or radio stations.

We have three centers in the country where young people can meet other members and join projects. We plan to open more centers across the country. Our news agency started in 1994 and was first called 'Young News'. Since then, over 2,500 young people have been members.

Sophie was one of our members. She says, "I first heard about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article about young people's opinions on hip hop music. I was amazed by the opportunities the young journalists had. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to do the stories on their own. I started going to the Eight-eighteen center in my city, got some training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I thought possible. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, checking articles before they go online."

Get involved at every level

When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training and join monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen encourages members to share skills. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members who are 12 years old and over. They train new members and teach them basic journalism skills. As they gain more experience, some members present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are always supported by older staff who go with them on these trips.

Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training for new members will be in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with reading and writing skills at all levels. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight.

**About the Flights**

During the short Antarctic summer, we offer sightseeing flights over Antarctica. We fly from Sydney, Australia, in a large passenger plane (Boeing 747) and return the same day. Flight dates for next year are not set yet, but if you book now, you can change your date if needed.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and then return home. During the flight, experts who have lived in Antarctica give talks about the environment and history. They also answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you the view from the cockpit on the plane's video system.

**Will I get a window seat?**

All passengers get two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you will change seats. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half of the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half of the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. While over Antarctica, you can walk around the plane to see the sights. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' so everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.

**What if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 different flight routes. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the weather and chooses the route with the best views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most wildlife lives at sea level, which is over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them clearly. We do not land in Antarctica to protect the environment. To see wildlife, you would need to take a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Yes, you can take photos. All cameras are welcome. We also have some fun photo opportunities on board where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs

For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are for learning how to cook seriously. Their weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children who want to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food.

Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to eat the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really liked it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too interested at first. But I'm really glad I decided to come.'

Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it's hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog might be waiting for you at the top of a hill. Ice can be hiding under the melting snow, ready to make you slide off the road. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, when you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive so you don't spill it. Rule Number Two is to pay attention to what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison

Craigie Aitchison was a painter born in Scotland. He moved to London to study law but decided to go to art school instead. At art school, he found traditional drawing classes hard, but he continued to paint. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art in Italy. There, he became interested in early Italian artists, and this can be seen in some of his work. He loved the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. To do this, he painted colors in thin layers, from light to dark. He says he never knows exactly how the painting will turn out. He explains, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound easy, like anyone can do it. 'Anyone can use colors - you can buy them. I just notice what colors go well together.' Unlike some artists, he doesn't make drawings before starting a painting because he thinks he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he likes models who don't ask to see their pictures while he's painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he hasn't felt connected to the Scottish art scene. He says he doesn't want to follow any tradition and just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we didn't like the idea because of the noise. Ben said, 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time, and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'Okay,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band started coming to our home with their guitars and other electric equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must say that, although their music sounds a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a great private school in Wales. This school is special because it gives young people important experiences outside the classroom, as well as helping them study for their exams. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from all over the world. In the morning, they study, and in the afternoon, they do useful activities. These activities include helping on a farm, taking care of people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the best things about Atlantic College is that its students come from many different countries and social backgrounds. Since not many can pay the fees of £20,000 for two years, there are grants available. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them can only attend because they get help from the government.

"I really admire the college for trying to encourage international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even those you don't like. During the summer holidays, my mother couldn't believe how much less I argued with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College gives its students an excellent education with methods that really seem to work.

Text: 'Being an older student At 32, I have just finished my first year at university. I go to lectures regularly, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, I was earning a good amount of money, but I was bored because I didn't have to think much. I felt sad because I thought I would be stuck in that job forever. I was jealous of the students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope, and I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I'm a student, I find it hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I can't answer. I also feel different from the teachers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am happy to study because I know I need a qualification to get a good job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending my weekends with my books instead of going to parties. There are also normal student benefits like long holidays and discounts at the theatre and cinema. I often wonder what I will do after university, but I hope that going back to school at this age was a good decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not enjoy farming. At the age of fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cars that were cheap enough for ordinary people to buy. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars every day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this also meant there were fewer choices. Henry Ford once said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course starts in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs £150. If you want to start in June, we have another course that lasts 10 weeks and costs £200. I hope this information helps you. Yours, David May

Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before she climbed the highest mountain in the world, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small apartment in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is difficult. "You have to carry everything on your back," she said, "so you can only take what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and in the end, I didn't even take a toothbrush. I usually like to be clean, but there is no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!" When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now she has written a book about the trip, and people often ask her to talk about it. She also has a new job on a science TV show. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in the small apartment in south London with her pictures and books about mountains!

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? The party was really good; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some nice presents. I will tell you more about the party when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are big birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are very cold, and the birds can die if they stay there. Last spring, Bill Lishman found sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane, and he decided to teach the birds to follow him. All summer, he took short trips in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When the cold weather came in autumn, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and went back home. This spring, Bill waited for the birds to return. They didn't come, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't find them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Esther's Story

When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. Most of Esther's friends chose to go to college, but Esther used her aunt's money to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold the jam for £1 a jar to her friends and soon doubled her aunt's £500.

At first, her parents didn't want Esther to spend her time making jam. They thought she should study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. But Esther didn't listen. She kept making jam. After a few months, she started selling it at the local market. Then she began making orange juice and sold it to a school where one of her friends worked.

After two years, her business grew very large, and her parents were very happy with her. She made all kinds of food and sold it to shops and supermarkets. She was so busy that she had to hire some people to work for her.

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to come to the cinema with me after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film starts at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I am very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has some work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline '

Corryvale Farm is in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler have cows and chickens and sell milk and eggs. But most of their money comes from Jenny's sheep. She has 50 sheep, and each sheep has enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen cuts the wool off the sheep so they don't get too hot. 

Five years ago, Jenny made some sweaters with the wool and tried to sell them at country markets. But it was summer, and the weather was hot, so people didn't want to buy sweaters. Then she made some socks. Everyone loved them because they were cheap, strong, and easy to wash. That's how Jenny's business started. 

At first, she made the socks at home, but soon she had many customers, so she had to send the wool to a factory. Now, all the socks are made by machines. There are six colors, five sizes for all ages, and different socks for walkers, sportsmen, and skiers. Jenny is busiest at Christmas because Corryvale socks are a favorite gift. In Jenny's office, there are many letters from happy customers from all over the world.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived here three weeks ago. I am studying at a language school in Brighton. The students come from many different countries, and I have made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I like our teacher very much. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I want to visit London next weekend because I am going back to my country on Monday. Can I see you there? Please write to me soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS LOVE THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries happen between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., say the police. Inspector Ian Saunders told our newspaper that the number of house burglaries has increased by more than 30% compared to last year. He also said that 67% of burglaries happen when people leave and forget to close a door or a window. He explained that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually at home then. But he said that winter afternoons are the best time for burglars because it is dark and they can't be seen easily. Also, many houses are empty at that time because people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders said it is a good idea to leave lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday. This will help to keep burglars away. He also asked neighbors to watch the other houses in the street when people are not at home. They should call the police if they see anything strange. 'We will also tell you how to make your house safe,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This kind of help costs nothing.''

Dear Lynne and Tony,

Thank you for letting me stay in your lovely home for two nights. It was nice to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you wanted. They are good photos, right? I hope you like them. I really love my new camera. Next week, I am going to visit my sister in New York. I will take many photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time.

Thanks again.

Love,  
Roy

Text: 'The History of Farming Before people started farming, they went to the forest to find plants or fruit they could eat. This meant that people were always moving to find food. But about 12,000 years ago, in the Middle East, people began to grow their own food. These people were the first farmers. Farming allowed people to stay in one place, and their villages slowly became bigger. Some people in the villages could do other jobs, like making clothes, because the farmers grew food for everyone. Unfortunately, farming was hard when the weather was bad, and then some people did not have enough food to eat. Today, farmers can grow more food, and it travels thousands of kilometers from where it is grown to our homes.'

Nicola Peet started working after she finished school at eighteen. She went to college and then got a job at a local airport. After nine months, she worked for Saudi Arabian Airlines. Later, she joined British Airways as an air hostess. Four years after that, she became a manager, which is her job now. 

Nicola's office is at Heathrow Airport, but she spends 60% of her time flying. She teaches air hostesses and helps them with any problems. She also attends many meetings. Her work hours are usually from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes she works from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. 

At work, the first thing Nicola does is check plane times on her computer. Then, she talks to some of the air hostesses. Sometimes, she goes on long flights to see how the air hostesses are doing. This is her favorite part of the job, but she also likes working in the office. 

Traveling can be tiring. When Nicola returns from a long trip, she just eats something and goes to bed. She doesn't earn a lot of money, but she is happy working for British Airways and wants to stay there to keep traveling.

Dear Maria,

It's nice to be back home in my country, but I still think about all the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my visit was too short. I want to go back to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still looking for a job? I hope you find one soon.

Love, Sophie

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8.30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a large blue bag and my name is written on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms Johnson, I am happy to tell you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can give it to you. The office opens at 9 a.m. and closes at 6.30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson '

People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for people in different jobs. For example, the weather is very important for farmers. Many years ago, farmers spent a lot of time looking at the sky, animals, and flowers to try to understand the weather. Now, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather information on their mobile phones. Today, many people still believe in old ideas about the weather. They say, for example, that if there is a red sky in the evening, it will be sunny the next day. Some people also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will rain soon.

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small town in Canada. They have always been friends and go to the same school. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing or swimming on weekends. But recently, they have been spending their weekends in Peter's room working on his laptop. This is not because they have a lot of homework. They have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's little brother, Kevin, who has trouble reading. Kevin learns words better by seeing pictures and hearing sounds than by reading. Frazer wanted to help him. Frazer and Peter worked together for more than 200 hours to make the game, and now it is ready to use. It is a game with pictures and sounds. For example, when you see the word 'hat', there is a picture of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' at the same time. The two boys have won many prizes for their game, and it will soon be sold around the world. Many schools want to buy it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I go to my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. But after a concert, it's hard to sleep because I keep thinking about the music. Sport is important too. Before my car accident, I went to the sports centre for two and a half hours a day, five days a week. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's good for health. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always do that. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but I also like doing other things. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's good to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since the doctor told me to eat better. Now, I eat lots of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still eat burgers sometimes!'

Bollywood

'Bollywood' is the name of the film industry in Mumbai, India. It makes almost 1,000 films every year. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has made over 29,000 films. This is more than the USA, making it the biggest film industry in the world. Most Indians enjoy watching films more than any other free-time activity, and ten million people go to the cinema every day. Bollywood films usually tell romantic love stories, and singing and dancing are important parts of each film. Indian films are also popular outside India. Last year, Bollywood earned over $500 million by selling its films to other countries. Indian actors make more films each year than American actors in Hollywood, but they do not earn as much money. This is why most Bollywood films only cost about $2 million to make. A Hollywood film usually costs at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young. They work hard but only for a few years. Amitabh Bachchan, who some people say is India's greatest actor, is different. He has been the star of more than 140 films in a career that has lasted almost 40 years.

Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written many travel books about England. I lived in England with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the United States. I think they will be happier because they have lived in two countries. I like Britain and want to go back, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so we will stay for another four years. I just visited England for six weeks to work on a radio program about the English language and to talk about my new book. Most writers don't like doing this; they don't like traveling around the country to promote their book. I don't mind it. I enjoy visiting new places and meeting many people. It's very different from my life in the United States when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.

Schnauzer Dogs

There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes came to England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer came more recently. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair, which needs to be cut often. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, but the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers come from Germany. Farmers in Germany use these dogs to help with their sheep. The police also use them because Schnauzers are very smart. A Schnauzer is a good family dog. It is friendly and very good with young children.

Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two big towns. Mary said, 'It was very difficult because there was no water to drink and no shops to buy food.' She also said, 'It was very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to go back next year to do more work there.

Dear Keira,

Thank you for your letter. I started at my new school today. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I will visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was happy because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time, and I really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I am scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he shouts a lot. I have to go now because I need to do my homework.

Hester

New Books This Month

The Long Night  
This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia. She works in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very sick, so Maha has to drive all night to take the baby to the nearest big city. They have many problems on the way.

Hard Work  
This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they do not have much money. Then one day, a man dressed in all black buys the most beautiful table in the shop.

Hospital or Cinema?  
Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine. But one day, she meets a man who asks her to go to the USA with him to become a film star. What will Tina do?

Horse racing has been an important sport for a long time. It started in Central Asia about 4,500 years ago and was popular in Greek and Roman times. Modern horse racing began when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. At first, races were long and only had two horses. But at the start of the 18th century, races became shorter and had more horses competing. Today, horse racing is watched by many people in the USA, second only to baseball. It is also popular in other parts of the world.

Nick Barlow is a world traveler who loves his job. He is a British actor and travels around the world to make TV shows. "People are friendly to me everywhere I go, and when I come home, I remember all the amazing things from each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but there are still some trips he wants to take. "I would love to visit South America and go back to Australia one day," he says. 

On each trip, Nick travels with a team. They bring cameras and other equipment needed for filming. Nick doesn't pack many things for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always makes sure to have some books in his suitcase. 

Nick's wife, Helen, is okay with him traveling for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When Nick returns, she enjoys listening to his travel stories. However, sometimes there are problems. Once, when Nick was in the Malaysian rainforest, he heard that Helen was sick in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so happy when I heard she was better," he says.

Parrots

Maybe you have seen these beautiful birds with their bright colors and long tails in the forest or at the zoo. Parrots live in countries like Brazil, Australia, and India. They usually live in big groups. Because they like to eat fruit, they can sometimes cause problems for farmers. There are many different types of parrots, but they all have strong beaks and feet. They use these for climbing and holding food. The biggest parrots can live for up to 80 years. They are very noisy, but they are smart birds, and you can teach them to talk easily. Some zoos have parrot shows where you can watch the birds do tricks they have learned.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a lovely village about fifty kilometers west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr. Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written in French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on lots of clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and eat in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy to do? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and it's much harder to cook for fifty people than to cook for your family, but he is sure he has done the right thing.'

John Pickering works in a park in a small town in central England. He cuts the grass and waters the flowers. But last week, he was in Tokyo, and many people in Japan watched him on TV. John is 35 years old and is the most popular singer in Japan right now. 

A few months ago, John went to Japan to sing in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A radio DJ heard his songs and played them on his show. Many young people called the radio station and asked to hear the songs again. In Japan, John uses the name Jon Otis when he sings.

Even though he is famous in Japan, John will keep working in the park in England. He does not know how much money he will make from his music yet. He says, "I must keep my job in the park. I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners do not know he is famous in Japan, and they have never heard him sing.

John's wife, Denise, works in a hospital. She says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Memo To: All staff  
Subject: Holidays  
From: D Brown  
Date: 22.2.02  

I am planning the holidays for next year. Please tell me when you want to take your holiday. If you can, give me two date options. Please let me know by the end of the month. Thank you.  
D Brown  

---

Memo To: D Brown  
Subject: Holidays  
From: J Green  
Date: 23.2.02  

Can I take two weeks' holiday in July? I would like the first two weeks, but if that is not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Also, can I take three extra days in the first week of December?  
John

Line Dancing

Thousands of people in Britain have a new hobby called line dancing. In almost every town, you can find clubs and classes for this activity. Fiona Lever, a teacher, says, "Line dancing is easy to learn. If you have two feet and can walk, then you can do it!" You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to make new friends. In my classes, there are both young and old people. The boys like it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!

When did line dancing start? Most people think it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.

Text: 'The Rhino There are five different kinds of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open areas of Africa. The other types live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have big, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. The large body of the rhino stands on four short legs. Each foot has three toes. They usually walk very slowly, but they can run at 50 kilometers an hour. Rhinos are usually quiet and calm animals, and they only eat grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos when it is born. It stays inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live to be 50 years old.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE**

Today, there are policemen everywhere, but in 1700, London did not have any policemen. A few old men used to watch the city streets at night, and they did not get paid much. About 300 years ago, London started to grow bigger. The city was very dirty, and many people were poor. There were many thieves who stole money in the streets, so people stayed in their homes as much as they could.

In 1750, Henry Fielding began to pay a group of people to stop thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had become very big and needed more policemen. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force started with 3000 officers. Most of the men worked on foot, but a few rode horses. Until 1920, all the police in London were men. Today, London police are paid quite well, and for the few police officers who still ride horses, the pay is even better than for the others.

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Do you want to join a camping trip this weekend? We will go to the forest in the school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite has hot showers and a small shop, and you can rent bicycles there. The trip costs £25. It is very cold at night, so you should bring warm clothes and wear strong shoes. If you want to come, please tell me today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, many people come to Edinburgh, the capital city of Scotland, to join the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks every August and September, the city is full of actors and artists from all over the world. They come for the biggest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are full of music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even see artists painting on the streets. One of the best parts of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small halls and cafes. Many tourists come to the Festival to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, you can watch over five hundred performances with actors from more than forty countries. The tickets for these shows are quite cheap, and it is usually easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So come to Edinburgh next summer, but remember it can be hard to find a room, so why not book your hotel now!'

ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake turns to ice, and many Canadian fishermen go there every weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Then they sit inside to catch fish that swim under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy," he says. "First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,  

I'm not having a good week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team played much better than us! Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news.
