He can't come to stay with us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. And this morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school! She didn't tell me she needed it. I'm really angry with her. I hope you have some good news! Write back today if you can.  

Greg

Madame Tussaud's

A very famous place for tourists in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. In this museum, people can see wax figures of famous people. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle was a doctor who made wax figures of people. He opened a museum with these figures in Paris, and Marie helped him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was put in prison. While in prison, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous people who had died, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud. In 1802, she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her wax figures can still be seen today.

BICYCLES

Bicycles are a cheap and clean way to travel. The first bicycle was made about 150 years ago. At first, bicycles were expensive, and only rich people could buy them. These early bicycles looked very different from the ones we have today. Later, when bicycles became cheaper, many people bought them. People started riding bicycles to work and in their free time. Today, people use cars more than bicycles because cars are much faster, and you don't get wet when it rains! But some people still like to cycle to work. They say there are too many cars in city centers, and it's hard to find a place to park!

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I went to Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we visited a park near our hotel. The park had beautiful flower gardens, but we were most excited about the elephant show. We went to a big area with seats on three sides. Three elephants came in with their keepers and stood in front of large white cards. Each elephant got a paintbrush and started to paint on its card. Sometimes, the keepers gave the elephants a new brush with paint and took the old one away. Slowly, with help from their keepers, the elephants drew pictures on the cards. I couldn't believe my eyes! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers showed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they don't work there anymore, but the smartest elephants live in special places where visitors can watch them.'

Big Cats

There are many kinds of big cats. They are different in size, and they do not look or act the same. Tigers are the biggest cats. From head to tail, they can be 3.7 meters long. Most cats don't like water, but tigers often lie in water when it is hot!

Lions are the only cats that live in large family groups. Several lions work together to get food for the group. They usually live in flat, open areas where they can see far and easily follow other animals.

All cats need good eyes because they catch smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.

Dear Mrs. Brian,

I'm sorry, but I can't come to your class anymore because I have to go back to my country. My sister is getting married next month. I want to go shopping with her to choose a dress. My parents will make a big meal for the guests, and there will be a lot of work in the kitchen. I'm sorry I have to leave the English class. You are a very good teacher. Please say goodbye to the other students for me.

Thank you again.

Best wishes,  
Soraya

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please write back and tell me when you are free and where I can meet you. I hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I got it this morning. Yes, I would love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There is a good Italian restaurant near there. Do you like Italian food? I have to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Dear Lorna,

How are you? I'm happy because I got a new job in the city center last month. I work in a Tourist Information Office, and it is very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I like telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me. I'm wearing my new uniform. Do you like it?

Love,  
Gloria

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the biggest bird in the world. An adult ostrich can weigh more than 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches live in southern Africa, but there are not many left. Ostriches have wings like all birds, but they cannot fly. They use their wings to help them turn when they run. Ostriches can run very fast, between 65 and 90 kilometers an hour, so it is hard for other animals to catch them. Baby ostriches are the same size as chickens and need about 3 years to grow into adults. Ostriches eat plants and can live for many days without drinking water.'

Victoria Jamieson from Britain started snowboarding when she was 20 years old. Now, she is 23 and has won many snowboarding competitions. We talked to her last week at a snowboarding competition in Switzerland. We asked her why she started snowboarding. She said, "I have always liked sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding was a natural choice. It doesn't take long to learn, and you can become really good in a few months."

We also asked her if she practices a lot. She said, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains every day from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and go biking. I love doing all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because they are so beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding for fun when not in a competition, is the best thing for me."

We asked her what is important when learning to snowboard. She said, "You can learn quickly, but you need lessons. It's also important to have the right clothes so you don't get wet because, at first, you spend a lot of time falling down!"

23 Oak Avenue  
Manchester  

Dear Sir or Madam,

I want to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I need a single room with a shower and a telephone. Can I have a quiet room on the ground floor, please? I will drive to the hotel. Does the hotel have a car park? I will arrive at about 10:30 p.m. What time does the restaurant close in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal when I arrive. 

Thank you for your help.

Yours faithfully,  
Mark Jones

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. Many people have climbed it, including a seven-year-old boy and an 87-year-old man. There are different paths to reach the top. The Marangu path is five kilometers long and is thought to be the easiest. It takes about five days to climb and is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the people who try to climb Kilimanjaro make it to the top. This is often because the weather can change quickly. At the start, it can be hot and wet, but at the top, there is ice and snow, and the temperature can be below 20 degrees. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothes!

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They usually come out of their homes at night. Otters are very good swimmers and can swim faster than 10 kilometers an hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, which helps them stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, there were not many otters in Great Britain. The rivers were very dirty, so many fish and insects died, and the otters couldn't find food. But today, there is a lot of food for them because the rivers are clean again.'

Dear Deshini,

I'm happy you are my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I am fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there one day. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you can send me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family. I'll send more next time I write. I hope you write to me soon.

Tom

17 Green Street  
Camden  
London  
29th August 2002  

Dear John,

Thank you for helping me with my English. You are a very good teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying to become a doctor. I will stay with him for two weeks and then go back home to Greece. I like London a lot. Yesterday, we went to Regents Park by bus. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a movie with my brother and some of his friends. I will write to you again from Greece.

Best wishes,  
Kostas

Text: 'Dear David, I will visit your country next month with two friends. We don't know where to stay. Are there any cheap hotels in your town? We want to stay in the center. Can you help us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the center are expensive, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than my house! Is that okay with you? David'

People have always built different kinds of buildings. We need houses to stay warm and dry. We build stadiums to watch football games and concerts. We use buildings like museums to keep beautiful things safe. Many people work together to make a building. The architect decides how the building will look and draws pictures to show their ideas. Engineers make sure the building will be strong and safe. Then, workers build it carefully. The Sydney Opera House is a famous modern building with a beautiful roof. It looks nice from every side, not just from the top. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This interesting building looks like a glass tent.

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and I need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother will be 80 years old next month, and she is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I have grown a lot, and now all my trousers are too short! I want to buy some new trousers and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet me in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England that are close to each other. On the road between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a picture of a very large man. This man is called the Cerne Giant because the village next to him is called Cerne. Nobody really knows when the Cerne Giant was made, but people think it was a very long time ago. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the picture. If you go on the first of May when the sun rises, you will see all the people from the village dancing around the man on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the best runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she wants to run the 10,000 meters and maybe the 5,000 meters at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in big races. But she always laughed and smiled, and people in her city love her for that. Everything changed in 2004 when she ran her first half-marathon, which is a very long road race. She won with the fastest time of the year for any British woman runner.

Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, also used to race when he was younger. But he had to stop competing because he hurt his right leg. He can still run a little and sometimes trains with Gail. But it's not fun for Mike when Gail runs faster than him and he can't catch up. Gail trains hard. She does a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon. But she always takes a break from running on Sundays. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually cakes, but she can eat almost everything."

Piano Players - When They Were Young

Ivan Petrov  
Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. Ivan's mother started teaching him piano when he was six. At ten, he decided he wanted to write music and soon began his first song.

Oleg Gagarin  
Oleg was the youngest of five children. When he was four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him some traditional Russian music. At six, Oleg started piano lessons with a teacher in his city. He quickly began winning prizes for his piano playing. At fourteen, he went to a music college in Austria for two years. Later, he returned to Russia.

Josef Heptmann  
Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he started playing the piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months during a trip to England! Josef always liked music, but he was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now, but one day he wants to write his own music.

Bill Prince-Smith

Bill Prince-Smith did many jobs before he started writing children's books at 60 years old. He was a farmer, a teacher, and a dentist. Now, thirteen years later, he has written more than 80 books. Every day, he goes to his office to write. In the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' says Bill. His ten grandchildren don't live close by, but they also read his stories and say if they are good or bad. This way, Bill has learned what young children like to read.

Bill writes about life in his village and the farms nearby. His fifth book is his favorite: The Sheepdog is about a farmer and the dog that helps him. 'I have always liked animals,' says Bill, 'and dogs are so clever, they learn very quickly.' Last year, the book was made into a film with real animals and actors. The film-makers used new computer technology to make it look like the animals are talking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes film-makers change books, but they didn't change mine and I love the film.'

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people like to send postcards to their friends and family. These postcards usually have pictures of beaches, mountains, or castles on them, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards when they are on holiday because postcards are cheap, and the pictures on them are often better than people's own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century. It had a picture of a town by the sea. Later, postcards had pictures showing something in the news that week, like an accident or an important person's visit. People liked to see them because their newspapers did not have pictures then.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur because they died out about 60 million years ago, long before people lived on Earth. We don't know exactly why they disappeared. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs didn't all look the same. There were more than 5000 different kinds. Some were very small, but others were very big. The biggest ones were larger than any other animals that lived on land. For example, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and ate plants. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as big, but it was stronger. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast because it had long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can hurt people. Bears are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. But they do not see well. Like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears. The biggest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears. One type lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in South-East Asia. But not all black bears are black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Many people love the black and white panda bear, which comes from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in warm parts of the world, like Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water, but they can move quickly in water and on land. You often see many crocodiles together in big groups. They eat anything they catch, such as fish, birds, and small animals. Sometimes, they even eat big animals or people. There are more than ten different kinds of crocodiles. All crocodiles have very sharp teeth. They often lose their teeth, but new ones grow back quickly. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, but some are much bigger. Crocodiles can live for a long time. The oldest crocodile in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers made the first balloon that could carry people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers built the first plane with an engine and flew it. This happened in the United States. Then, in 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Aeroplanes changed a lot in the next thirty years. In the 1950s, aeroplanes became much faster because they got jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was made in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world and can fly at 2500 kilometres an hour, so the trip from London to New York takes only four hours. Today, millions of people travel by aeroplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was very different from visiting a theatre today. The building was round and had no roof, so people got cold and wet if it rained. The queen loved going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to watch plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors ate, talked to friends, walked around during the show, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same place near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a good holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water is very warm, and I love swimming there. The fish are all different colors: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
